? Anamul Hoque Shamim, ??? ?? and 8 others are new friend suggestions for you
That subject line? That’s a quote in The Economist by Jeff Dean, the director of Google Brain—Google’s AI department. He’s talking about a broad spectrum of organizations across a wide range of industries facing a similar problem: they have collected a quintillion bytes of critical data, but have no idea how to leverage it. They just don’t have the experts on staff.

That’s where you come in.
 
Our new Pro Intensive, Machine Learning Fundamentals ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/machine-learning-fundamentals?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=mlf_10_02_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), will teach you the skills that can solve problems for millions of companies. We’ll take you from zero experience to being able to build computer systems that can make intelligent predictions based on large datasets in just seven weeks. In this course, you’ll:
* Design and implement the building block of a neural network—an advanced Machine Learning technique that interprets data the way a human brain would.

* Build a Naïve Bayes classifier that correctly identifies different emotions in text messages and Amazon customer reviews.

* Use Python libraries to build a classifier that predicts whether cancer cells are malignant or benign. 

You’ll work with large, complex datasets to solve problems based on real-world scenarios—and develop the skills you need to ace a data science interview. Along the way, you’ll get help and feedback from our team of professional developers.
 
Sign up for our Machine Learning Fundamentals ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/machine-learning-fundamentals?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=mlf_10_02_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ) Pro Intensive today—and launch a new career tomorrow. Our next cohort starts on October 2nd.

Bangladesh Insight | Oct 01, 2018

http://albd.org

Oct 01, 2018 | Issue 207

NEWSLETTER

https://goo.gl/PTwymm

Rohingya crisis: HPM pushes for quick solution at 73rd UNGA meet https://goo.gl/PTwymm

In her address at the 73rd UN General Assembly at the UN headquarters on Thursday, Honourable Prime Minister (HPM) Sheikh Hasina has demanded immediate and effective implementation of the Myanmar-UN agreement on the solution to Rohingya crisis which is putting immense socioeconomic pressure on Bangladesh. The Bangladesh Premier said Bangladesh was appalled by what it saw in UN reports about atrocities against the Rohingyas, which are tantamount to genocide and crimes against humanity. On the sidelines of a high level meet, she pressed for three recommendations for solving the Rohingya crisis at its root, including abolition of laws, policies and practices of Myanmar against the minority group. 
 https://goo.gl/PTwymm

HPM receives 2 int'l awards for hosting Rohingyas https://goo.gl/PueDbE

https://goo.gl/PueDbE

HPM Sheikh Hasina has received two international awards -- the IPS International Achievement Award and the 2018 Special Distinction Award for Leadership -- for her humanitarian and responsible policy in hosting the Rohingyas and for her far-sighted leadership over the Rohingya issue. The Inter Press Service (IPS), one of the world's leading news agencies, and the Global Hope Coalition, a network of three not-for-profit foundations based in New York, Zurich and Hong Kong, honoured her with the two awards. The Premier received the awards at two functions in New York.

HPM for putting world on track of Paris Agreement https://goo.gl/M4Gybu

https://goo.gl/M4Gybu

HPM Sheikh Hasina has called for putting the world on the track of Paris Agreement to meet the long term goals of addressing the climate disasters. She hoped that UN members would utilise the opportunity in COP 24, slated for December this year in Poland, to have a more focused discussion on climate finance to meet pre-2020 ambition and long term goals of Paris Agreement. The Bangladesh Premier was addressing a high level dialogue of the leaders on Climate Change Implementation of the Paris Agreement-towards COP24 and beyond at UN Headquarters on Wednesday last.

HPM emphasises three actions for women empowerment at UN discussion https://goo.gl/yT412K

https://goo.gl/yT412K

HPM Sheikh Hasina has emphasised the need for three actions, including working for overcoming gender stereotypes regarding women's ability, to advance women empowerment. Addressing a high-level discussion on 'Economic Growth through Women Empowerment' at the Conference Room-3 of the United Nations Headquarters on Thursday on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, she called for enhancing women's productivity by addressing challenges specific to them -- including violence against women, and creating equal opportunities for women in all sectors of life and livelihoods with gender-responsive policy intervention. UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres was present at the event, hosted by President of Lithuania and Chair of the Council of Women Leaders Dalia Grybauskaite. 

US secretary of state Mike Pompeo meets Sheikh Hasina in New York https://goo.gl/JwDHgw

https://goo.gl/JwDHgw

US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo held an exclusive meeting HPM Sheikh Hasina in New York(USA) last week. During the meeting, a stream of bilateral issues came up, resulting in a further elevation in the ties between the countries. The meeting took place at hotel Grand Hyatt New York where the Bangladesh Premier stayed during her weeklong visit to the USA. DOn the other hand, a number of international aid and development organization chiefs also met the Bangladesh Premier, on the sideline of the UNGA.

UN expresses full solidarity with Bangladesh government https://goo.gl/JVqwhA

https://goo.gl/JVqwhA

The United Nations expressed full solidarity and cooperation with the government and the people of Bangladesh. ‘The UN expresses full solidarity and full cooperation with the government led by Sheikh Hasina and the people of Bangladesh,’ UN secretary general Antonio Guterres said in a meeting with the Bangladesh premier in New York. The meeting was held at the UN secretary general’s meeting room at the UN headquarters on last Thursday afternoon. The prime minister briefed him on different aspects of developments in Bangladesh.

HPM reiterates her commitment for ensuring free, fair and inclusive polls https://goo.gl/SBSQQP

https://goo.gl/SBSQQP

HPM Sheikh Hasina has said her government wants the next general election to be held in a free and fair manner with the participation of all political parties. She made the remarks when UK Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Jeremy Hunt met her at the bilateral meeting room of the UN headquarters in New York. In response to a request put forward by the UK envoy, the Bangladesh Premier said that her government wants all [political parties] to take part in the next election and it'll be free and fair. To this goal, the government has been working constantly for fulfillment of this goal. 

At UN, Bangladesh floats four ideas to engage youths in mediation for lasting peace https://goo.gl/x5DwjL

https://goo.gl/x5DwjL

Bangladesh has placed four ideas to engage youths in the mediation of conflicts for lasting peace as the role of youths in peace building is being recognised by the UN. State Minister for Foreign Affairs Md Shahriar Alam spoke at the UN high-level meeting of the Group of Friends of Mediation in New York and shared those ideas for conflict prevention, resolutions and mediation processes. First, he said, community projects can be developed to train and equip young women and men in mediation, ICTs, life skills and entrepreneurship. With these new skills they can become peace leaders who work within their communities to cultivate peace. Third, the state minister said, there could be initiative at regional and global level. All actors at sub-regional and regional level can also be motivated to play their roles. Fourth, he said, awareness can be built in the nations to reach out to the young people. The idea of mediation can be included in the academic curricula.

Asian Development Bank projects 7.5% growth rate for Bangladesh in FY19 https://goo.gl/F4pziV

https://goo.gl/F4pziV

Bangladesh posted a GDP growth rate of 7.9% in FY18, and is expected to achieve 7.5% GDP growth in FY19, according to a report by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). ADB announced the projection, releasing an update to its Outlook-2018 report in the capital. The GDP growth rate achieved in FY18 is the highest for Bangladesh since 1974, the report said. Over the space of last ten years, the country has seen a remarkable turn-around in most of the economic indices under the able and prudent leadership of HPM Sheikh Hasina.

HPM Sheikh Hasina: Architect of a different Bangladesh https://goo.gl/pGG1Vq

https://goo.gl/pGG1Vq

HPM Sheikh Hasina has been able to turn around the wheels of the fortune of the country's people since she took over the charge of Prime Minister in 2009. Bangladesh has achieved the highest level of socio-economic development during last several years under the premiership of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Bangladesh's growth rate has escalated from 5.05% to 7.86% during these years. Per capita income of the people of Bangladesh has increased from $703 to $1751. Inflation has gone down from 12.3% to 7.5%. Electricity generation capacity has increased from 5, 000 megawatt to 18, 000 megawatt plus. Export has increased from $15.6 billion to $36.7 billion. Import has increased from $22.5 billion to $54.5 billion dollars. Remittance has peaked from $9.7 billion dollars to around $15 billion. With the increase of export and remittance, foreign currency reserve has gone up from $7.4 billion to $32.9 billion. During last one decade the branches of different banks have increased by three folds. Deposits have increased by 2.47 folds and loans have mounted by 3.2 times.

HPM Sheikh Hasina's place in history https://goo.gl/afq8rM

https://goo.gl/afq8rM

In the forty-seven year independent history of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, HPM Sheikh Hasina has turned out to be the most formidable of politicians to have presided over the fortunes of this country. Where other politicians and the nation's two military rulers have been instrumental in creating problems, most of them seemingly insurmountable, HPM Sheikh Hasina has proved to be a problem solver. Her leadership has been firm, uncompromising and focused. She is the predominant force in national politics in these times, a head of government who is more than primus inter pares --- first among equals. It is a truth not to be denied, for the government is shaped around her personality in much the same way it was focused on Bangabandhu in an earlier era.

HPM Sheikh Hasina’s leadership delivers on promises https://goo.gl/cms4Yj

https://goo.gl/cms4Yj

In the last 10 years, Bangladesh has come a long way on the road of development because one politician has kept her biggest promises and pledges to the people. In 2008, the yet-to-be Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina talked of ‘Vision 2021’ in her ‘Manifesto of Change’ (Din Badaler Ishtehar), an aspiration to turn our country into a middle-income country by 2021. It was also a moment of national pride to learn that after being a least developed country (LDC) for more than four decades, in March 2018, Bangladesh for the first time, fulfilled the eligibility requirements to graduate to the ‘Developing Country’ status, as per the UN Committee for Development Policy (CPD). While the official approval can be as far off as 2024 that Bangladesh is on the right development track and trajectory, cannot be denied.

Indian minister praises Bangladesh economy https://goo.gl/3YE7Wo

https://goo.gl/3YE7Wo

The economic development of Bangladesh is a unique model and a good example for the rest of the world, said Indian Commerce Minister Suresh Prabhu, during his recent visit to Bangladesh. He said at first, social and human resources development took place in Bangladesh, followed by economic development. All the three developments happened together and it is unique, he said. The minister was speaking on Bangladesh-India trade relations at a dinner hosted by the commerce minister of Bangladesh at the Sonargaon hotel in Dhaka.

BANGLADESH AWAMI LEAGUE 23, Bangabandhu Avenue, Dhaka-1000. Bangladesh. http://albd.org

How to find datasets in data.world

Hi tushar1404116,

Search thousands of open datasets from government agencies, academia and the open data community on data.world. Beyond simple text search, you can try searching by:

- column header - column:zip (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkr0j9W5pvtW95hBlhKW6HjNBQ7R0PTZW99fC1C5_msSff1CYJMH13 )
- dataset tag - tag:twitter (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkr0j9W5pvtW95hBlhKW6HjNBQ7R0PTZW99fC1C5_msSff1CYJMH23 )
- file extension - extension:xml (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkr0j9W5pvtW95hBlhKW6HjNBQ7R0PTZW99fC1C5_msSff1CYJMH33 )

You can directly search data.world from the Chrome search bar by entering “data.world” in the URL bar and then pressing the space bar or the tab key. Afterwards, whatever you input in the URL bar will search data.world.

Lastly, check out your personalized activity feed for trending and relevant data, and to stay current on your data projects and topics of interest.

Explore your activity feed! (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkr0j9W5pvtW95hBlhKW6HjNBQ7R0PTZW99fC1C5_msSff1CYJMH43 )

Ashikur, you have 28 new notifications
Hi,

Today's blog post is on Keras vs. TensorFlow: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzg5NTc0MDEwNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMDgva2VyYXMtdnMtdGVuc29yZmxvdy13aGljaC1vbmUtaXMtYmV0dGVyLWFuZC13aGljaC1vbmUtc2hvdWxkLWktbGVhcm4vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

"Should I be using Keras vs. TensorFlow for my project? Is
TensorFlow or Keras better? Should I invest my time studying
TensorFlow? Or Keras?"

The above are all examples of questions I hear echoed throughout
my inbox, social media, and even in-person conversations with
deep learning researchers, practitioners, and engineers.

I even receive questions related to my book, Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzg5NTc0MDEwNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) where readers are asking why I’m covering “just” Keras — what
about TensorFlow?

It’s unfortunate.

Because it’s the wrong question to be asking. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzg5NTc0MDEwNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMDgva2VyYXMtdnMtdGVuc29yZmxvdy13aGljaC1vbmUtaXMtYmV0dGVyLWFuZC13aGljaC1vbmUtc2hvdWxkLWktbGVhcm4vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzg5NTc0MDEwNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMDgva2VyYXMtdnMtdGVuc29yZmxvdy13aGljaC1vbmUtaXMtYmV0dGVyLWFuZC13aGljaC1vbmUtc2hvdWxkLWktbGVhcm4vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

As of mid-2017, Keras was actually fully adopted and
integrated into TensorFlow. This TensorFlow + Keras integration
means that you can:

* Define your model using the easy to use interface of Keras
* And then drop down into TensorFlow if you need (1) specific
TensorFlow functionality or (2) need to implement a custom
feature that Keras does not support but TensorFlow does.

In short:

You can insert TensorFlow code directly into your Keras model or
training pipeline!

Don’t get me wrong. I’m not saying that you don’t need to
understand a bit of TensorFlow for certain applications — this is
especially true if you’re performing novel research and need
custom implementations. I’m just saying that if you’re spinning
your wheels:
* Just getting started studying deep learning…
* Trying to decide on which library to use for your next project…
* Wondering if Keras or TensorFlow is “better”…

…then it’s time those wheels got some traction.

Stop worrying and just get started. My suggestion would be to use
Keras to start and then drop down into TensorFlow for any
specific functionality you may need.

In today’s post, I’ll show you how you can train both (1) a
neural network using strict Keras and (2) a model using the Keras
+ TensorFlow integration (with custom features) built directly
into the TensorFlow library.

To read the full tutorial, just click here! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzg5NTc0MDEwNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMDgva2VyYXMtdnMtdGVuc29yZmxvdy13aGljaC1vbmUtaXMtYmV0dGVyLWFuZC13aGljaC1vbmUtc2hvdWxkLWktbGVhcm4vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Are you interested in learning Keras, TensorFlow, and Deep
Learning in more depth?

If so, you should take a look at my book, Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzg5NTc0MDEwNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Inside the book you'll find:
* Super practical walkthroughs that present solutions to actual,
real-world image understanding problems, challenges, and
competitions.
* Hands on tutorials (with lots of code) that not only how you
the algorithms behind deep learning for computer vision but
their implementations as well.
* A no-nonsense teaching style that is guaranteed to help you
master deep learning for image understanding and visual
recognition.

To grab a PDF of both (1) the table of contents and (2) sample
chapters to my deep learning book, just click here ( http://t.dripemail2. ), and I'll send you the PDF immediately.

Your table of contents and sample chapters PDF should arrive in
your inbox a minute or two after clicking the link.

Click here to grab your free table of contents + sample chapters
PDF. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

How to find datasets in data.world

Hi tushar1404116,

Search thousands of open datasets from government agencies, academia and the open data community on data.world. Beyond simple text search, you can try searching by:

- column header - column:zip (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk71MqW6jrNg_62DBGvW4Zr4jg78jWRTW9k7P0983QR2lf1CYJMH13 )
- dataset tag - tag:twitter (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk71MqW6jrNg_62DBGvW4Zr4jg78jWRTW9k7P0983QR2lf1CYJMH23 )
- file extension - extension:xml (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk71MqW6jrNg_62DBGvW4Zr4jg78jWRTW9k7P0983QR2lf1CYJMH33 )

You can directly search data.world from the Chrome search bar by entering “data.world” in the URL bar and then pressing the space bar or the tab key. Afterwards, whatever you input in the URL bar will search data.world.

Lastly, check out your personalized activity feed for trending and relevant data, and to stay current on your data projects and topics of interest.

Explore your activity feed! (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk71MqW6jrNg_62DBGvW4Zr4jg78jWRTW9k7P0983QR2lf1CYJMH43 )

Announcing Two New Courses

 

Good news! We're turning our course release cadence up a notch.

 

The spectacular enthusiasm from learners like you during our recent September sweepstakes has prompted us to deliver even more new courses faster than ever before. Now, we have plans to release a new course every week through the end of the year.

 

This week we're releasing two new courses that teach important skills in Computer Science and Data Science:

 

1. Sorting Algorithms ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/sorting-algorithms?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_15_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sorting lies at the heart of many problems in Computer Science. By understanding how to order a dataset, you'll unlock countless new levels of algorithmic thinking that will allow you to build faster and more scalable programs. This course starts from the classic bubble sort algorithm and moves on to advanced implementations which optimize for efficiency — such as merge sort, quicksort, and more.

( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/sorting-algorithms?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_15_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

2. Data Visualization in Python ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/data-visualization-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_15_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In Data Science, we find insights from data. But insights are powerless if we can't present them and convince others that our results are important. Learn how to visualize your findings using Python in this new course.

( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/data-visualization-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_15_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

The Monday Course Drop Continues
Hi,

In today’s brand new blog post ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzk3MzUxNzA2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMTUvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1oeWRyb3Bvbmljcy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1tYXJpanVhbmEvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) we will investigate a practical use case of applying deep
learning to hydroponics, a type of method used to grow plants
without soil using mineral-rich nutrient solutions in a water
solvent.

Specifically, you will learn how to train a Convolutional Neural
Network (CNN) using Keras to automatically classify root health ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzk3MzUxNzA2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMTUvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1oeWRyb3Bvbmljcy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1tYXJpanVhbmEvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) without having to physically touch the plants:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzk3MzUxNzA2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMTUvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1oeWRyb3Bvbmljcy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1tYXJpanVhbmEvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

The actual experiment design of this tutorial is motivated
by Darrah et al. in their 2017 paper, Real-time Root Monitoring
of Hydroponic Crop Plants: Proof of Concept for a New Image
Analysis System.

Such a system can improve the yields of existing hydroponic farms
making farms more efficient and sustainable to run. Of course,
the successful application of hydroponics
has massive implications for the medical marijuana industry.

While potentially controversial, and knowing full well that I’m
going to get a few angry/upset emails about this blog post, I
decided to publish today’s tutorial anyway. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzk3MzUxNzA2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMTUvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1oeWRyb3Bvbmljcy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1tYXJpanVhbmEvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

It’s highly educational for us at students, researchers, and
engineers to see practical examples of how deep
learning can and is being applied in the real-world.

I’d also urge you to keep in mind that we’re all researchers,
students, and developers here, and most importantly, we’re all
here to learn from practical, real-world examples. Be civil,
regardless of whether you agree or disagree with some of the
downstream implications of hydroponics.

With all that said, to learn more about how deep learning is
being applied to hydroponics (and how to train a custom CNN to
classify root health), just keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzk3MzUxNzA2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMTUvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1oeWRyb3Bvbmljcy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1tYXJpanVhbmEvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Today’s tutorial is not meant to be a discussion on the
legality, morality, or usage of marijuana — this is not a
platform to share “Legalize It” or NORML campaigns, anti-drug
campaigns, or simply have a discussion on the recreational use of
marijuana. There are more than enough websites on the internet to
do that already, and if you feel the need to have such a
discussion, please do, just understand that PyImageSearch is not
that platform.

P.P.S. If you're interested in more applications of deep learning
applied to real-world problems, be sure to check out my
book, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiMzk3MzUxNzA2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Inside the book you'll find real-world case studies on:

* Facial expression and emotion recognition
* Age estimation and prediction
* Animal species classification
* Vehicle make and model identification
* Working with large datasets, including my best practices, tips,
and suggestions

To grab a PDF of both (1) the table of contents and (2) sample
chapters to my deep learning book, just click here ( http://t.dripemail2. ), and I'll send you the PDF immediately.

Your table of contents and sample chapters PDF should arrive in
your inbox a minute or two after clicking the link.

Click here to grab your free table of contents + sample chapters
PDF. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

Search thousands of open datasets from government agencies, academia and the open data community on data.world.

Not rendering correctly? View this email as a web page here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykcdWdW9c9Z0N7tZhyzW7hQWdr4PgFfDW4xSZ_y973Lq-dBzP8M04 ) .

How to find datasets in data.world

Hi tushar1404116,

Search thousands of open datasets from government agencies, academia and the open data community on data.world. Beyond simple text search, you can try searching by:

- column header - column:zip (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykcdWdW9c9Z0N7tZhyzW7hQWdr4PgFfDW4xSZ_y973Lq-dBzP8N04 )
- dataset tag - tag:twitter (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykcdWdW9c9Z0N7tZhyzW7hQWdr4PgFfDW4xSZ_y973Lq-dBzP8P04 )
- file extension - extension:xml (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykcdWdW9c9Z0N7tZhyzW7hQWdr4PgFfDW4xSZ_y973Lq-dBzP8Q04 )

You can directly search data.world from the Chrome search bar by entering “data.world” in the URL bar and then pressing the space bar or the tab key. Afterwards, whatever you input in the URL bar will search data.world.

Lastly, check out your personalized activity feed for trending and relevant data, and to stay current on your data projects and topics of interest.

Explore your activity feed! (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykcdWdW9c9Z0N7tZhyzW7hQWdr4PgFfDW4xSZ_y973Lq-dBzP8R04 )

happy-sparkle.png

Cheers!

The data.world team

7000 N. Mopac Expy

Suite 425

Austin

TX

78731

Announcing Two New Courses

 

Happy Monday!

 

We know it's corny, but this week the Fall season (plus some pun-kin pie) is leafing smiles on our faces at our New York headquarters. If you've wondered how computers autumnatically make predictions or quickly find data, our two new courses released today will be a treat:

 

1. Search Algorithms ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/search-algorithms?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_22_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Being able to efficiently search through a dataset is a fundamental Computer Science skill. This course will help you master two classic algorithms — linear search and binary search — and their implementations in Python. By the end, you will be able to write search algorithms from scratch in the "Searchcademy" project.

( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/search-algorithms?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_22_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

2. Linear Regression ( https://www.codecademy.com/courses/machine-learning/lessons/linear-regression/exercises/introduction?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_22_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

How many honey bees will be in America in the year 2050? We can predict answers to challenging questions like this using regression, a Machine Learning technique for numerical predictions. This course teaches you how to implement a linear regression model — giving you the valuable skills needed to discover answers to difficult questions of all kinds.

( https://www.codecademy.com/courses/machine-learning/lessons/linear-regression/exercises/introduction?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_22_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

No tricks, just treats
Hey
there,

Back during the summer (July/August-ish) I wrote a series of
tutorials on object tracking. Specifically, we learned how to:

* Track objects with OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1MjQzMDAwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDcvMzAvb3BlbmN2LW9iamVjdC10cmFja2luZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Perform multi-object tracking with OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1MjQzMDAwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDgvMDYvdHJhY2tpbmctbXVsdGlwbGUtb2JqZWN0cy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Build a "person counter" that can count the number of people
who enter and leave an area ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1MjQzMDAwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDgvMTMvb3BlbmN2LXBlb3BsZS1jb3VudGVyLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )
(such as a convenience store, department store, or building)

The people counter in particular leveraged the dlib library, and
more specifically, dlib's implementation of correlation trackers;
however, we have yet to discuss how to actually use these
trackers.

That's why, in today's post, we'll be discussing object tracking
with dlib: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1MjQzMDAwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjIvb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1MjQzMDAwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjIvb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Today's post will help you get up to speed with dlib's object
tracking algorithm and give you a better idea of how to utilize
it in your own applications.

Next week I'll be back to discuss how use dlib's object tracker
for multi-object tracking, including optimizations that can make
it many times faster than OpenCV's multi-object tracker.

But until then, be sure to give today's tutorial on object
tracking with dlib a read. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1MjQzMDAwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjIvb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

See you soon!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Do you know about dlib's object tracker...?
Hi,

Back in high school I was not that great of a public speaker.

The stress. The anxiety. The fear of making a stupid mistake and
saying something wrong in front of an auditorium filled with
people was paralyzing -- the pressure weighed on me and delivered
a severe blow to my public speaking confidence.

But after 4 years in graduate school filled with presenting
papers in front of battle hungry academics, just waiting to
pounce on you at first light of slipping up, and defending my
dissertation in front of my committee, knowing that I was going
to be grilled at any second, I was able to conquer my fear of
public speaking.

You see, I recently talked about computer vision, surveillance
and tracking, and the algorithms behind [bank] check detection
and recognition on the Hanselminutes podcast ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1NzUwNjQ0NSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cuaGFuc2VsbWludXRlcy5jb20vNDU2L2NvbXB1dGVyLXZpc2lvbi1leHBsYWluZWQtd2l0aC1weWltYWdlc2VhcmNocy1hZHJpYW4tcm9zZWJyb2NrP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ).

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1NzUwNjQ0NSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cuaGFuc2VsbWludXRlcy5jb20vNDU2L2NvbXB1dGVyLXZpc2lvbi1leHBsYWluZWQtd2l0aC1weWltYWdlc2VhcmNocy1hZHJpYW4tcm9zZWJyb2NrP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Scott Hanselman, the host of Hanselminutes, is a great guy and a
podcasting legend. Just being able to chat with him on a podcast
was quite the honor!

Anyway, the interview is pretty high-level (i.e. not that
technical) and is geared towards an audience that is just hearing
about computer vision for the first time. But it’s still a great
listen and I would definitely encourage you to check it out.

Just click here to give it a listen! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDA1NzUwNjQ0NSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cuaGFuc2VsbWludXRlcy5jb20vNDU2L2NvbXB1dGVyLXZpc2lvbi1leHBsYWluZWQtd2l0aC1weWltYWdlc2VhcmNocy1hZHJpYW4tcm9zZWJyb2NrP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Do you have any suggestions for podcasts that I should go
on? If so, just hit reply to this email and let me know!

Are you ready to test your skills?
Learning to code is more crucial now than it's ever been. But it can also be overwhelming. Because with hundreds of programming languages to choose, where do you start?
 
Turns out we have a strong opinion on that. Start with Python.
 
Here’s why. Python is one of the top workhorse programming languages used to solve problems in a wide range of organizations—including Facebook, Google, Spotify, and even NASA. But you don’t need to be a rocket scientist to accomplish amazing things with it.
 
In fact, part of Python's appeal to programmers working in a variety of fields is that, as flexible as it is, Python is also very easy to learn. And in our new Pro Intensive, Programming with Python ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pwp_10_30_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), you’ll master the fundamentals in just 7 weeks. In this course, you’ll:
* Get to know the basics of syntax, variables, code refactoring, and branching logic—plus how to document your code.

* Learn Object-Oriented Programming—and create simple building blocks of code that solve complex problems.

* Get feedback at every step of the way from our team of professional developers.

Even if you’ve never used Python before, this course will have you coding with confidence, fast. But don’t wait too long to sign up. Our next cohort starts on October 30th. Space is limited—reserve your seat today.

Enroll Now ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pwp_10_30_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=bottom_cta )

How to find datasets in data.world

Hi tushar1404116,

Search thousands of open datasets from government agencies, academia and the open data community on data.world. Beyond simple text search, you can try searching by:

- column header - column:zip (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yjPMzdW74jXLm7tFd4MW5clLRd55NLvBVh-FP75kQBs8dBzP8N04 )
- dataset tag - tag:twitter (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yjPMzdW74jXLm7tFd4MW5clLRd55NLvBVh-FP75kQBs8dBzP8P04 )
- file extension - extension:xml (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yjPMzdW74jXLm7tFd4MW5clLRd55NLvBVh-FP75kQBs8dBzP8Q04 )

You can directly search data.world from the Chrome search bar by entering “data.world” in the URL bar and then pressing the space bar or the tab key. Afterwards, whatever you input in the URL bar will search data.world.

Lastly, check out your personalized activity feed for trending and relevant data, and to stay current on your data projects and topics of interest.

Explore your activity feed! (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yjPMzdW74jXLm7tFd4MW5clLRd55NLvBVh-FP75kQBs8dBzP8R04 )

happy-sparkle.png

Cheers!

The data.world team

Suite 425

Austin

Announcing Two New Courses

 

Boo-yah!

 

We know learning to code can be frighteningly intimidating. But if you want to learn quickly and easily, a skeleton—a template program capturing and organizing the essential components that are difficult to set up—just might be your new best friend. The two new courses we're releasing today give you just that.

 

1. Introduction to Multiple Linear Regression ( https://www.codecademy.com/courses/machine-learning/lessons/multiple-linear-regression-streeteasy?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_29_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Finding an inexpensive apartment in any major city is an overwhelming process. Want tall ceilings? Location near a park? Doorman in the building? All of these criteria will inevitably affect rent prices. But by how much? We teach you how to predict the correlations between multiple variables and a response, such as rent prices, by building your own Multiple Linear Regression models. You'll even practice on a real dataset of apartments in New York City provided by StreetEasy.

( https://www.codecademy.com/courses/machine-learning/lessons/multiple-linear-regression-streeteasy?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_29_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

2. Building Interactive JavaScript Websites ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/build-interactive-websites?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_29_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

HTML, CSS, and JavaScript — learn how these foundational coding languages work together to add style and functionality to websites. This course will teach you the ins and outs of the Document Object Model (DOM), JavaScript Events, and the new template-generating framework Handlebars.js. To finish off this course, you will build basic functionality for an e-commerce website using JavaScript.

( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/build-interactive-websites?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_10_29_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

Break out the skeletons ?? 
Hi,

In today's brand new tutorial, ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjkvbXVsdGktb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) you will learn how to use the dlib library to efficiently track
multiple objects in real-time video:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjkvbXVsdGktb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

So far in this series on object tracking we have learned how to:

* Track single objects with OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDcvMzAvb3BlbmN2LW9iamVjdC10cmFja2luZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Track multiple objects utilizing OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDgvMDYvdHJhY2tpbmctbXVsdGlwbGUtb2JqZWN0cy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Perform single object tracking with dlib ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjIvb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Track and count people entering a business/store ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDgvMTMvb3BlbmN2LXBlb3BsZS1jb3VudGVyLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

We can of course track multiple objects with dlib; however, to
obtain the best performance possible, we need to
utilize multiprocessing and distribute the object trackers across
multiple cores of our processor.

Correctly utilizing multiprocessing allows us to improve our dlib
multi-object tracking frames per second (FPS) throughput rate by
over 45%!

To learn how to (efficiently) track multiple objects using
dlib, just keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzMjIxNzg0MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTAvMjkvbXVsdGktb2JqZWN0LXRyYWNraW5nLXdpdGgtZGxpYi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Multi-object tracking with dlib [w/ Python code]
Hi,

Today I want to share an interview I did with Saideep Talari, a
PyImageSearch Gurus graduate who was recently hired as a computer
vision engineer at a startup in India.

Saideep’s story holds a special place in my heart as it’s so
incredibly sincere, genuine, and heartfelt.

>> Click here to read the full story ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzNjk5NDk4NyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTcvMDYvMTIvcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC1ndXJ1cy1tZW1iZXItc3BvdGxpZ2h0LXNhaWRlZXAtdGFsYXJpLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

You see, Saideep comes from a very low income Indian family. They
did not have much money. In fact, online education (such as the
PyImageSearch Gurus course, Udacity, etc.) was considered a
“luxury”.

But that didn’t stop Saideep — he took it upon himself to study
computer vision, not only because he felt it to be
his passion and calling, but because he wanted to help his
family.

In fact, Saideep felt so strongly about studying computer vision
that he took out an educational loan from his personal bank to
help supplement the cost of the PyImageSearch Gurus course.

Saideep joined PyImageSearch Gurus in August 2016 and then
graduated in February 2017. I was consistently impressed with
his dedication, work ethic, and commitment to mastering computer
vision

Back in April I received an email from Saideep expressing his
happiness — he recently acquired a job at a computer vision
startup in India working with drone-based AI solutions.

During the interview process, the company gave Saideep a computer
vision assignment to complete. His solution was so
impressive that they immediately hired him and brought him on
board as a computer vision engineer.

Today, Saideep:

* Holds a very well paying job.

* Can take care of his family and support them.
* Has cleared all of his/his families' debts.
* Is currently doing what he loves — working with computer
vision.

Even more impressive, he has transformed from computer
vision student to computer vision engineer in just barely over
six months, proving there is undoubtedly money to be made working
in the computer vision space.

This is truthfully one of the most heartwarming computer vision
success stories I have heard and I am so incredibly proud of
Saideep and his accomplishments.

Join me in this interview ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzNjk5NDk4NyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTcvMDYvMTIvcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC1ndXJ1cy1tZW1iZXItc3BvdGxpZ2h0LXNhaWRlZXAtdGFsYXJpLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) and discover how Saideep transformed his life (and the life of
his family) by studying computer vision.

And if you have a second, be sure to leave a comment on the post
( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzNjk5NDk4NyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTcvMDYvMTIvcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC1ndXJ1cy1tZW1iZXItc3BvdGxpZ2h0LXNhaWRlZXAtdGFsYXJpLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) and congratulate Saideep on all his success.

Cheers,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Interested in following in Saideep's footsteps? If so, just
click here to learn more about the PyImageSearch Gurus course ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDEzNjk5NDk4NyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ), your first
step towards computer vision mastery.

Can you make $$$ working in computer vision?
Thanks for being a data.world community member for over a month. Here's another way you can practice modern data teamwork.

Not rendering correctly? View this email as a web page here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yk5qd9W6-7F1d5V5BvWW5-Ktt-59K0wfW37Vkyh6f3vYCdBzP8M04 ) .

logo.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yk5qd9W6-7F1d5V5BvWW5-Ktt-59K0wfW37Vkyh6f3vYCdBzP8N04 )

Hi there,

Thanks again for joining us at data.world. You’ve been a community member for more than a month now, and we’re grateful for your support of our mission to build the most meaningful, collaborative, and abundant data resource in the world.

I also wanted to invite you to join another community we’re proud to be a part of. The Manifesto for Data Practices (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yk5qd9W6-7F1d5V5BvWW5-Ktt-59K0wfW37Vkyh6f3vYCdBzP8P04 ) is a set of four values and twelve principles that we believe describe the most effective, ethical, and modern approach to data teamwork. I co-authored the manifesto along with a group of “data people” from diverse backgrounds including academia, business, journalism, open source, and the public sector. You can read it here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8yk5qd9W6-7F1d5V5BvWW5-Ktt-59K0wfW37Vkyh6f3vYCdBzP8Q04 ) .

If it resonates with you, please sign it, share it, and stay tuned for opportunities to help shape the future of data teamwork.

Sincerely,

Brett Hurt

Co-founder & CEO of data.world

Hi there,
Here is something exciting for you!
As a run-up to Bengaluru Tech Summit 2018, the Department of IT, BT and S&amp;T, Government of Karnataka, is organizing “Humane Code” - a truly global hackathon in collaboration with Global Innovation Alliance partner countries and innovation hubs from across the globe to create solutions that address local or global societal needs.
The mission of the BTS Global Hackathon is to create technology solutions and initiatives that will contribute to social good and address the needs and challenges facing humanity.
With cash prizes of up to 12,000 USD for the top teams, this is an amazing opportunity you just have to grab! That's not all. The Top 20 teams from across the globe will win a fully paid trip ed to the Bengaluru Tech Summit, which will boost knowledge and offer amazing networking and business opportunities.

 Register Now

Do send in your submissions by November 19, 2018.
Ps: All the participants who submit relevant solutions by November 19, will receive an Amazon Gift Voucher :)
Feel free to reach out to us in case you have any queries.
Regards,
Team Hackerearth

logo.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8N04 )

data_digest_banner_small.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8P04 )

Data Digest

Hi tushar1404116,

No time to waste. Let’s look at the data.

Haunted Places

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8Q04 ) ‘Tis the season for the scares. Whether it’s a house specifically built to traumatize, or supernatural beings haunting the halls of regular buildings, where do the ghosts roam on earth? Find out in this extra spooky dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8R04 ) .

Twitter Bot Detection for #WalkAway Campaign

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8S04 ) The #WalkAway Twitter campaign highlights Democrats who have supposedly left their political party. But how much of the hype was driven by bots, and who was behind it? Dr. Steve Kramer’s dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8T04 ) digs into the details. Check it out.

Human Trafficking 2016

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8V04 ) A perpetually underreported type of crime, Uniform Crime Reporting has seen an increase in data submissions over the years. Get a window into how law enforcement sees this crime from a data perspective. See how it looks like in this data.world dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/MmZ-8ykJ3mpW5mznZm8CHw5qW6ds7Cm9k5XNsW4qYsBz5DbLxMdBzP8W04 ) .

Cheers,

The data.world team

Announcing Two New Courses

 

To mark the fourth consecutive Monday course drop, we invite you to connect with us in our Facebook group ( https://www.facebook.com/groups/170643816928188/ ) — a new place we've set up for Codecademy students and alumni of all skill levels to come together.

 

There you'll be able to chat about any code-related topic you'd like, including the two new courses we're releasing today on perceptron ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/machine-learning?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_05_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) and recursion ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-recursion-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_05_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ). Introduce yourself, ask a question, or take a look to fuel your inspiration. As you'll see once you join, our sense of community at Codecademy is as cherished as home.

 

Now, without further ado, scroll down to learn more about our new courses on perceptron and recursion.

 

1. Machine Learning Neural Networks: Perceptron ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/machine-learning?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_05_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When you think of Machine Learning, you might think of Neural Networks. Neural Networks are combinations of individual blocks of code that mimic neurons. Learn how to code one single neuron, known as a Perceptron. This powerful Python class can separate data into different classes. You'll practice using Perceptrons to make logic gates, like AND and OR.
( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/machine-learning?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_05_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

2. Learn Recursion: Python ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-recursion-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_05_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Recursion gives you a new perspective on problem-solving by defining a problem in terms of itself. This mind-bending concept unlocks new strategies for reducing difficult tasks into a few lines of code. The best part is recursion is a concept which can be used in almost any programming language!
( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-recursion-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_05_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

P.S. Have you heard about our new course on recursion? Scroll up to learn more.

? Stay in the loop: open for a recursive message
Hey there,

Over the past couple of weeks I've been helping a family member
who is ill and I'm not going to lie, seeing them in that
condition has taken a bit of toll on me.

Some days I'm doing just great. Other days...not so much.

At this moment I could really use a laugh. Maybe you do as well.

And perhaps since the very first packet of data was sent across
the interwebz, one of the best ways to find LOLs is from memes.

Some of my favorite all-time memes include:

* Kermit the Frog’s “But That’s None of My Business”

* Grumpy Cat
* Epic Fail
* Good Guy Greg

But for me personally, none of these memes compare to the “Deal
With It” meme.

Using a photo of myself along with Jemma (the family beagle) as a
puppy, I used Python, OpenCV, and facial applications to create
the following GIF: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDIwMzYzOTcyNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMDUvY3JlYXRpbmctZ2lmcy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDIwMzYzOTcyNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMDUvY3JlYXRpbmctZ2lmcy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

To add a bit a context, "Deal With It" memes are normally:
* Used as a response or retort to someone being disapproving of
something you did/said
* Involve putting on sunglasses as you walk away, leaving them to
“deal with it”

Building a Deal With It meme generator using OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDIwMzYzOTcyNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMDUvY3JlYXRpbmctZ2lmcy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) can teach us a number of valuable computer vision techniques
used in practice, including:

* How to perform deep learning-based face detection

* How to use the dlib library to apply facial landmark detection
and extract the eye regions

* How to take these two regions and compute the rotation
angle between the eyes
* And finally, how to generate animated GIFs

Today’s tutorial ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDIwMzYzOTcyNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMDUvY3JlYXRpbmctZ2lmcy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) is meant to be fun, jovial, and above all, entertaining — all
while teaching you valuable computer vision skills that are used
in the real world.

To learn all of these skills, and have a laugh along the
way, just click here to read the full guide! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDIwMzYzOTcyNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMDUvY3JlYXRpbmctZ2lmcy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Enjoy it! And if you found it educational, fun, and/or simply
entertaining, please do leave a comment in the comments section
of the post.

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Didn't like today's tutorial?

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDIwMzYzOTcyNSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMDUvY3JlYXRpbmctZ2lmcy13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

According to PayScale, Machine Learning Engineers earn an average of $111,614 per year.
 
Why the high salaries? We’re in a machine learning arms race.

To gain a competitive edge, leading companies are using Artificial Intelligence (AI) to solve problems of all kinds. From chatbots that reduce customer support costs to medical software that can quickly analyze x-rays, and recommendation tools that drive new sales, the applications of AI are growing in scope and complexity.

But the number of people who can combine theoretical AI knowledge with practical, hands-on coding skills is not keeping up. Over the past 3 years, the number of AI-related jobs posted on Indeed has more than doubled—an increase of 119%. Nearly half of these new job listings remain unfilled for 60 days or more. That’s where you come in, where we come in.

 
Our new Pro Intensive, Machine Learning Fundamentals ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/machine-learning-fundamentals?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=mlf_11_13_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), will give you the skills you need to land one of those jobs. All you have to know is a little Python. We’ll teach you the rest, including:

* Scikit-learn—an essential Python library (and powerful data mining and analysis tool) that provides efficient, scalable versions of many common algorithms.

* Foundational concepts in multiple linear regression, predictive analysis, and classification of large, complex datasets.

* How to build your own classifier, neural network cell, and Python library—and leverage those skills to solve real-world AI challenges.

If you’re serious about a career in machine learning, Machine Learning Fundamentals ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/machine-learning-fundamentals?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=mlf_11_13_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ) is an ideal entry point. It takes you from basic Python skills to the ability to solve real-world challenges you might encounter at work—in just 7 weeks.

Space is limited, though. Reserve your seat today—our next cohort starts on November 13th.

Data Digest

Hi tushar1404116,

Let’s get right to the data.

U.S. Congressional Districts by Density

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdZwHW6FfTL98b_L_gW5f7D6w5pzzJkW5DTC8q6MYRR7f1CYJMH33 ) How does neighborhood density affect U.S. election results, including the midterm elections? Check out this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdZwHW6FfTL98b_L_gW5f7D6w5pzzJkW5DTC8q6MYRR7f1CYJMH43 ) to learn how competitive the races across the country were this week.

Social Influence on Shopping

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdZwHW6FfTL98b_L_gW5f7D6w5pzzJkW5DTC8q6MYRR7f1CYJMH53 ) As we head into one of the biggest shopping seasons, it’s no surprise that social media plays a big role in buying behavior. Find the data on how millennials shop in this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdZwHW6FfTL98b_L_gW5f7D6w5pzzJkW5DTC8q6MYRR7f1CYJMH63 ) .

Tourist Prices in Europe’s Most Popular Cities

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdZwHW6FfTL98b_L_gW5f7D6w5pzzJkW5DTC8q6MYRR7f1CYJMH73 ) Want to splurge for a once-in-a-lifetime vacation? Or maybe you're searching for a getaway on a budget? From London to Lisbon, dig into this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdZwHW6FfTL98b_L_gW5f7D6w5pzzJkW5DTC8q6MYRR7f1CYJMH83 ) to see the most economical (and expensive) European cities for tourism.

Cheers,

The data.world team

Announcing Three New Courses

 

What do Leonardo DiCaprio's character in Titanic and Leonardo DiCaprio's character in The Revenant have in common? They both should have read this email.

 

That's because this week's new courses are all about survival—surviving your technical interviews, surviving error messages, and surviving the sinking of the Titanic—with the help of Machine Learning:

 

1. Logistic Regression ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/machine-learning?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_12_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What’s the probability that you would have survived the sinking of the Titanic? Or that an email arriving in your inbox is spam? Discover how these predictions can be made with Logistic Regression, one of the most popular classification algorithms in Machine Learning. In this course, you will learn how the logistic regression algorithm works, discover how you can implement it yourself, and predict your survival as a passenger onboard the Titanic. All aboard!

( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/machine-learning?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_12_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

2. Technical Interview Practice: Python ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/technical-interview-practice-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_12_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You'll need to pass a technical interview if you want to be hired for a technical role. Don't worry—these interviews are pretty predictable, and the same kinds of problems appear again and again. We wrote a course to give you the practice that you need, starting with the Python list, a common built-in data type that is used in all kinds of problems. Learn about naive and optimal solutions and improve your chances of landing that job!

( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/technical-interview-practice-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_12_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

3. JavaScript Errors and Debugging ( http://codecademy.com/learn/javascript-errors-debugging?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_12_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When learning to write code, many people start to dread error messages. But error messages are actually your friend—they help you find and identify bugs and edge cases where your code is failing. This course will give you the tools that you need to understand, diagnose, and learn from every error message that you get!
( http://codecademy.com/learn/javascript-errors-debugging?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_11_12_18&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

? All aboard: Don't miss the boat on new courses
Hi !

I've got an awesome, brand new tutorial for you today!

Inside this blog post you’ll learn how to use the YOLO object
detector to detect objects in both images and video streams using
Deep Learning, OpenCV, and Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4MjgyNzIwNiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMTIveW9sby1vYmplY3QtZGV0ZWN0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ):

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4MjgyNzIwNiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMTIveW9sby1vYmplY3QtZGV0ZWN0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

By applying object detection, you’ll not only be able to
determine what is in an image, but also where a given object
resides!

Inside the post we’ll start with a brief discussion of the YOLO
object detector, including how the object detector works. From
there we'll look at some Python code that can be used to detect
objects using YOLO in both images and video streams. We’ll wrap
up the tutorial by discussing some of the limitations and
drawbacks of the YOLO object detector, including some of my
personal tips and suggestions.

To read the full tutorial, and learn how to apply YOLO to your
own images/video streams, just click here! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4MjgyNzIwNiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMTIveW9sby1vYmplY3QtZGV0ZWN0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. I've kept this under wraps for the past two months but now
it's time to spill the beans:

The 2nd edition of my book, Deep Learning for Computer Vision
with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4MjgyNzIwNiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ), will be releasing next week!

The second edition includes 4 brand new chapters (80+ pages of
additional content) covering topics, such as:

* RetinaNet, arguably the best deep learning object detector, and
training RetinaNet for logo detection.

* A case study on training an object detector for weapon
detection and then applying the weapon detector to images and
video streams.
* The Mask R-CNN architecture and applying it to cancer/skin
lesion segmentation, a required first step when building a cancer
identification system.
* A case study on how to annotate your own data for Mask R-CNN,
train a model, and then apply it to your own images. We'll be
exploring our case study in the context of prescription pill
segmentation.

All of these chapters are super practical and illustrate how deep
learning can be used in actual real-world applications. Just
check out a sample of the results below:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4MjgyNzIwNiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

As you can see, these chapters are the real deal —
they're exactly what you need to become
proficient in state-of-the-art deep learning, build your own
applications, and become successful at applied deep
learning.

These four chapters will be included in the ImageNet Bundle of
the book. 

I'll be back on Wednesday with more details so stay tuned...

Hi,

I’ve got a very special blog post to share with you today. To
date, this article ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4Nzc0NTgwNCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTQvMTIvMDEvY29tcGxldGUtZ3VpZGUtYnVpbGRpbmctaW1hZ2Utc2VhcmNoLWVuZ2luZS1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) is the longest and most detailed post I have ever done on the
PyImageSearch blog -- it’s the real-deal and is jam-packed with
all the necessary details you need to build a basic image search
engine of your own.

In reality this 7,000+ word mammoth article might be better
suited in a textbook than on the PyImageSearch blog...but I had
to share it with you since I thought you would enjoy it and could
apply it to your own projects.

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4Nzc0NTgwNCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTQvMTIvMDEvY29tcGxldGUtZ3VpZGUtYnVpbGRpbmctaW1hZ2Utc2VhcmNoLWVuZ2luZS1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Because let’s face it. Trying to search for images based on text
and tags sucks.

Whether you are tagging and categorizing your personal images,
searching for stock photos for your company website, or simply
trying to find the right image for your next epic blog post,
trying to use text and keywords to describe something that is
inherently visual is a real pain.

I faced this pain myself last Tuesday as I was going through some
old family photo albums that there were scanned and digitized
nine years ago.

You see, I was looking for a bunch of photos that were taken
along the beaches of Hawaii with my family -- but I just couldn’t
find them. It was like looking for a needle in a haystack.

While applications such as iPhoto and Picasa let you organize
your photos into collections and even detect and recognize faces,
you can certainly do more.

No, I’m not talking about manually tagging your images. I’m
talking about something more powerful. What if you could actually
search your collection of images using an another image?

Wouldn’t that be cool? It would allow you to apply visual search
to your own images, in just a single click.

And that’s exactly what this blog post covers. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4Nzc0NTgwNCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTQvMTIvMDEvY29tcGxldGUtZ3VpZGUtYnVpbGRpbmctaW1hZ2Utc2VhcmNoLWVuZ2luZS1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

By the time you finish reading it you’ll be able to build an
image search engine from your own photo albums...and apply visual
search to your own projects.

So give it a read ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDI4Nzc0NTgwNCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTQvMTIvMDEvY29tcGxldGUtZ3VpZGUtYnVpbGRpbmctaW1hZ2Utc2VhcmNoLWVuZ2luZS1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ). And then hit reply to this email and let me know what you
thought!

I look forward to hearing from you,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearch
