Hi,

On Monday I announced that the 2nd edition of my book, Deep
Learning for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDMwNzM5MDg5OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (DL4CV) will be releasing next Thursday, November 22nd at noon
EST.

The second edition includes 4 brand new chapters in the ImageNet
Bundle covering more advanced computer vision + deep learning
topics, including:

* The RetinaNet object detector and how it can be used for logo
detection

* Training RetinaNet to detect weapons in images and video
streams

* The Mask R-CNN architecture and how to apply it to skin lesion
segmentation and cancer identification

* How to annotate your own data for Mask R-CNN, train a model,
and then apply it to your own images

Today I want to share with you a sneak preview of what you can
expect inside each of these four additional bonus chapters.

**************************
RetinaNet + Logo Detection
**************************

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDMwNzM5MDg5OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

When it comes to training your own custom object detectors, there
are two primary frameworks I use above all others: Single Shot
Detector (SSDs) and RetinaNet.

Both strike a balance between speed and accuracy. Furthermore,
they usually tend to be a bit easier to train and fine-tune on
your own custom data.

The first edition of DL4CV already covered SSDs — the second
edition adds a chapter on RetinaNet, including the theory behind
it, why it works, and how it's different than other deep learning
object detectors.

Inside this additional chapter I'll show you how to:

* Work with the logos dataset, parse it, and become proficient in
preparing image datasets for object detection (a critical skill
when working with your own data)
* Train RetinaNet to detect logos in images

* Use RetinaNet on your own custom datasets

I've included my pre-trained logo detector in the download of the
book is well, enabling you to detect logos in images and video
streams as soon as you download the files.

Furthermore, the knowledge gained from this chapter will enable
you to train your own custom object detectors on your own data as
well.

****************
Weapon Detection
****************

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDMwNzM5MDg5OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

If you've been following the news in the United States then you
know gun violence and mass shootings have become an unfortunate,
frequent occurrence.

I think we can agree, regardless of stance on the right to own
guns, that we should all be doing something to help prevent these
tragedies.

As computer vision and deep learning engineers, one way we can
help is to apply object detection to specifically detect guns in
images and video streams.

Such an application of weapon detection could be used in schools,
home security systems, places of worship, etc. as an "early
warning system".

For example:

You can imagine a school with security cameras both inside and
outside the building. A weapon detection object detector is
applied to every frame of the video feed. If a weapon is found,
the system raises an alarm throughout the school to warn students
to take shelter and advise teachers to barricade the doors. The
system could also alert the school principal and potentially
issue an automatic 9-1-1 call to the police, ideally preventing,
or at the very least dissuading, a potential tragedy.

In this new chapter you'll:

* Gain additional experience working with image + bounding box
data
* Train RetinaNet to detect weapons
* Apply the weapon detector to images and video streams

I've written this chapter as a case study and included the
pre-trained RetinaNet weapon detector in the download associated
with the text.

It is my sincere hope that you use the knowledge and pre-trained
model in the book to develop your own weapon detection systems to
help prevent these tragedies.

******************************************************
Mask R-CNNs for Cancer Segmentation and Identification
******************************************************

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDMwNzM5MDg5OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

The past few weeks have been really tough on me — I found out
that a close relative has cancer.

Last week they went through an operation to remove the tumor and
since then I've been helping take care of them. They are doing
well and we're hoping for remission and no evidence of the cancer
the next time we visit the doctor.

I'm almost certain that you know a relative who has/had cancer.
Maybe it was you yourself. And I think we can agree and relate to
what a powerless and hopeless feeling that can be.

A few weeks ago I was looking for a way to regain that feeling of
control and throw that hopeless feeling in the ditch, leaving it
behind.

I found my sense of control again when Abhishek, who works with
me here at PyImageSearch, brought to my attention a dataset for
skin lesion segmentation and cancer/Melanoma identification.

While my relative's particular cancer was not Melanoma I still
wanted to contribute to cancer research and do my part.

Over the course of a week I worked with the dataset and performed
a number of experiments with Mask R-CNN to automatically segment
skin lesions from images, a critical first step in cancer
identification.

After I ran the experiments I decided to include them in the 2nd
edition of DL4CV.

Inside this new chapter you will:
* Learn how the Mask R-CNN architecture works, including the the
theory surrounding architecture and how it uses Faster R-CNN as a
building block.
* Discover the similarities and differences between traditional
segmentation, object detection, semantic segmentation, and
instance segmentation
* Learn how Mask R-CNN can predict pixel-wise masks that can be
used for segmentation
* Train a Mask R-CNN to automatically segment cancerous
regions from an input image
* Discover my tips, best practices, and suggestions when training
your own Mask R-CNNs

I have also included my pre-trained cancer segmentation model in
the download of the book so you can use it for your own projects
right out-of-the-box.

If you have any interest in medical deep learning + computer
vision then this is the chapter for you.

************************************************
Annotating Your Own Training Data for Mask R-CNN
************************************************

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDMwNzM5MDg5OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

One of the most common questions I receive from readers either
already using Mask R-CNNs or wanting to use Mask R-CNNs is: "How
in the world do I create my training data?"

Creating a training dataset for Mask R-CNN is significantly more
complicated than annotating a dataset for image classification or
even object detection.

Not only do you need the class label for each object in the image
but you also need to create a pixel-wise mask as well!

But how do you go about creating your dataset? What tools can you
use to create these labels and masks? And how do you even get
started training a Mask R-CNN?

I answer all of these questions inside this additional case study
chapter in DL4CV.

Inside the case study you will:
* Discover my favorite image annotation tools and learn how to
use them

* Obtain hands-on experience annotating an example dataset for
prescription pill segmentation, the process of automatically
segmenting pills from images (a first step in pill
identification)
* Learn how to train your own Mask R-CNN on your own dataset,
allowing you to take the knowledge gained from this chapter and
apply it to your own projects

You might be wondering, "Why prescription pills for the case
study?"

Each year, over 3.3 million injuries and deaths happen due to the
incorrect prescription pill being taken. By using computer vision
to identify pills we can help prevent these injuries and deaths.

And like I said, you can take the skills and techniques you learn
from this chapter and use them to train a custom Mask R-CNN on
your own dataset.

*****************************************************
Interested in these chapters? Mark your calendar now.
*****************************************************

So here's the deal:

The 2nd edition of Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python
( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDMwNzM5MDg5OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) will be released Thursday, November 22nd at noon EST.

And yes, THERE WILL BE A THANKSGIVING/BLACK FRIDAY SALE to
celebrate the release.

Exactly what is the sale?

Well...I'll talk more about that next week, but I will say this:

If you've been interested in picking up a copy my books or
courses you should earmark some funds now. This will be
the biggest sale I've ever ran.

Mark your calendars now and keep an eye on your inbox — I'll be
back with more info soon...

Adrian Rosebrock

Find out when you connect more tools and sources to fresh election data right in data.world.

logo.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH03 )

Here's how to win with data

With all the exciting, complex data available from the midterm elections, our top data.world customers shared their tips for keeping data projects from getting messy. Whether you're working on your own or with a fast-paced team, these suggestions help you stay organized, dig in, and share your results.

-

List all of your data in one spot.

The Associated Press offers a single portal for hundreds of newsrooms to access data in moments. Simply connecting files to data.world makes them visible, discoverable, and usable. You’ll be less likely to duplicate work, and everyone gets more tools to shape their reporting. Here's the best way to catalog your data.

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH13 )
-

Take advantage of public data.

Governments make an enormous amount of rich data available. Save time and build on the work they’ve already done. CityLab already released a free, comprehensive dataset containing extensive historical voting records by district (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH23 )  and population density.

Here’s how to use it:

- View the data in data.world.  (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH33 )
- Select “Add to project” at the very top of the page.
- Connect your own datasets to your new project. (For example, if you want to analyze against your customers' geographic distribution.)
- Dig in to find stories that change your business, the world, or both.

-

Just ask the experts.

Not sure where to begin? Let us know! (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH43 ) We’ll find the right way to get your data team working together in no time. And with an active community of fellow data experts, you're guaranteed to get an answer, fast.

Featured integrations

Work with the programming languages you know best (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH53 )

Did you know data.world connects with 40+ data tools? Some of our most popular ones let you work with data in just the right language for the job In fact, CityLab's election data (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH63 ) includes a fully reproducible R notebook.

What's new?

- We've been busy! From new ways to add data to your catalog to exploring and visualizing it, find out if your favorites are among our newest integrations (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH73 ) .

- Caroline Horn, part of data.world's engineering team, discussed everything from data prep to school bus schedules (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH83 ) with Daniel Haight, President of Dark Horse Analytics.

- Build up your toolkit with a checklist to discover "dark data" (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMH93 ) and improve your data project process (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbjPrvyW53q0Np9jxr-xW5fjtNG8c5QJ4W5BW2GB8pp4-Df1CYJMHb3 ) .

Cheers,

The team at data.world

A free 6-hour video course on Angular - everything you need to start building Angular web apps
What does your Thanksgiving menu have on it? What drinks should you serve with it? All this and more in the data!

Not rendering correctly? View this email as a web page here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH03 ) .

logo.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH13 )

data_digest_banner_small.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH23 )

Data Digest

Hi tushar1404116,

In the U.S., Thanksgiving is closing in, and the annual tradition brings decades of data with it. Let’s take a look!

What’s on the menu?

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH33 ) The New York Public Library has kept track of over 170 years of historical menus. How popular (or not) were your Thanksgiving staples in the 1900s? Check out this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH43 ) and its insights (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH53 ) to find out.

2015 Thanksgiving Meal Poll Dataset by FiveThirtyEight

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH63 ) Food is at the heart of the holiday but, from Black Friday shopping to attending the Macy’s Parade, there’s no shortage of things to do (or eat) over the long weekend. See the breakdown of how Americans celebrate the holiday in FiveThirtyEight’s dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH73 ) .

Wine, Beer, and Liquor Reviews

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH83 ) No celebration is complete without beverages. Datafiniti’s Product Database has kept track of over 2,000 online reviews of alcoholic beverages, so you know exactly what to serve your guests. Find out which ones are best in this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMH93 ) .

***

DarkHorse_Analytics_-_data_world (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMHb3 )

Data Culture Interviews: Daniel Haight, President & co-founder, Darkhorse Analytics (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMHc3 )

Did you know data cultures can save lives? Learn why in our latest Data Culture interview (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMHd3 ) where Dan Haight of Darkhorse Analytics explains that working collaboratively, testing assumptions, and keeping your focus on the right goal can make or break a data project. Especially, the high stakes projects, like reducing ambulance response times in congested cities.

His interviewer and our esteemed colleague, Caroline Horn, had this to say about their conversation, "His ideas encourage taking things to the next level, stressing the importance of adoption of ideas as a way of validating their success. I think anyone working with analytics could benefit from understanding Dan's outlook."

Watch the Interview (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkd5BfW70j-_4706D4HW5MRGvC67j70dW5g778q8cxr33f1CYJMHf3 )

Cheers,

The data.world team

Data Digest: Thanksgiving Menu | Alcohol Reviews
Hi,

In today's brand new tutorial, you will learn how to use Mask
R-CNN + OpenCV to automatically segment objects from images ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDM2Mzg4ODIzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMTkvbWFzay1yLWNubi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ).

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDM2Mzg4ODIzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMTkvbWFzay1yLWNubi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

In last week's blog post you learned how to use the YOLO object
detector to detect the presence of objects in images. Object
detectors, such as YOLO, Faster R-CNNs, and Single Shot Detector
(SSDs) generate four sets of (x, y)-coordinates which represent
the bounding box of an object in an image.

Obtaining the bounding boxes of an object is a good start, but
the bounding box itself doesn't tell us anything about (1) which
pixels belong to the foreground object and (2) which objects
belong to the background.

That begs the question:

Is it possible to generate a mask for each object in our image,
thereby allowing us to segment the foreground object from the
background?

The answer is a resounding yes — to learn how to apply a Mask
R-CNN with OpenCV to both images and video streams, just keep
reading. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDM2Mzg4ODIzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMTkvbWFzay1yLWNubi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Interested in learning how to train a Mask R-CNN on your own
custom dataset?

If so, you'll want to check out the 2nd edition of my book, Deep
Learning for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDM2Mzg4ODIzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (DL4CV).

Inside the ImageNet Bundle you will:

* Learn how to annotate and label your image dataset for a Mask
R-CNN
* Train a Mask R-CNN from scratch on your custom dataset
* Use the Mask R-CNN to predict object masks for your own images

I've also provided two case studies on (1) skin lesion/cancer
segmentation and (2) prescription pill segmentation, a first step
in pill identification:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDM2Mzg4ODIzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

These case studies are designed to give you hands-on experience
on how Mask R-CNNs are used in real-world applications.

And if you want really good news...

I'll be launching a Thanksgiving/Black Friday sale starting
on Thursday, November 22nd at noon EST which includes 25-35% OFF
all DL4CV bundles.

This upcoming sale will be the BIGGEST sale I've ever ran. I'll
be sharing more details on the sale tomorrow so be sure to keep
an eye on your inbox.

In the meantime, I would suggest you click the following link to
grab your (free) table of contents + sample chapters PDF to my
book:

Click here to claim your table of contents + sample chapters PDF
( http://t.dripemail2. )

After clicking the link you'll PDF will land in your inbox within
a few short minutes.

The PDF will help you (1) see what topics are included in the
book as well as (2) get a feel for my writing and teaching style
(which I'm confident you'll enjoy and find helpful).

Be sure to grab your table of contents + sample chapters now ( http://t.dripemail2. ) — I'll see you tomorrow!

? Sabit Khan is a new friend suggestion for you
As a person with data skills, you can do all kinds of incredible things. Predict moves in the stock market. Contain the spread of an epidemic. Figure out what makes people fall in love.

But first, you’ll have to learn Structured Query Language — or SQL for short.

A firm knowledge of SQL is a strong foundation for any Data Science career, making it the perfect entry-point for beginners. Its syntax is easy-to-read, its query structure is easy-to-understand, and because it's a declarative language, you only have to specify what result you want rather than creating specific instructions for how to perform a task.

Our new Pro Intensive, Learn SQL from Scratch ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/learn-sql-from-scratch?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=sql_11_27_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), will help you build that foundation in just 6 weeks. You’ll:
* Learn the basics of SQL, then level up quickly to combine data from multiple sources, identify patterns, and draw subtle and complex conclusions.

* Apply your knowledge in common business environments — such as customer attribution, churn rates, and process funnels.

* Get constant feedback in our interactive learning environment — plus detailed code reviews from our professional programmers.
No other course on the market takes you this far in SQL, this fast. Space is limited, so enroll today—our next cohort begins on November 27th.

Enroll Now ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/learn-sql-from-scratch?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=sql_11_27_18&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link )

Hey,

This Thursday is Thanksgiving in the United States, one of the
largest holidays of the year for Americans.

And while this year was a rollercoaster of triumphant highs and
tragic lows for me and my family, I think it's incredibly
important to count your blessings and reflect on the good in life
during this holiday season.

Here are just a few that I am thankful for this past year:

* Trisha and I got married in September. We're very happy
together and each day I feel lucky to be with her.

* A close relative of mine had a surgery to remove a malignant
tumor not too long ago. I've been helping take care of them the
past few weeks. Last week they went to see their doctor and got a
clean bill of health — they are cancer free.

* I finished up the 2nd edition of my book, Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDM4MTk1Mzg2MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (DL4CV), including an additional four chapters on Object
Detection, Mask R-CNNs, Weapon Detection, and Cancer Segmentation
and Identification.

Lastly, I want to say that I am so incredibly thankful to you, as
a PyImageSearch reader, for being supportive of myself and the
blog over the past few years. Without you this blog would not be
possible. It doesn't have to be Thanksgiving for me to recognize
this — I literally feel this lucky every day I get up in the
morning and start working.

Clearly, I had the spirit of Thanksgiving in mind when I sat down
to write this email.

And every year around Thanksgiving I run a HUGE sale on the
PyImageSearch blog.

This year is no different.

And honestly, this is the BIGGEST sale yet!

So here's the deal:

I'm doing a Black Friday sale that will go LIVE on Thursday,
November 22nd at noon EST.

The sale includes 25% OFF my entire library:

* 25% OFF the brand new 2nd edition of Deep Learning for Computer
Vision with Python

* 25% OFF my first book, Practical Python and OpenCV

* 25% OFF all memberships of the PyImageSearch Gurus course. This
course has NEVER been discounted so this is HUGE.

But I'm just getting started...

* To make this a true doorbuster sale I'm going to increase the
discount from 25% to 35% OFF for a limited time.

* If you purchase in the first 10 minutes of the
sale (12:00-12:10PM EST) I'm increasing the discount to 35% OFF!
* There will be no exceptions on the doorbuster 35% discount.
Once the clock strikes 12:10PM EST, I'm taking down the 35%
discount.

As you can see, this sale is a BIG deal:

In the history of PyImageSearch I've never offered a public sale
on the PyImageSearch Gurus course.

On Thursday you'll have a chance to join the course and gain
access to all 13 modules, 168 lessons, and 2,161 pages of
content of the most complete, comprehensive computer vision
course online — all for 25-35% OFF.

You won't find a more detailed computer vision course anywhere
else online, I guarantee it.

Of course, the point of this sale is to celebrate the 2nd edition
release of Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python.

The 2nd edition includes 4 brand new chapters in the ImageNet
Bundle covering advanced computer vision + deep learning topics,
including:

* The RetinaNet object detector and how it can be used for logo
detection

* Training RetinaNet to detect weapons in images and video
streams

* The Mask R-CNN architecture and how to apply it to skin lesion
segmentation and cancer identification

* How to annotate your own data for Mask R-CNN, train a model,
and then apply it to your own images

In the image below you can find a sample of results from these
chapters:

I think the results speak from themselves — the skills you learn

learning + computer vision projects.

But if you're just getting your start with OpenCV, you can't
forget about my first book, Practical Python and OpenCV. This
book is your guaranteed quick start guide to learning the
fundamentals of computer vision and image processing using Python
and OpenCV.

Thousands of PyImageSearch readers have used Practical Python and
OpenCV to get their start with computer vision and image
processing — I have no doubt it will help you get your start as
well.

As you can see, this Black Friday sale is a big deal (and quite
the bargain).

My hope is that you'll take advantage of this deal and continue
your journey to computer vision/deep learning mastery.

I'll be back tomorrow with more details on the Black Friday
discount (as well as some tips to ensure you're first in line to
grab the doorbuster 35% discount).

See you then!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Get ready — this is my *BIGGEST* sale ever.
Hey,

Let me tell you a story:

Four years ago, when PyImageSearch was still in its infancy, I
decided to run a Black Friday sale for my first book, Practical
Python and OpenCV. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQwMDA3MjU4MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3ByYWN0aWNhbC1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

To be completely honest with you, I had no idea how the Black
Friday discount was going to go over — I had never offered one
before!

And had it not been for a little "liquid courage" (i.e., a glass
of wine Thanksgiving night), the discount would
have never happened.

I remember waking up the morning after I announced the sale in
a nearly panicked state.

My pulse was racing like a thoroughbred pounding the turf on the
home stretch.

I felt dizzy and nauseous. My stomach ached, rolled, and tumbled
as if I hadn't eaten in days. My mouth was dry as cotton, while
my palms sweated bullets.

My left eye was even starting to involuntarily twitch — I had all
the classic signs of someone on the verge of an anxiety attack.

So, why was I so anxious and nervous?

I was scared to check my inbox — I simply didn't know how people
were going to react to the Black Friday sale.

Were readers, people I had gotten to know well over many email
exchanges, suddenly going to be angry with me because I tried to
"sell" them my book?

Were they going to unsubscribe from the PyImageSearch email list
and never trust me again?

Or worse, would they turn to social media and bad-mouth me?

When I finally mustered up the courage to open up my Gmail inbox
I was in for a huge surprise.

You see, my inbox was filled with PyImageSearch readers just like
yourself who were so happy that I offered a Black Friday
discount.

During that first Black Friday weekend over 100+ PyImageSearch
readers got their hands on a copy of Practical Python and
OpenCV at the discounted Black Friday price.

These readers were able to jumpstart their computer vision +
OpenCV education before Thanksgiving weekend was even over!

Sure, I got a few replies from people who thought it was too
"gimmicky" for a small website like PyImageSearch to do a Black
Friday sale. And yeah, I got a few unsubscribes from readers who
simply weren't interested.

But you know what?

None of that compared to the overwhelming positive response from
everyone else. PyImageSearch readers just like you were genuinely
excited that I was offering a discount.

As the day went on my anxiety lessened...and eventually stopped
altogether.

That day taught me something important — even when you try to do
something good you'll still ruffle a few feathers. And that's
totally fine.

What really matters is if people recognize the value in what
you're creating. If they do, they'll listen. And when you
consistently provide value to someone who is listening they'll
eventually trust you as well.

I feel very lucky and privileged to run PyImageSearch — it's not
a trust I take lightly.

This year I'm pleased to announce that I'll be carrying on the
Black Friday discount tradition and offering:

* 25% OFF the brand new 2nd edition of Deep Learning for Computer
Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQwMDA3MjU4MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

* 25% OFF my first book, Practical Python and OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQwMDA3MjU4MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3ByYWN0aWNhbC1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

* 25% OFF all memberships of the PyImageSearch Gurus course. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQwMDA3MjU4MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) This course
has NEVER been discounted so this is a HUGE deal.

Starting Thursday, November 22nd at noon EST I'll be launching
the 25% OFF Black Friday deal.

But I'm not stopping there...
* To make this a true doorbuster sale I'm going to increase the
discount from 25% to 35% OFF for a limited time.

* If you purchase in the first 10 minutes of the
sale (12:00-12:10PM EST) I'm increasing the discount to 35% OFF!
* There will be no exceptions on the doorbuster 35% discount.
Once the clock strikes 12:10PM EST, I'm taking down the 35%
discount.

The Black Friday discounts I offer at PyImageSearch are
a BIG deal and have a history of being competitive and selling
out quickly:

* Three years ago I offered 10 hand-signed editions of Practical
Python and OpenCV on a first-come, first serve basis — all 10
were sold out in exactly 17 minutes.

* Two years ago I offered 10 hand-signed editions and 10 (free)
Raspberry Pi 3's — all 10 sold out in 5 minutes.

* Last year I offered 10 NVIDIA Jetson TX2s to the first 10
readers who purchased my deep learning book — all 10 of the TX2s
were claimed in 2 minutes, 16 seconds.

This year I'm going to do things a bit different. I'm going to
level the playing field so no matter where in the world you live
and no matter how good your internet connection is (or
isn't), you have a full 10 minutes to take advantage of the 35%
OFF discount.

But 10 minutes can go by quick so you'll need to act FAST!

To make sure you're able to take advantage of the 35% OFF
doorbuster discount I suggest you:

* Set an alarm on your phone and desktop for Thursday, November
22nd at noon EST (in fact, I would recommend setting your alarm a
few minutes early to ensure you don't miss out on the sale). You
can use the following link ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQwMDA3MjU4MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnRpbWVhbmRkYXRlLmNvbS93b3JsZGNsb2NrL2NvbnZlcnRlci5odG1sP2lzbz0yMDE4MTEyMlQxNzAwMDBcdTAwMjZwMT0xNzlcdTAwMjZwMj0xMzZcdTAwMjZwMz0xNzZcdTAwMjZfX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) to convert Thursday, November 22nd at noon EST to your own
timezone — just use the "Add Another City" field to add your
country/timezone.
* Start refreshing your inbox for the announcement email as soon
as your alarm goes off.

arrive, keep the following pages for my books/courses open in

1. The 2018 State of JavaScript survey asked 20,000 developers about which tools they use and why. Here are the results (5 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/8322bcc51bd8

2. Here are the winners of the 2018 freeCodeCamp JAMstack Hackathon at GitHub, and demos of the winning projects (7 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/2a39bd1db878

3. An Airbnb software engineer talks about 7 habits she has observed that most successful engineers have in common (9 minute watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/n/ms9fp28jf

4. An introduction to Git Merge and Git Rebase: what they do and when to use them (6 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/131b863785f

5. Young left his job at a Los Angeles pharmacy, coded for 8-months, and got a job as a professional developer. This is his journey from anxiety to triumph (6 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/240212

Black Friday: 25% OFF *ALL* my books and courses.
Hi,

The first part of this email may sting a bit, but bear with me,
it’s the truth:

In the near future, a computer scientist without at
least some knowledge of AI, DL, CV will be like an engineer
without basic programming skills — potentially unemployable and
overlooked for new job opportunities, research grants, and
projects.

If you think I’m exaggerating by saying “unemployable”, I have
news for you, it’s already happening.

Just take a look at Microsoft Build and Google IO, two developer
conferences, from earlier this year:

* Microsoft Build presented their new AI/CV cameras, their DL +
CV models deployed to drones, and their new DL + CV library.
* Google IO introduced their new AI voice assistant, (seemingly)
passing the Turing test and holding a conversation with a real,
actual person used to book a hair dresser appointment.

Let me again remind you — these were developer conferences, not
AI conferences!

As I said, the transition is happening. If you do not have at
least some knowledge over AI, DL or CV, your job, research, and
project opportunities may start to diminish in the next 5-10
years.

And the more CV + DL knowledge you have, the better — make sure
you prepare yourself now.

The question is, "How do you prepare yourself?"

To answer that, I'd like to share with you an email I received
last week from Saideep Talari, a PyImageSearch reader who has
gone through my books and courses:
"Adrian, I'm writing this email to tell you that I've been
promoted as CTO of our company.

I'm incredibly thankful to you for all the help. You have been
very helpful in tough times and without you, I can't think of
this day. I'm extremely happy today by the way I'm given the
responsibility to take our technology forward.

Computer vision has added so much weight to my profile and also,
the PyImageSearch Gurus course ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ3MDEzODY5MCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) is just
terrific. I've gained so much knowledge from the course and
books. These added substantial importance for growing in this
industry to this role.

We were recently funded ($2M Series-A in India) and still getting
more. And the investors choose me as my contribution for tech in
our company is huge.

All this was only possible because of you. If you haven't helped
me that day! Or if PyImageSearch is not there? I would be some
random guy doing penetration testing of networks and web
applications instead of computer vision or deep learning."

Saideep's story holds a special place in my heart as it's so
incredibly sincere, genuine, and heartfelt.

You see, Saideep comes from a lower income family. They did not
have much money. In fact, online education (such as the
PyImageSearch Gurus course, Udacity, etc.) was considered a
“luxury”.

But that didn’t stop Saideep — he took it upon himself to study
computer vision, not only because he felt it to be
his passion and calling, but because he wanted to help his
family.

Saideep joined PyImageSearch Gurus ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ3MDEzODY5MCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) in August
2016 and then graduated in February 2017.

After graduation Saideep applied for a computer vision job and
was given a project to complete. His solution was so
impressive that the company immediately hired him and brought him
on board as a computer vision engineer.

That job was life changing for Saideep. He locked down a well
paying job. He was able to care of his family and support them.
He cleared his and his families debts. And most importantly, he
was doing what he loved — working with computer vision.

But Saideep's education wasn't over.

While working for the company he read through my deep learning
book, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ3MDEzODY5MCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ).

He learned how to train deep neural networks on massive image
datasets. He learned advanced deep learning techniques. And he
learned my best practices, tips, and suggestions when applying
computer vision and deep learning.

His hard work has paid off tremendously.

In just over 2 years he has gone from computer
vision novice to CTO of a tech company with $2M in funding.

It's an incredible journey and one I know you can successfully
take as well.

So, what do you say?

Do you want to join Saideep in computer vision + deep learning
mastery and ensure you’re ready for the next wave of AI, DL, and
CV job + research opportunities?

If so, now is the time to invest in yourself. From now
until Monday at midnight EST I am offering a 25% OFF Black Friday
sale on all of my books and courses:

* 25% OFF the brand new 2nd edition of Deep Learning for Computer
Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ3MDEzODY5MCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

* 25% OFF my first book, Practical Python and OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ3MDEzODY5MCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3ByYWN0aWNhbC1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

* 25% OFF all memberships of the PyImageSearch Gurus course. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ3MDEzODY5MCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) This course
has NEVER been discounted so this is a HUGE deal.

My books and courses get results, guaranteed (just ask Saideep).

Don't wait any longer, this deal will be gone on Monday at
midnight.

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. If you choose not to pick up a copy of my books or courses,
no worries. I understand my books/courses are not for everyone.

But I am serious about the transition in job, research, and
project opportunities. Please make sure you are educating
yourself in AI, CV, and ML, if nothing more than from a
high-level.

The engineering and programming landscape is changing rapidly
with the introduction of these new CV + DL algorithms. Don’t miss
out on it — you owe it to yourself to invest in your education.

If you don’t have *some* knowledge of CV/DL, you may be unemployable in 5 years.
Hi,

Back in September, I saw Microsoft release a really neat feature
to their Office 365 platform — the ability to be on a video
conference call, blur the background, and have your colleagues
only see you (and not whatever is behind you).

Inspired by PyImageSearch reader, Zubair Ahmed, who also created
a similar example with DeepML, I decided to try my hand using
OpenCV + Instance Segmentation:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ5MjQ5MDI2MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMjYvaW5zdGFuY2Utc2VnbWVudGF0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Whether you’re taking the call from a hotel room, working from a
downright ugly office building, or simply don’t want to clean up
around the home office, the conference call blurring feature can
keep the meeting attendees focused on you (and not the mess in
the background).

Such a feature is especially helpful for people working from home
and wanting to preserve the privacy of their family members.

Imagine your workstation being in clear view of your kitchen —
you wouldn’t want your colleagues watching your kids eating
dinner or doing their homework! Instead, just pop on the blurring
feature and you’re all set.

To learn how to perform instance segmentation with OpenCV, and
build a video chat background blurring "app", just keep reading!
( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ5MjQ5MDI2MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTEvMjYvaW5zdGFuY2Utc2VnbWVudGF0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Instance segmentation is made possible using a deep learning
architecture called Mask R-CNN.

The Mask R-CNN model used in today's tutorial has been trained on
the COCO dataset and is capable of recognizing 90 class labels of
common objects you encounter in day-to-day life.

But did you know you can train your own custom Mask R-CNN to
recognize and segment your own objects?

Last week I released the 2nd edition of my book, Deep Learning
for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ5MjQ5MDI2MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (DL4CV), and inside the ImageNet Bundle I teach you how to:

* Annotate and label your image dataset for a Mask R-CNN
* Train a Mask R-CNN from scratch on your custom dataset
* Use the Mask R-CNN to predict object masks for your own images

I've also provided two case studies on (1) skin lesion/cancer
segmentation and (2) prescription pill segmentation, a first step
in pill identification:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDQ5MjQ5MDI2MSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

These case studies are designed to give you hands-on
experience on how Mask R-CNNs are used in real-world
applications.

the book but I'll be taking that offer down in a little over 12
hours.

If you've been on the fence/waiting for a sale, now is the time
to act!

your time and finances, take a look at this DL4CV review from
PyImageSearch reader, James F.:

"By far, one of the most well-written, informative books that

information-packed book!"

help you with your projects, research, and studies.

? ??? ???? is a new friend suggestion for you
Hi there,

In today's brand new tutorial, you will learn how to apply deep
learning to perform medical image analysis. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU4OTkyNDI3MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMDMvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1pbWFnZS1hbmFseXNpcy13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) Specifically, you will discover how to use the Keras deep
learning library to automatically analyze medical images for
malaria testing:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU4OTkyNDI3MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMDMvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1pbWFnZS1hbmFseXNpcy13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Such a deep learning + medical imaging system can help reduce the
400,000+ deaths per year caused by malaria.

Today’s tutorial was inspired by two sources. The first one was
from PyImageSearch reader, Kali, who wrote in two weeks ago and
asked:

~~~

Hi Adrian, thanks so much for your tutorials. They’ve helped me
as I’ve been studying deep learning.

I live in an area of Africa that is prone to disease, especially
malaria. I’d like to be able to apply computer vision to help
reduce malaria outbreaks.

Do you have any tutorials on medical imaging? I would really
appreciate it if you wrote one. Your knowledge can help me which
can help me help others too.

~~~

Soon after I saw Kali’s email I stumbled on a really interesting
article from Dr. Johnson Thomas, a practicing endocrinologist,
who provided a great benchmark summarizing the work of the United
States National Institutes of Health (NIH) used to build an
automatic malaria classification system using deep learning.

Johnson compared NIH’s approach (~95.9% accurate) with two models
he personally trained on the same malaria dataset (94.23% and
97.1% accurate, respectively).

That got me thinking — how could I contribute to deep learning
and medical image analysis? How could I help the fight against
malaria? And how could I help readers like Kali get their start
in medical image analysis?

To make the project even more interesting, I decided I was going
to minimize the amount of custom code I was going to write.

Time is of the essence in disease outbreaks — if we can utilize
pre-trained models or existing code, fantastic. We’ll be able to
help doctors and clinicians working in the field that much
faster.

Therefore, I decided to:

* Utilize models and code examples I had already created for my
book, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU4OTkyNDI3MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ).
* And demonstrate how you can take this knowledge and easily
apply it to your own projects (including deep learning and
medical imaging).

Over 75%+ of today’s code comes directly from my book with only a
few modifications, enabling us to:

* Quickly train a deep learning model capable of replicating
NIH’s work...
* ...at a fraction of both training time and model size.

To learn how to apply deep learning to medical image analysis
(and not to mention, help fight the malaria endemic), just keep
reading the full tutorial here. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU4OTkyNDI3MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMDMvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1pbWFnZS1hbmFseXNpcy13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

I hope you enjoy it!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Are you interested in more applications of deep learning and
medical imagery? If so, let me know in the comments section of
today's post. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU4OTkyNDI3MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMDMvZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1hbmQtbWVkaWNhbC1pbWFnZS1hbmFseXNpcy13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) Be sure to let me know what applications of medical imagery
you're interested in along with any datasets you find interesting
or want to explore in more detail.

? ????????? ?? ???? is a new friend suggestion for you
Today isn't actually my birthday. But it's the birthday of
something that I poured my heart and soul into.

Exactly one year ago I was dog-tired, sleep deprived, sitting at
my kitchen table, fingers dancing across my Macbook Pro keyboard
like an expertly choreographed Cirque du Soleil show.

My eyes were wide and piercing from the four empty coffee cups
sitting next to me. I can still remember the dried coffee stain
patterns on each of the mugs like it was yesterday.

My right eyelid was even starting to twitch from the caffeine
overload and the lack of sleep -- I had not had a wink of
shut-eye in over 36 hours.

The chair I was sitting on felt like a medieval torture device,
even though in reality it was probably quite comfortable. My legs
ached from the lack of bloodflow. My back hurt from hunching over
my laptop. My shoulders drooped, struggling to manage the weight
of that endless writing marathon.

And despite all the torment and anguish, I still felt light, as
if I was floating on a cloud. My pulse quickened as my adrenaline
soared to new heights, leaving my chest breathless.

You see exactly one year ago at the end of that writing marathon,
I hit the period key on my keyboard so hard that I nearly broke
my laptop in half.

That period -- that final period -- meant that my book, Practical
Python and OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU5NTU3MDQyOSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3ByYWN0aWNhbC1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9lbWFpbD10dXNoZXJraGFuNTczQGdtYWlsLmNvbVx1MDAyNl9fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) was complete.

I've put my heart and soul into Practical Python and OpenCV
-- and I would like to share this part of me with you.

If you haven't picked up a copy of Practical Python and OpenCV
yet, I would definitely encourage you to do so. I'm obviously
biased, but I really think it's the best introduction to computer
vision + OpenCV that you can possibly get. You have my word on
that.

To grab your copy, just use this link. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU5NTU3MDQyOSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3ByYWN0aWNhbC1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9lbWFpbD10dXNoZXJraGFuNTczQGdtYWlsLmNvbVx1MDAyNl9fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

All the best,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. If you're looking for the next steps, I'm currently spending
countless nights getting the PyImageSearch Gurus computer vision
course ready to go. Be sure to claim your spot in line ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDU5NTU3MDQyOSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cucHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC5jb20vcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC1ndXJ1cy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) when the

Data Digest

Hi tushar1404116,

Let's check out the data!

UFO Sightings

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH33 ) Are we really alone in the universe? The answer depends on who you ask. The National UFO Research Center has documented over 100,000 reports of UFO sightings going back 600 years. Dig into this extraterrestrial dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH43 ) to see exactly when, where, and what people saw.

Downtown Louisville Pedestrian Counts

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH53 ) Looking for a place in downtown Louisville? Or are you planning a smoother commute? Pedestrian data can be invaluable for either pursuit. Check out the data the City of Louisville collected and cataloged (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH63 ) .

2017 ESPN World Fame 100

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH73 ) The best athletes aren't always the most famous. From social media to TV interviews, some athletes are better at crafting their images than others. See how influential your favorite athlete is in this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH83 ) .

Cheers,

The data.world team

About data.world

data.world is the world's largest collaborative data community with hundreds of data partners across the world sharing their open data with our members.The smart catalog for data and analysis wakes up the hidden data workforce by replacing outdated barriers and disparate silos with deep connections between data, people, and analysis. When every employee can find, understand, and use data, your advanced practitioners can focus on high-impact work, and you can build a data-driven culture, faster. Check out a demo here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkk8gVW7Stm3c73W-6RW7228M87rD-n_W6J4rP757Lznjf1CYJMH93 ) .

Data Digest: UFOs | Pedestrians | Famous Athletes
Hi,

In today's brand new tutorial, you will learn how to save and
load your Keras deep learning models: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDY3NzIwODkzOCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMTAva2VyYXMtc2F2ZS1hbmQtbG9hZC15b3VyLWRlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctbW9kZWxzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDY3NzIwODkzOCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMTAva2VyYXMtc2F2ZS1hbmQtbG9hZC15b3VyLWRlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctbW9kZWxzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

This blog post was inspired by PyImageSearch reader, Mason, who
emailed in last week and asked:

~~~

Adrian, I’ve been going through your blog and reading your deep
learning tutorials. Thanks for them.

I have a question though:

After training, how do you save your Keras model?

And once you have it saved, how do you load it again so you can
classify new images?

I know this is a basic question but I don’t know how to save and
load my Keras models.

~~~

Mason asks an excellent question — and it’s actually not as
“basic” of a concept as he (and maybe even you) may think.

On the surface, saving your Keras models is as simple as calling
the model.save and load_model function. But there’s actually more
to consider than just the load and save model functions!

What’s even more important, and sometimes overlooked by new deep
learning practitioners, is the preprocessing stage — your
preprocessing steps for training and validation must
be identical to the training steps when loading your model and
classifying new images.

Therefore, I decided to create today's tutorial to help you
understand:

* How to properly save and load your Keras deep learning models.
* The proper steps to preprocess your images after loading your
model.

To learn how properly save and load your deep learning models,
just keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDY3NzIwODkzOCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMTAva2VyYXMtc2F2ZS1hbmQtbG9hZC15b3VyLWRlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctbW9kZWxzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

I'll be back next week with another brand new tutorial.

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

---------------------

Keras – Save and Load Your Deep Learning Models

Not rendering correctly? View this email as a web page here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH03 ) .

logo.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH13 )

Thanks for a great year.

We hope you know how glad we are that you're part of the data.world community. Together, we've built the largest collaborative data community in the world.

We've also released a massive amount of new functionality over the year. Your feedback has helped create a smart catalog for data and analysis, helping you get more value from your data and create data-driven cultures. Check out some of the biggest improvements below.

Discover data and build your catalog

Data is only useful if teams can find, understand, and use it. New integrations (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH23 ) , an updated view of your catalog (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH33 ) , and a streamlined home feed (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH43 ) let you get right back to the things you were working on, and to collaborate across multiple projects and groups with ease.

Tip: Use the Enterprise Data Tech Stack Audit to discover your business's data.

Start your audit (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH53 )

Manage security, access, and governance

Advanced security (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH63 ) (including SOC 2 certification), control (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH73 ) , and expanded auditing (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH83 ) features help you scale self-service access with confidence.

Tip: Learn the best way to create a space just for your team's data work.

Read the guide (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMH93 )

Make data teamwork more collaborative

Even the least technical team members can slice and dice data (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHb3 ) on their own, and smart suggestions for related data automatically enhance analysis (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHc3 ) . Insights that travel with data help everyone immediately get value from your work (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHd3 ) .

Tip: Use the Modern Data Project Checklist to work together better.

Complete this checklist (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHf3 )

Reuse and reproduce data analysis

Did you know the same core dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHg3 ) can be used for analysis in multiple projects simultaneously? Then, projects (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHh3 ) automatically document your work as you query, transform, and annotate the data without changing the original source. A single "2018 Transactions" dataset could power projects for Q4 customer ARR, regional gains, Sales leaderboards, operational costs, and more.

Tip: Use this guide to figure out how your analysis can keep adding value.

Get retrospective (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHj3 )

What's new?

Take time to reflect and improve. Get the guide: learn to run data project retrospectives like Google (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHk3 ) does.

From new ways to add data to your catalog to exploring and visualizing it, find out if your favorites are among our newest integrations (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHl3 ) . Most notably, you can now connect with top databases like MySQL and Microsoft SQL Server, RedShift, Oracle Database, and PostgreSQL.

Need help making data-driven plans for 2019? Let us know! (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkdsWGW7bmjMd7pS25lW8WwcBZ81K0-hW9cd7vx8TYPPKf1CYJMHm3 )  We’ll find the right way to get your data team working together in no time. And with an active community of fellow data experts, you're guaranteed to get an answer, fast.

Cheers,

The team at data.world

How many journalists gave their lives to inform their audiences? What’s the garbage situation in Singapore?

Not rendering correctly? View this email as a web page here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH03 ) .

logo.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH13 )

data_digest_banner_small.png (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH23 )

Data Digest

Hi tushar1404116,

Ready for some data? Let's get right to it.

Journalist Deaths Since 1992

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH33 ) This week, Time Magazine announced its person of the year for 2018: The Guardians (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH43 ) . The group of four journalists and a newspaper represent a profession that increasingly faces danger for its noble cause of holding power to account. Take a moment to learn how many have given their lives to tell the world’s most important stories in this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH53 ) .

Waste Management in Singapore

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH63 ) Time to take out the trash? Depending on when you get this, it might be in Singapore. In this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH73 ) , you might be surprised to see which types of waste are recycled most and how much is disposed of every year there. Take a look!

Music Composers' Birthdays

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH83 ) Whether it tugs your heartstrings, evokes nostalgia, or improves your mood, music is timeless. Check out this century-spanning dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMH93 )  that contains the dates of birth for over 4,000 composers.

Cheers,

The data.world team

About data.world

data.world is the world's largest collaborative data community with hundreds of data partners across the world sharing their open data with our members.The smart catalog for data and analysis wakes up the hidden data workforce by replacing outdated barriers and disparate silos with deep connections between data, people, and analysis. When every employee can find, understand, and use data, your advanced practitioners can focus on high-impact work, and you can build a data-driven culture, faster. Check out a demo here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbkhlWFW53VSf_90plBKW8s_vs88NsxFbW6crldT5R_5p0f1CYJMHb3 ) .

Tushar, start a conversation with your new connection, Md Meraz
Hi,

In today's brand new tutorial, you will learn how to perform
multiple image stitching using Python and OpenCV. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDc3MjQwMDUwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMTcvaW1hZ2Utc3RpdGNoaW5nLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2LWFuZC1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) Using today’s code you’ll be able to stitch multiple images
together, creating a panorama of stitched images:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDc3MjQwMDUwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMTcvaW1hZ2Utc3RpdGNoaW5nLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2LWFuZC1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Today's tutorial is actually a followup to two posts I published
nearly two years ago on image stitching and panorama
construction:

* Fundamentals of image stitching ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDc3MjQwMDUwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTYvMDEvMTEvb3BlbmN2LXBhbm9yYW1hLXN0aXRjaGluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Real-time panorama and image stitching ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDc3MjQwMDUwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTYvMDEvMjUvcmVhbC10aW1lLXBhbm9yYW1hLWFuZC1pbWFnZS1zdGl0Y2hpbmctd2l0aC1vcGVuY3YvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Both of these tutorials covered the fundamentals of the typical
image stitching algorithm, which, at a bare minimum, require four
key steps:

* Detecting keypoints (DoG, Harris, etc.) and extracting local
invariant descriptors (SIFT, SURF, etc.) from two input images
* Matching the descriptors between the images
* Using the RANSAC algorithm to estimate a homography matrix
using our matched feature vectors
* Applying a warping transformation using the homography matrix
obtained from Step #3

However, the biggest problem with my original implementations is
that they were not capable of handling more than two input
images.

In today’s tutorial, we’ll be revisiting image stitching with
OpenCV, including how to stitch more than two images together
into a panoramic image.

To learn how to stitch images together (and not to mention, build
your own panoramas), just click here. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDc3MjQwMDUwMSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMTcvaW1hZ2Utc3RpdGNoaW5nLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2LWFuZC1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Cheers,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Multiple Image Stitching with OpenCV + Python
Over the past few weeks I've been having a lot of fun playing
with my new quadcopter.

And this morning, right as I was finishing up the last sip of
coffee, I got to call in my very own drone strike...on the
kitchen cabinets.

Image ( http://t.dripemail2. )

If you can't already tell, I'm really excited about this
tutorial. It's definitely one of my favorite posts that I've ever
published on PyImageSearch — and once you give it a read, I think
you'll see why. Inside this post I detail how you can
leverage simple contour properties to build a really awesome
target detection system. By the time you have gone through this
post, you'll be able to build target detection systems of your
own!

To give the post a read, just click here. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

enjoyed it and can spare a second, please consider sharing

When we started off this year, we remarked that Python "had a moment ( https://news.codecademy.com/why-learn-python/ )" in 2017 and that 2018 would be the year for Python to reign supreme. Now, it's time to check in on that statement. So, what happened with Python in 2018?

Python Search Interest ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pwp_1_2_19&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=img )Google search interest in "Python" from 2013 - 2018.

Python's popularity has propelled once again, with a major driver of its growth being Data Science—one of the fastest growing global business trends. Like yin and yang, Data Science and Python are now two inseparable forces that stand mightily on their own, but together, they produce an even more powerful energy.

As a result, Python has become the most popular language for Codecademy learners. More than 2 million people started learning Python with us this year!

Lucky for you, if you haven't yet mastered Python, it's not too late double down on its popularity. Here's why you should:
* Python easy to learn with Codecademy. No experience required.
* Python is a core skill in high-paying jobs like Data Analyst, Machine Learning Engineer, and Web Developer.
* There are more jobs available requiring knowledge of Python than there are people to fill them.

Our new Pro Intensive, P ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pwp_1_2_19&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link )rogramming with
Python ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pwp_1_2_19&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), will start you on the path towards being qualified for one of those jobs, taking you from no experience to mastering the fundamentals in 7 weeks. You'll:
* Learn in our interactive platform where you'll get immediate feedback—minutes into your first lessons.

* Build your confidence in a time-tested course structure, perfected after teaching millions of learners.

* Complete fun, challenging projects based on real-world problems—culminating in building a natural language processing engine that solves a murder mystery.

Python forms the basis for almost any career in code—from Data Science to Web Development and everywhere in between. Start here ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pwp_1_2_19&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), and go anywhere—but you’ll have to start soon. Our next cohort begins on January 2nd, and seats are filling up fast.

    Hello there!

Are you familiar with the controversy around Lyndsey Scott? For the unacquainted, Lyndsey Scott is a Lead iOS software engineer for Rally Bound and a former Victoria’s Secret model. B...

    
    




















Hello there!
Are you familiar with the controversy around Lyndsey Scott? For the unacquainted, Lyndsey Scott is a Lead iOS software engineer for Rally Bound and a former Victoria’s Secret model. Back in September 2018, an Instagram post on Scott’s ability to code invited flak from a lot of people with responses to the post ranging from demeaning and hostile(“What a waste”) to downright discrediting (“Printing Hello World these days is considered as coding”)!
Despite her multiple accomplishments, Lyndsey says that she is not used to being taken seriously. She doesn’t think it’s because she is a model. Instead, she attributes it to being a woman in tech. 
Lyndsey Scott is not the only one.
Just like her, many talented women technologists find it hard to overcome the inherent bias. We surveyed more than 1000 women technologists across organizations worldwide to know more about women in tech:  the challenges they face, the opportunities they seek, and the career they aspire to build.
 Download free report 
We hope this report plays a role in addressing gender inequality and helps in building an inclusive workplace for women. In Lyndsey Scott’s own words:

Regards,
Team HackerEarth











This email was sent to you because you are subscribed to blogs on HackerEarth

 from this email.
























What do Lyndsey, Divya, Aisha, and Juana have in common?
This is my final "links worth your time" list for 2018. Happy Holidays!

Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:

1. Learn React.js with this free 5 hour course for beginners. You'll learn about styling components, conditional rendering, state management, and more (5 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/n/jiLKNpplm

2. Introducing Programmer Playing Cards - learn about programmer history while you play classic card games like Poker, Blackjack, and Solitaire (4 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/d3eeeffe9a11

3. Here are the results of the freeCodeCamp 2018 New Coder Survey. 31,000 respondents told us about how they're learning to code and getting their first developer jobs (6 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/e10feb9ed419

4. Learn how to build your own Android app. This free course will show you how to use Android Studio, Firebase, Java, and more to build your own clone of WhatsApp messenger (5 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/n/ksLpiub87

5. How Phoebe went from stay-at-home mom to working as a front end web developer in less than a year by studying freeCodeCamp (8 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/39724046692a


Happy coding!

- Quincy Larson

Teacher at freeCodeCamp.org


If these emails aren't worth your time, you can turn them off: https://www.freecodecamp.org/ue/AModHXT8RWHjIO~AfS3rM

Data Digest

Hi tushar1404116,

It's our final data digest of 2018, so let's dig into the data one more time!

Christmas trees sold in the U.S.

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH33 ) It’s a ubiquitous symbol of the holiday season. From Rockefeller Center to the living room, the Christmas tree is the focal point of many families' household decorations. Or is it? Check out this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH43 ) to see how many trees have been sold the past few years.

Airline Twitter Sentiment Since 2015

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH53 ) When was your last flight delay? If it was within the last three years and you mentioned it on Twitter, data on that interaction might be on data.world. Airlines often take the brunt of public consumer feedback on Twitter, but which one gets the most positive mentions? Find out in this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH63 ) .

Dog Names in Alaska

(https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH73 ) Naming your new buddy is like naming a baby. Your dog is part of your family, so obsessing over the right name is understandable. But if you’re looking for something unique and you live in Alaska, "Buddy" isn't the right answer. Check out this dataset (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH83 ) for a breakdown on Alaskan dog names.

***

[Case Study] How Square Panda increased sales by nearly 3,000% (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMH93 )

While data.world is home to the world's largest data community, did you know that companies like Square Panda use it for work, too?

In fact, Square Panda uses data.world every day to monitor data as it comes and react to market signals to stay ahead of the competition. Learn how this small team automated processes, encouraged collaboration, and fostered data literacy for their most successful day in company history. Download here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMHb3 ) .

Cheers,

The data.world team

About data.world

data.world is the world's largest collaborative data community with hundreds of data partners across the world sharing their open data with our members.The smart catalog for data and analysis wakes up the hidden data workforce by replacing outdated barriers and disparate silos with deep connections between data, people, and analysis. When every employee can find, understand, and use data, your advanced practitioners can focus on high-impact work, and you can build a data-driven culture, faster. Check out a demo here (https://page.data.world/e2t/sc2/Mm-nFbk4BryW6hlJyg51v6c6W4XDPtZ5L5ySPW5JQJ968RLH7cf1CYJMHc3 ) .

Tushar, start a conversation with your new connection, Tahsin
Hi,

Today’s brand new blog post ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDg2NzY0NjcxMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMjQvaG93LXRvLXVzZS1rZXJhcy1maXQtYW5kLWZpdF9nZW5lcmF0b3ItYS1oYW5kcy1vbi10dXRvcmlhbC8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) is inspired by PyImageSearch reader, Shey.

Shey asks:

~~~

Hi Adrian, thanks for your tutorials. I’ve been methodically
going through every one. They’ve really helped me learn deep
learning.

I have a question about the Keras “.fit_generator” function.

I’ve noticed you use it quite a bit in your blog posts but I’m
not really sure how the function is different than Keras’
standard “.fit” function.

How is it different? How do I know when to use each? And how to I
create a data generator for the “.fit_generator” function?

~~~

Shey asks a great question.

The Keras deep learning library includes three separate functions
that can be used to train your own models:

* .fit
* .fit_generator
* .train_on_batch

If you’re new to Keras and deep learning you may feel a bit
overwhelmed trying to determine which function you’re supposed to
use — this confusion is only compounded if you need to work with
your own custom data.

To help lift the cloud of confusion regarding the Keras fit and
fit_generator functions, I’m going to spend this tutorial
discussing:
* The differences between Keras’ .fit, .fit_generator, and
.train_on_batch functions
* When to use each when training your own deep learning models
* How to implement your own Keras data generator and utilize it
when training a model using .fit_generator
* How to use the .predict_generator function when evaluating your
network after training

To learn more about Keras’ .fit and .fit_generator functions,
including how to train a deep learning model on your own custom
dataset, just keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDg2NzY0NjcxMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMTIvMjQvaG93LXRvLXVzZS1rZXJhcy1maXQtYW5kLWZpdF9nZW5lcmF0b3ItYS1oYW5kcy1vbi10dXRvcmlhbC8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Christmas is tomorrow! Regardless of whether you celebrate
the holiday or not, now is a great time to grab yourself (or
special friend or colleague) a copy of my book, Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNDg2NzY0NjcxMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Inside the book you’ll find:
* Super practical walkthroughs on image classification (VGG,
ResNet, SqueezeNet), object detection (Faster R-CNN, SSDs,
RetinaNet), and instance segmentation (Mask R-CNN).
* Solutions to actual, real-world image understanding problems,
including working with large datasets.
* Hands-on tutorials (with lots of code) that not only show you
the algorithms behind deep learning for computer vision but
their implementations as well, including how to work with large
amounts of data and train Keras deep learning models on top of
your dataset.
* A no-nonsense teaching style that is guaranteed help you master
deep learning for image understanding and visual recognition.

To grab your (free) table of contents + sample chapters PDF of my
deep learning book, just click here. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

After clicking the link your PDF will land in your inbox within a
few short minutes.

The PDF will help you (1) see what topics are included in the
book as well as (2) get a feel for my writing and teaching style
(which I'm confident you'll enjoy and find helpful).

Be sure to grab your table of contents + sample chapters now ( http://t.dripemail2. ) — have a safe and wonderful holiday season!
