One-Month Resolutions ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=hero_image )

 

 

Last New Year's, we ran a One-Day Resolution challenge—where we encouraged our users to complete a single coding goal in one day.

 

This year, we're raising the stakes. Instead of asking you to learn one new skill in a day, we're challenging you to achieve a new career goal in under one month. We're calling it the New Year's One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge.

 

No goal is too ambitious. Start a career as a game developer. Learn everything you need to know to ace a coding interview. Whatever your goal, we'll tell you exactly what to learn—and in what order—to get it done in a month or less.

 

How One-Month Resolutions work

 

We've carefully curated our courses toward exciting career goals that you can complete in 30 days or less.

 

Commit to a goal, follow the courses on the list, and crush your resolution. It's that simple.

 

What to expect

 

Over the next week, watch your inbox. To keep you motivated, we'll send you stories from real people who've used Codecademy Pro to accomplish big goals.

 

Oh—and one more thing. This week only, you get a New Year's discount on Codecademy Pro. Use the code NEWYEARS20 ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/#save?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=promocodelink ) to get 20% off our 6-month and annual plans.

 

It’s never been a better time to commit to yourself. Are you in?

 

Pick My Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=bottom_cta )

It’s Day 2 of the One-Month Resolution challenge. This week, we’ll share stories of real people who made big changes using skills they learned in Codecademy Pro.

First up? A marketing specialist who learned to build his own landing pages—and saved his company thousands.

 

 

Jason Hogge

 

 

 

How I learned to build my own landing pages from scratch

 

Meet Jason Hogge. He’s a marketing specialist at an IT services company in Canada—and he came to us to learn to build landing pages.

 

“As a small team, we realized that if you're going to execute email campaigns and call-to-action landing pages, you have to do a lot of it yourself,” Jason says. “Previously, we were outsourcing a lot of that to outside agencies. Those outsourcing costs, they're in the thousands.”

 

Jason enrolled in Codecademy, and quickly picked up tangible skills—like CSS, HTML, and JavaScript—that he could put to use immediately. Soon he was building his own landing pages.

 

“We were holding an event for the industry to talk about IT challenges,” Jason said. “I was able to code up a page for the event that linked to the registration page on a different platform. With the skills I learned, it only took me four hours.”

 

“I think I fooled everyone into thinking I was a front-end developer,” Jason adds.

 

Would building your own websites help you excel at your job? Join our One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge, choose the Learn How to Build Websites resolution, and pick up skills you can use at work right away.

 

Start Now ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=bottom_cta )

Up next: an inspiring story from a mother of two who landed a job working from home—for Microsoft.

 

 

Lacey Bathala

 

 

 

How I landed my dream job as a data analyst

 

Meet Lacey Bathala. When her boss asked her to learn SQL for work, she came to Codecademy.

 

With two kids at home, finding time to study was a challenge. Taking quick breaks whenever she could at work, Lacey busted through our lessons at a rate of about one a day. In just 3 weeks, she built a strong foundation in SQL.

 

“As a working mom of two wanting to further my career, it was perfect,” Lacey says. She used her skills to start a career in analytics—and now she works from home as a data analyst for Microsoft.

 

Demand for data analysts is only going up—and these are some of the best-paid jobs in the industry. We can help you build the foundation you need to start a career in this field—in just one month.

 

Getting started is easy. Join our One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge, pick Become a Data Analyst, and follow the path we’ve laid out for you.

It’s Day 4 of the One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge.

Next up? A tech support pro who used his Python skills to take his career to the next level.

 

 

Kyle Johnson

 

 

 

Learning Python landed me a job as a business analyst

 

Kyle worked in a technical support role for a social analytics company. His career was progressing, but he could only go so far. His next step was to become a business analyst—and for that, he had to upgrade his skills.

 

“I noticed that a lot of positions for business and data analysts were looking for someone with Python skills,” he said.

 

So Kyle signed up for Codecademy. With the program’s accountability, structure, and guidance, he knew he could pick up Python much faster than trying to learn alone.

 

“I knew there was a possibility of filling a void within the company,” Kyle says. And he seized the opportunity, impressing his boss with his initiative. After building a strong foundation in Python, Kyle landed one of those business analyst positions.

 

Do you see an opportunity in your company? We can help you build the skills you need to stand out. Join our One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge, pick Analyze Business and Financial Data, and follow the steps. It’s that simple.

It’s Day 5 of the One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge.

Each day, we’ll share stories of people who took their careers to the next level with Codecademy Pro.

Next up? A working mom who landed a job as a front-end developer.

 

 

Saadika Alard

 

 

 

How learning front-end transformed my career

 

Not long ago, Saadika was working in retail. “My weekends were never my own,” Saadika says. “I would be off when everyone else was working and my son had to attend school.”

 

Her husband was a programmer, and Saadika was fascinated by his work—so she signed up for Codecademy. Fitting in her studies during lunch breaks, she soon learned the basics of web development.

 

“It was fascinating how easy it became to build something using code,” she says.

 

Saadika’s coding skills landed her an internship, and then a full-time job as a front-end developer at Man Made Media. She still uses Codecademy to pick up new coding skills.

 

“Anyone can start coding and be great at it if they stick to it,” says Saadika. “Coding is a unique talent that anyone can learn—so take the opportunity to learn it.”

 

Want to love what you do—without sacrificing work-life balance? Join our One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge, pick the Create a Web App resolution, and follow the steps. Pretty soon, you’ll be on your way to thinking like a real front-end web developer.

 

Start Now ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=bottom_cta )

One-Month Resolutions ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=hero_image )

 

 

It’s Day 6 of the One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge.

Each day, we’ll share stories of people who did amazing things with the skills they learned in Codecademy Pro.

Next up? A guy who set out to learn a few basics—and ended up co-founding his own web design company.

 

 

Jackson Hardy

 

 

 

From coding newbie to startup co-founder

 

In the beginning, all Jackson Hardy wanted was to learn some basic HTML and CSS so he could custom edit Squarespace templates at work.

 

Jackson learned HTML and CSS through Codecademy, and quickly moved on to JavaScript. From there, he learned Python, Git, and Ruby—and then mastered the Command Line.

 

“The most challenging part of learning was I didn't know how to learn it,” Jackson says. “The way [Codecademy] ‘forced’ me to stay engaged was just the push I needed.”t. From there, he learned Python, Git, and Ruby—and then mastered the Command Line.

 

Jackson was applying for jobs as a web developer before he was even halfway done with his first Codecademy course. And just 12 months after he started learning HTML and CSS, he and a friend started their own web design agency: webside.io.

 

Want to follow in Jackson’s footsteps? Join our One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge, and pick the Learn the Basics of Coding resolution. We’ll teach you the practical basics of all the most popular languages, in less than one month.

 

Start Now ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=bottom_cta )

One-Month Resolutions ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=hero_image )

 

 

This week, we sent you stories from real people who've used Codecademy Pro to achieve big goals.

 

Hopefully, they left you feeling extra motivated to go after your own coding goals in 2019.

 

If you haven’t already, make sure you join our One-Month Resolution ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) challenge. We’ve curated lists of courses to help you attain the most popular goals we hear from learners. Goals like:

* Create a Web App. Go beyond HTML and CSS—and learn the more advanced frameworks for building interactive apps.

* Develop a Video Game. Learn to create browser games with JavaScript and Phaser, then take it to AAA game territory with C++ and Unreal Engine.

* Learn Programming for Finance & Business. Build predictive models, run regression analyses, and go further than Excel can take you.

* Ace a Coding Interview. Learn data structures and algorithms, solve common technical interview problems, and start thinking like a pro developer.

* Become a Data Analyst. Build the skills to work in one of the industry’s best-paid careers. Use SQL, Pandas, and Matplotlib to harness big datasets.

 

These are just a few of the many resolutions you can choose. Check out the full list here.

 

And today only, save on Codecademy Pro. Use the code NEWYEARS20 ( https://one-month-resolutions.codecademy.com/#save?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=newyears2019&utm_medium=email&utm_content=promocodelink ) to get 20% off 6-month and annual plans.

Tushar, start a conversation with your new connection, Md. Emdadul Huq
Hi,

In today's brand new blog post, you will learn how to use
Auto-Keras, an open source alternative to Google’s AutoML, ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTAxMzA4ODQzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMDcvYXV0by1rZXJhcy1hbmQtYXV0b21sLWEtZ2V0dGluZy1zdGFydGVkLWd1aWRlLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) for automated machine learning and deep learning:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTAxMzA4ODQzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMDcvYXV0by1rZXJhcy1hbmQtYXV0b21sLWEtZ2V0dGluZy1zdGFydGVkLWd1aWRlLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

When training a neural network on a dataset there are two primary
objectives a deep learning practitioner is trying to optimize and
balance:

* Defining a neural network architecture that lends itself to the
nature of the dataset
* Tuning a set of hyperparameters over many experiments that will
lead to a model with high accuracy and ability to generalize to
data outside the training and testing sets. Typical
hyperparameters that need to be tuned include the optimizer
algorithm (SGD, Adam, etc.), learning rate and learning rate
scheduling, and regularization, to name a few

Depending on the dataset and problem, it can take a deep learning
expert upwards of tens to hundreds of experiments to find a
balance between neural network architecture and hyperparameters.

These experiments can add up to hundreds to thousands of hours in
GPU compute time.

And that’s just for experts — what about non-deep learning
experts?

Enter Auto-Keras and AutoML:

The end goal of both Auto-Keras and AutoML is to reduce the
barrier to entry to performing machine learning and deep learning
through the use of automated Neural Network Search (NAS)
algorithms.

Using AutoML and Auto-Keras, a programmer with minimal machine
learning expertise can apply these algorithms to achieve
state-of-the-art performance with very little effort.

Sound too good to be true?

Well, maybe — but you’ll need to read the rest of the post first
to find out why. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTAxMzA4ODQzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMDcvYXV0by1rZXJhcy1hbmQtYXV0b21sLWEtZ2V0dGluZy1zdGFydGVkLWd1aWRlLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Spoiler alert — Both Google’s AutoML and Auto-Keras are
great steps forward; however, automated machine learning is
nowhere near solved.

While Auto-Keras performed reasonably well on my CIFAR-10 test,
when I applied it to one of my previous tutorials on medical deep
learning and malaria detection, Auto-Keras only achieved 96%
accuracy, a full percentage point below my 97% accuracy using a
simple ResNet architecture I had implemented.

Furthermore, Auto-Keras required a full 2,300%+ more compute
time when compared to my own implementation and training of
ResNet.

Automatic machine learning (currently) does not beat having
expertise in deep learning — domain expertise, specifically in
the data you are working with, is absolutely critical to obtain a
higher accuracy model.

My suggestion is for you to invest in your deep learning
knowledge, don’t rely on automated algorithms.

To be a successful deep learning practitioner and engineer you
need to bring the right tool to the job. Use AutoML and
Auto-Keras for what they are, tools, and then continue to fill
your own toolbox with additional knowledge.

If you're interested in building out your own deep learning and
computer vision toolbox, make sure you take a look at my
book, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTAxMzA4ODQzNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Inside the book you'll find hands-on tutorials (with lots of
code) that not only show you the algorithms behind deep learning
+ computer vision, but their implementations as well.

You'll also find super practical walkthroughs to actual,
real-world image classification problems, projects, and
challenges using image classification (ResNet, Inception, etc.),
object detection (Faster R-CNNs, SSDs, RetinaNet), and instance
segmentation (Mask R-CNN).

After going through my deep learning book you'll have all the
tools you need to become a successful deep learning practitioner.

Sound interesting?

To learn more, including (1) what topics are included in the book
as well as (2) get a feel for my writing and teaching style, I've
put together a (free) PDF including sample chapters and the table
of contents:

Click here to grab your sample chapters and table of contents PDF
( http://t.dripemail2. )

I'll then email you the PDF in a few short minutes.

Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:

1. The React Handbook - a massive free guide to building web applications with ReactJS (116 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/the-react-handbook-b71c27b0a795

2. How to build your own Tetris game using Python and Pygame (2 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/tetris-python-tutorial-pygame

3. The story of how Christina went from stay-at-home mother of 3 kids to working full time from home as a JavaScript developer (3 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/244230

4. Learn MongoDB - the popular NoSQL database - by building a Node.js CRUD app from scratch (75 minute watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/mongodb-crud-app

5. Over the winter holiday, Angela challenged herself to build one coding project each day for 20 days. Her resulting apps are fun and elegant. (6 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/5cd4c9383f84

This week's quote: "If the automobile had followed the same development cycle as the computer, a Rolls-Royce would today cost $100, get a million miles per gallon, and explode once a year, killing everyone inside." - Robert Cringely

Ashikur, you have 40 new notifications
Hey there,

I just ran the numbers and can confirm that today's tutorial on
Machine Learning in Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTEwMTM0MDMzMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMTQvbWFjaGluZS1sZWFybmluZy1pbi1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) is the longest tutorial I've ever written:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTEwMTM0MDMzMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMTQvbWFjaGluZS1sZWFybmluZy1pbi1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

The purpose of today's 8,000+ word behemoth of a blog post is to
give you hands-on experience creating machine learning and deep
learning pipelines.

Specifically, you will learn how to:

* Examine your problem
* Prepare your data (raw data, feature extraction, feature
engineering, etc.)
* Spot-check a set of algorithms
* Examine your results
* Double-down on the algorithms that worked best

You'll also gain hands-on experience working with 9 machine
learning algorithms applied to both numerical data and image
data:

* k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN)
* Naïve Bayes
* Logistic Regression
* Support Vector Machines (SVMs)
* Decision Trees
* Random Forests
* Perceptrons
* Multi-layer, feedforward neural networks
* Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)

If you're ready to get your start in machine learning with
Python, this is the definitive guide. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTEwMTM0MDMzMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMTQvbWFjaGluZS1sZWFybmluZy1pbi1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. It took quite a long time (and a huge amount of effort) for
me to put this massive, comprehensive tutorial together.

If you enjoyed it and think your friends, colleagues, or
co-workers would enjoy it as well, please share it on your
favorite social media channels (ex. Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn
etc.). Sharing tutorials helps me grow PyImageSearch which in
turn allows me to keep creating these free tutorials for you to
learn from.

Here is a sample social media post I put together:
How to get started in Machine Learning with Python. Read the full
tutorial here:
http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTEwMTM0MDMzMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMTQvbWFjaGluZS1sZWFybmluZy1pbi1weXRob24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9
#MachineLearning #DeepLearning #Python

If you enjoyed today's tutorial, please consider copying +
pasting it and posting it on your favorite social media channels.

Thank you so much!

Tushar, start a conversation with your new connection, Sayed
Hi,

Today’s brand new post ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTE3OTMyMDM1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjEvcmVncmVzc2lvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )
kicks off a 3-part series on deep learning, regression, and
continuous value prediction:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTE3OTMyMDM1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjEvcmVncmVzc2lvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Specifically, we’ll be studying regression prediction in the
context of house price prediction:

* Part 1: Today we’ll be training a neural network to predict
house prices based on categorical and numerical attributes ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTE3OTMyMDM1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjEvcmVncmVzc2lvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) such as the number of bedrooms/bathrooms, square footage, zip
code, etc.
* Part 2: Next week we’ll train a Convolutional Neural Network to
predict house prices based on input images of the houses
themselves (i.e., frontal view of the house, bedroom, bathroom,
and kitchen).
* Part 3: And in two weeks we’ll define and train a neural
network that combines our categorical/numerical attributes with
our images, leading to better, more accurate house price
prediction than the attributes or images alone.

Unlike classification (which predicts labels), regression enables
us to predict continuous values.

For example, classification may be able to predict one of the
following values: {cheap, affordable, expensive}.

Regression, on the other hand, will be able to predict an exact
dollar amount, such as “The estimated price of this house is
$489,121”.

In many real-world situations, such as house price prediction or
stock market forecasting, applying regression rather than
classification is critical to obtaining good predictions.

To learn how to utilize Deep Learning + Keras for regression (and
prepare yourself for the next two tutorials in the series), just
click here to keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTE3OTMyMDM1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjEvcmVncmVzc2lvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:

1. Harvard's CS50 Intro to Computer Science course is now free (and ad-free) on freeCodeCamp's YouTube channel. We're posting one new video each day and discussing them here (40 hour course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/the-first-few-harvard-cs50-videos-are-now-live/253738

2. Capture The Flag challenges are a great way to expand your cybersecurity and ethical hacking skills. Here's an in-depth walkthrough of the popular PicoCTF challenge (6 hour tutorial): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/improve-cybersecurity-skills-with-ctfs-picoctf-walkthrough

3. How Graph Data Structures work - explained visually (9 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/6d88f36ec768

4. How to build your own First Person Shooter game - using Unity3D (8 hour tutorial): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/unity-3d-first-person-shooter-game-tutorial

5. Maribel's parents immigrated to the US as field workers. She was the first person in her family to graduate from college. And after years of teaching herself coding, she is now working as a software engineer. This is her story (16 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/4ae301fc02b

This weeks quote: "The Web as I envisaged it, we have not seen it yet. The future is still so much bigger than the past."?—?Tim Berners-Lee (inventor of the web)

Happy coding!

Hello,
This is to inform you that HackerEarth will be under maintenance on 30th January, 2019 between 01:30 AM and 02:30 AM UTC. During this entire duration, the HackerEarth platform will be inaccessible and all operations on the platform will be paused.
This maintenance will add more capacity to our infrastructure and speed up our overall services.
We apologize for any inconvenience. Do write to us at support@hackerearth.com if you have any questions.
Regards,
Team HackerEarth

Ashikur, you have 43 new notifications
Hi,

Today I want to share with you a brand new tutorial on how to
train a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for regression
prediction with Keras. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI2MDAxOTk4OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjgva2VyYXMtcmVncmVzc2lvbi1hbmQtY25ucy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Specifically, you’ll learn how to train a CNN to predict house
prices from a set of images:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI2MDAxOTk4OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjgva2VyYXMtcmVncmVzc2lvbi1hbmQtY25ucy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Today’s tutorial builds on last week’s basic Keras regression
example ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI2MDAxOTk4OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjEvcmVncmVzc2lvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ), so if you haven’t read it yet make sure you go through it in
order to follow along here today.

By the end of this guide you will have:

* A strong understanding of training CNNs for regression
prediction with Keras
* A Python code template you can use for your own CNN +
regression projects
* My simple hack/trick to tile multiple images together when
passing them through a CNN, leading to higher accuracy

To learn how to train a CNN for regression prediction with Keras
(and discover my trick to working with multiple images per data
point), just read the full tutorial here! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI2MDAxOTk4OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjgva2VyYXMtcmVncmVzc2lvbi1hbmQtY25ucy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

I'll be back next week with the final tutorial in this 3-part
series where we'll combine categorical, numeric, and image data
into a single end-to-end neural network.

Stay tuned!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Hi!

Typically I only publish tutorials on Monday, but this week I
have an additional two posts to share with you.

A couple weeks ago I released the v2.1 edition of my book, Deep
Learning for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI4NTc4Mzc0NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (DL4CV).

This release of DL4CV includes support for the latest (stable)
deep learning and machine learning packages, including CUDA,
cuDNN, TensorFlow, Keras, mxnet, OpenCV, scikit-learn, and more.

To help you configure your own deep learning development
environments I've released two brand new tutorials for Ubuntu and
macOS:

* Ubuntu 18.04: Install TensorFlow and Keras for Deep Learning ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI4NTc4Mzc0NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMzAvdWJ1bnR1LTE4LTA0LWluc3RhbGwtdGVuc29yZmxvdy1hbmQta2VyYXMtZm9yLWRlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmcvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )
* macOS Mojave: Install TensorFlow and Keras for Deep Learning ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI4NTc4Mzc0NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMzAvbWFjb3MtbW9qYXZlLWluc3RhbGwtdGVuc29yZmxvdy1hbmQta2VyYXMtZm9yLWRlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmcvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

These guides have been thoroughly tested to ensure you can
configure your deep learning environment with minimal headache
and frustration.

After configuring your dev environment I recommend you work
through my Keras tutorial where you'll learn the fundamentals of
neural networks and deep learning (including training your first
NNs and CNNs):

Keras Tutorial: How to get started with Keras, Deep Learning, and
Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI4NTc4Mzc0NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDkvMTAva2VyYXMtdHV0b3JpYWwtaG93LXRvLWdldC1zdGFydGVkLXdpdGgta2VyYXMtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy1hbmQtcHl0aG9uLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Enjoy the tutorials!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. You're interested in deep learning and computer vision...

...but you don't know how to get started. Let me help.

Whether this is the first time you've worked with machine
learning and neural networks or you're already a seasoned deep
learning practitioner, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with
Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTI4NTc4Mzc0NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) is designed from the ground up to help you reach expert status.

Inside the book you'll find:
* Super practical walkthroughs covering machine learning basics,
neural networks, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), transfer
learning/fine-tuning, Faster R-CNNs, Single Shot Detectors
(SSDs), RetinaNet, Mask R-CNN, and more!

* Hands-on tutorials with lots of code that not only show you
the algorithms behind deep learning for computer vision but
their implementations as well.
* My best practices, tips, and suggestions showing you how to
improve and perfect your models for the real world. You’ll not
only learn deep learning, but you’ll also learn how to properly
run experiments and tune hyperparameters as well!

To help you get a feel for my teaching style (and see how the
text will help you on your deep learning journey), I've put
together a (free) PDF that includes both:

* The table of contents to my book
* 5 sample chapters

To claim your copy of the PDF just use the following link:

I want the table of contents + sample chapters PDF. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

I'll then email you the PDF in a few short minutes.

Even if you decide my deep learning book is not for you, that's
totally okay. My goal is to provide you with the best possible
resources to learn computer vision + deep learning.

Regardless, I hope you continue to enjoy the PyImageSearch blog
and the free weekly tutorials!

Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:

1. Python is a great programming language to learn once you feel comfortable with JavaScript. Here's Harvard's Intro to Python (2 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/learn-python-from-harvards-cs50

2. And if you want to dig even further into Python, try our in-depth course on Python basics (4 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/learn-python-basics-in-depth-video-course

3. How to produce your own meaningful datasets - right in SQL (7 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/394c4781a5e0

4. Ursula was in her late 30s and unhappy with her career in science. Here's how she taught herself to code using freeCodeCamp for 10 months, then got a job as a developer (3 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/252499/32

5. Here are 560 free online programming and computer science courses that you can start in February (browsable list): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/e621d959e64

Quote of the Week: "The most amazing achievement of the computer software industry is its continuing cancellation of the steady and staggering gains made by the computer hardware industry." - Henry Petroski

Happy coding!

- Quincy Larson

Teacher at freeCodeCamp.org

???? ??=??% ???, ?????= ??% ??????????, ????? ??????- ?% ???!
You've received this email because you have a consumer (personal) Google+  
account or you manage a Google+ page.

In December 2018, we announced(Link  
https://blog.google/technology/safety-security/expediting-changes-google-plus/)  
our decision to shut down Google+ for consumers in April 2019 due to low  
usage and challenges involved in maintaining a successful product that  
meets consumers' expectations. We want to thank you for being part of  
Google+ and provide next steps, including how to download your photos and  
other content.

On April 2nd, your Google+ account and any Google+ pages you created will  
be shut down and we will begin deleting content from consumer Google+  
accounts. Photos and videos from Google+ in your Album Archive and your  
Google+ pages will also be deleted. You can download and save(Link  
https://support.google.com/plus/answer/1045788) your content, just make  
sure to do so before April. Note that photos and videos backed up in Google  
Photos will not be deleted.

The process of deleting content from consumer Google+ accounts, Google+  
Pages, and Album Archive will take a few months, and content may remain  
through this time. For example, users may still see parts of their Google+  
account via activity log and some consumer Google+ content may remain  
visible to G Suite users until consumer Google+ is deleted.

As early as February 4th, you will no longer be able to create new Google+  
profiles, pages, communities or events.

See the full FAQ(Link https://support.google.com/plus/answer/9217723) for  
more details and updates leading up to the shutdown.

If you're a Google+ Community owner or moderator, you may download and  
save(Link https://support.google.com/plus/answer/1045788) your data for  
your Google+ Community. Starting early March 2019, additional data will be  
available for download, including author, body, and photos for every  
community post in a public community. Learn more (Link  
https://support.google.com/plus/answer/1045788#communities)

If you sign in to sites and apps using the Google+ Sign-in button, these  
buttons will stop working in the coming weeks but in some cases may be  
replaced by a Google Sign-in button. You'll still be able to sign in with  
your Google Account wherever you see Google Sign-in buttons. Learn more  
(Link https://support.google.com/plus/answer/9217723#signin?)

If you've used Google+ for comments on your own or other sites, this  
feature will be removed from Blogger by February 4th and other sites by  
March 7th. All your Google+ comments on all sites will be deleted starting  
April 2, 2019. Learn more(Link  
https://support.google.com/plus/answer/9217723#blogger)

If you're a G Suite customer, Google+ for your G Suite account should  
remain active. Contact your G Suite administrator(Link  
https://support.google.com/a/answer/6208960) for more details. You can also  
expect a new look and new features soon. Learn more(Link  
https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/g-suite/new-enterprise-grade-features-in-googleplus-help-businesses-drive-collaboration)

If you're a developer using Google+ APIs or Google+ Sign-in, click  
here(Link https://developers.google.com/+/api-shutdown) to see how this  
will impact you.

 From all of us on the Google+ team, thank you for making Google+ such a  
special place. We are grateful for the talented group of artists, community  
builders, and thought leaders who made Google+ their home. It would not  
have been the same without your passion and dedication.

Google LLC 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043

about important changes to your Google+ Page, product or account.

? Asik Pantho is a new friend suggestion for you
Hi,

In previous tutorials on the PyImageSearch blog I have covered
deep learning for multi-label classification and multi-input
prediction...but never multi-input.

Today that changes.

In today's brand new tutorial, you will learn how to use Keras
for multi-input and mixed data. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMDQva2VyYXMtbXVsdGlwbGUtaW5wdXRzLWFuZC1taXhlZC1kYXRhLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Specifically, you will learn how to define a Keras architecture
capable of accepting multiple inputs, including numerical,
categorical, and image data. We’ll then train a single end-to-end
network on this mixed data:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMDQva2VyYXMtbXVsdGlwbGUtaW5wdXRzLWFuZC1taXhlZC1kYXRhLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

As you probably guessed, today is the final installment in our
three part series on Keras and regression:

* Basic regression with Keras ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjEvcmVncmVzc2lvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (two weeks ago)
* Training a Keras CNN for regression prediction ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDEvMjgva2VyYXMtcmVncmVzc2lvbi1hbmQtY25ucy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) (last week)
* Multiple inputs and mixed data with Keras ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMDQva2VyYXMtbXVsdGlwbGUtaW5wdXRzLWFuZC1taXhlZC1kYXRhLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (today’s post)

In this series of posts, we’ve explored regression prediction in
the context of house price prediction.

The house price dataset we are using includes not only numerical
and categorical data, but image data as well — we call multiple
types of data/modalities mixed data as our model needs to be
capable of accepting our multiple inputs (that are not of the
same type) and computing a prediction on these inputs.

In the remainder of this tutorial you will learn how to:

* Define a Keras model capable of accepting multiple inputs,
including numerical, categorical, and image data, all at the same
time.
* Train an end-to-end Keras model on the mixed data inputs.
* Evaluate our model using the multi-inputs.

To learn more about multiple inputs and mixed data with Keras,
just keep reading the full post here! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMDQva2VyYXMtbXVsdGlwbGUtaW5wdXRzLWFuZC1taXhlZC1kYXRhLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. If you enjoyed today's more advanced deep learning post and
want to continue studying deep learning in more detail, be sure
to check out my book, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with
Python. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTM0MjYzMzcyNyIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

The book is designed to not only teach you the fundamentals of
deep learning but also advanced techniques and algorithms as
well, including:

* Building your own custom datasets
* Efficiently working with datasets too large to fit into memory
* Applying transfer learning and fine-tuning
* Building your own custom object detectors with Faster R-CNN,
Single Shot Detectors (SSDs), and RetinaNet
* Training custom instance segmentation networks with Mask R-CNN

To give you a taste of the book (and the value that you'll be
getting if you decide to pick up a copy) I've prepared a PDF that
includes both the table of contents and 5 free sample chapters to
the book.

To grab your free table of contents + sample chapters PDF just
use this link:

I want the table of contents + sample chapters PDF. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

I'll then email you the PDF in a few short minutes.

Tushar, see who you already know on LinkedIn
Has this ever happened to you?

You spot an opportunity for your company to do something better. You flesh out the idea, develop the proposal, and present it to the decision-makers.

And nothing happens.

Why do managers and business leaders pass on great ideas? Sometimes it boils down to apathy, aversion to change, and unconscious biases. Hard data can get you past all that—and give you the concrete proof you need to get to yes.

We designed our newest Pro Path, Data Science ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/paths/data-science?utm_test=optimize&utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pro_test_feb_18_b&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ), to teach professionals from every industry to persuade through data. This is the only offering of its kind that doesn't just teach the technical side—but also how to communicate your findings.

We'll guide you step-by-step from zero experience to work-ready in this self-paced Pro Path—giving you the skill set you need to solve real-life data analysis problems and create compelling visualizations with your findings. Along the way, you'll be able to track your progress through carefully selected milestones that we've laid out to help you strengthen your data-driven persuasion skills—which you can then apply to your career.

Next time, deliver a presentation with facts that your boss can’t ignore. Upgrade to Pro to begin the Data Science ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/paths/data-science?utm_test=optimize&utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pro_test_feb_18_b&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ) Path today.

Get Started ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/membership?utm_test=optimize&utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pro_test_feb_18_b&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=bottom_cta )

You appeared in 4 searches this week
Hi there,

Today you will learn how to train a simple Convolutional Neural
Network (CNN) with Keras on the Fashion MNIST dataset, ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTQyMTQyMDM2NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTEvZmFzaGlvbi1tbmlzdC13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) enabling you to classify fashion images and categories:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTQyMTQyMDM2NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTEvZmFzaGlvbi1tbmlzdC13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

The Fashion MNIST dataset is meant to be a (slightly more
challenging) drop-in replacement for the (less challenging) MNIST
dataset.

Similar to the MNIST digit dataset, the Fashion MNIST dataset
includes:

* 60,000 training examples
* 10,000 testing examples
* 10 classes
* 28×28 grayscale/single channel images

The ten fashion class labels include:

* T-shirt/top
* Trouser/pants
* Pullover shirt
* Dress
* Coat
* Sandal
* Shirt
* Sneaker
* Bag
* Ankle boot

Throughout this tutorial, you will learn how to train a simple
Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with Keras on the Fashion
MNIST dataset, giving you not only hands-on experience working
with the Keras library but also your first taste of
clothing/fashion classification.

To learn how to train a Keras CNN on the Fashion MNIST dataset,
just click here to read the full tutorial! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTQyMTQyMDM2NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTEvZmFzaGlvbi1tbmlzdC13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. After going through the tutorial you'll properly wondering
if the model we just trained on the Fashion MNIST dataset would
be directly applicable to images outside the Fashion MNIST
dataset?

The short answer is “No, unfortunately not.”

I provide deeper commentary on why a model trained on Fashion
MNIST may not transfer over to real-world images inside the post
but the crux is simply this:

Keep in mind that the Fashion MNIST dataset is meant to be a
drop-in replacement for the MNIST dataset, implying that our
images have already been processed.

For real-world fashion and clothing images, you would have to
preprocess your data in the same manner as the Fashion MNIST
dataset. And furthermore, even if you could preprocess your
dataset in the exact same manner, the model still might not be
transferable to real-world images.

You can and should use Fashion MNIST as a drop-in replacement for
the MNIST digit dataset; however, if you are interested in
actually recognizing fashion items in real-world images you
should refer to the following two tutorials:

* Multi-label classification with Keras ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTQyMTQyMDM2NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDUvMDcvbXVsdGktbGFiZWwtY2xhc3NpZmljYXRpb24td2l0aC1rZXJhcy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )
* Keras: Multiple outputs and multiple losses ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTQyMTQyMDM2NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDYvMDQva2VyYXMtbXVsdGlwbGUtb3V0cHV0cy1hbmQtbXVsdGlwbGUtbG9zc2VzLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Both of the tutorials linked to above will guide you in building
a more robust fashion classification system.

???? ?????! ????? ???????? '?' ????!
Hi,

In today's brand new tutorial, you will learn how to train a
Keras deep learning model to predict breast cancer in breast
histology images: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTUwNTE1NzcwMCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTgvYnJlYXN0LWNhbmNlci1jbGFzc2lmaWNhdGlvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTUwNTE1NzcwMCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTgvYnJlYXN0LWNhbmNlci1jbGFzc2lmaWNhdGlvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

This tutorial is important to me in couple of ways.

To start, it brings me back to 2012-2013 when I was working for
the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the National Cancer
Institute (NCI) to develop a suite of image processing and
machine learning algorithms to automatically analyze breast
histology images for cancer risk factors, a task that took
trained pathologists hours to complete. Our work helped
facilitate further advancements in breast cancer risk factor
prediction.

You see, back then deep learning was not as popular and
“mainstream” as it is now. For example, the ImageNet image
classification challenge had only launched in 2009 and it wasn’t
until 2012 that Alex Krizhevsky, Ilya Sutskever, and Geoffrey
Hinton won the competition with the now infamous AlexNet
architecture.

To analyze the cellular structures in the breast histology images
we were instead leveraging basic computer vision and image
processing algorithms, but combining them in a novel way. These
algorithms worked really well — but also required quite a bit of
work to put together.

Deep learning and medical image analysis has come a long way
since my time at NIH and NCI, so to show how deep learning can be
used to further help medical researchers, I thought it would be
worthwhile to explore deep learning in the context of breast
cancer classification. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTUwNTE1NzcwMCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTgvYnJlYXN0LWNhbmNlci1jbGFzc2lmaWNhdGlvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

This tutorial is important to me for a second reason as well —
just last year a close family member of mine was diagnosed with
cancer. And similarly, I would be willing to bet that every
single reader of this blog knows someone who has had cancer at
some point as well.

As deep learning researchers, practitioners, and engineers it’s
important for us to gain hands-on experience applying deep
learning to medical and computer vision problems — this
experience can help us develop deep learning algorithms to better
aid pathologists in predicting cancer.

To learn how to train a Keras deep learning model for breast
cancer prediction, just keep reading the full tutorial here! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTUwNTE1NzcwMCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMTgvYnJlYXN0LWNhbmNlci1jbGFzc2lmaWNhdGlvbi13aXRoLWtlcmFzLWFuZC1kZWVwLWxlYXJuaW5nLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Are you interested in applying computer vision and deep
learning to medical applications?

If so, be sure to take a look at my book, Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTUwNTE1NzcwMCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) (DL4CV).

Inside the book I provide detailed chapters (including code) on
how to utilize Mask R-CNN to:

* Annotate your own training data
* Train Mask R-CNN for instance segmentation on your own custom
datasets
* Use Mask R-CNN for skin lesion/cancer detection

* Train a Mask R-CNN for prescription pill detection and
segmentation

Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:

1. How to solve algorithm challenges in job interviews - a free 4-hour course.  This is taught using Python, which is similar to JavaScript and also worth learning.  (4 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/python-algorithms-for-job-interviews

2. The host of a popular Python podcast explains NoSQL databases and helps you get started with MongoDB (2 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/mongodb-quickstart-with-python

3. How to write an awesome junior developer résumé in a few simple steps (7 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/316010db80ec

4. How a young father from a small town in the American South taught himself to code for 2 years then got a job as a data engineer (12 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/forum/t/258285

5. From Zero to Deploy: How Eden created her own static website from scratch using Netlify and Gatsby, and how you can do it, too (5 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/ebca82612ffd

Quote of the Week: "A computer lets you make more mistakes faster than any invention in human history - with the possible exceptions of handguns and tequila." - Mitch Ratliff

Tushar, start a conversation with your new connection, Md. Nure Alam
Hi there,

A couple weeks ago I was visiting my parent's house. After dinner
my mom brought out an old photo album, and as we were leafing
through the pages of pictures, we came across a super old black
and white photo of my grandfather.

I never knew my grandfather, he died well before I was born. But
according to my dad him and I are pretty alike.

We both have short legs but walk very quickly. We both have the
same mannerisms. We've even moved to the same areas of the United
States at similar ages (a fact that I didn't know until last
year).

I would have liked to meet him — and looking at the old photo I
couldn't help but wonder what he would look like in full color.

If you know me at all, then you know once I start "wondering" how
computer vision could be applied to a project you can be pretty
sure there will be a blog post in the future!

The photo was too old and brittle for me to take it home after
the visit but I did spend the next day working on black and white
image colorization.

Today I'm happy to share the result of the work with you. Inside
this brand new tutorial you will learn how
to automatically colorize black and white images using OpenCV and
Deep Learning: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTU4Mzg4MjMxOCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMjUvYmxhY2stYW5kLXdoaXRlLWltYWdlLWNvbG9yaXphdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1hbmQtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTU4Mzg4MjMxOCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMjUvYmxhY2stYW5kLXdoaXRlLWltYWdlLWNvbG9yaXphdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1hbmQtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

The novel approach we are going to use here today instead relies
on deep learning. We will utilize a Convolutional Neural Network
capable of colorizing black and white images with results that
can even “fool” humans!

To learn how to perform black and white image colorization (and
get the source code + pre-trained models), you'll need to read
the full post here. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTU4Mzg4MjMxOCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDIvMjUvYmxhY2stYW5kLXdoaXRlLWltYWdlLWNvbG9yaXphdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1hbmQtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

---------------------
To make sure you keep getting these emails, please add
adrian@pyimagesearch.com to your address book or whitelist us. Want out of
the loop? <a href="http://t.dripemail2.">Unsubscribe</a>.
Our postal address: PO Box 17598 #17900, Baltimore, MD 21297-1598


Colorize black and white images with OpenCV and Deep Learning.

Tushar, start a conversation with your new connection, pervez
Hi,

Story time:

The first (and only) computer vision/image processing course I
took during college was "computational photography" during my
final undergraduate year.

Our first project in the course was to install OpenCV on our
system (and believe me, back then it was a multi-day project to
say the least).

The second project was a bit more practical — use OpenCV and the
Canny edge detector to count the number of coins in an image.

It was a great first project for us novices in computer vision
and image processing. Everyone in the class got their hands dirty
in code. We all got to see the computer vision algorithms we were
studying in the classroom "in action".

However, through our exploration we found there are a few
problems with the Canny edge detector, namely:

* Setting the lower and upper values to the hysteresis
thresholding is a manual process which requires experimentation
and visual validation.
* Hysteresis thresholding values that work well for one image may
not work well for another (this is nearly always true for images
captured in varying lighting conditions).
* The Canny edge detector often requires a number of
preprocessing steps (i.e. conversion to grayscale,
blurring/smoothing, etc.) in order to obtain a good edge map.

The Canny edge detector dates all the way back to 1986 when it
was first published and introduced to the computer vision would.

Is there a better way to perform edge detection nowadays?

Actually, there is (depending on your project requirements and
assumptions, of course).

Holistically-Nested Edge Detection ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTY2MjIzNjQ1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMDQvaG9saXN0aWNhbGx5LW5lc3RlZC1lZGdlLWRldGVjdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1hbmQtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) (HED) attempts to address the limitations of the Canny edge
detector through an end-to-end deep neural network:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTY2MjIzNjQ1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMDQvaG9saXN0aWNhbGx5LW5lc3RlZC1lZGdlLWRldGVjdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1hbmQtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

This network accepts an RGB image as an input and then produces
an edge map as an output. Furthermore, the edge map produced by
HED does a better job preserving object boundaries in the image.

To learn how to apply Holistically-Nested Edge Detection to your
own images and video (as well as grab the source code +
pre-trained model), just click here to keep reading. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTY2MjIzNjQ1NCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMDQvaG9saXN0aWNhbGx5LW5lc3RlZC1lZGdlLWRldGVjdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1hbmQtZGVlcC1sZWFybmluZy8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Cheers,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

the loop? <a href="http://t.dripemail2.">Unsubscribe</a>.

Python (red), the most popular programming language on StackOverflow in 2017.

JavaScript has been dethroned by the world’s new chief programming language: Python. And due to Python's association with rapidly growing fields such as Data Science and Machine Learning, its growth is unlikely to slow soon.

But coding, especially in Python, is not limited to burgeoning technical fields. Professionals of all kinds who learn Python improve their careers by using code to simplify and optimize their work-life. For example, you can use Python to:
* Automate manual reporting tasks

* Scrape data from web pages

* Export data into spreadsheets

* Create beautiful data visualizations
“We can do it in Python,” just might become your new catch-phrase, and Codecademy can definitely help you make it ring true. Programming with Python ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/intensive/programming-with-python?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pro_test_mar_7_a&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ) is our nine-week Intensive that we designed to introduce you to Python's powerful capabilities. * Write code that is robust and scalable

* Use Natural Language Processing to solve a murder mystery

Have no fear if you're worried you might get stuck on your own journey of personal growth. Our community support is often described by our learners as one of the most uplifting parts of their Codecademy experience.

Check-ins
Hi there,

Today's tutorial on liveliness detection with OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMTEvbGl2ZW5lc3MtZGV0ZWN0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) has been one of the most requested tutorials on the
PyImageSearch blog.

You see, over the past year I have authored a number of face
recognition tutorials, including:

* OpenCV Face Recognition ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDkvMjQvb3BlbmN2LWZhY2UtcmVjb2duaXRpb24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )
* Face recognition with dlib, Python, and deep learning ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDYvMTgvZmFjZS1yZWNvZ25pdGlvbi13aXRoLW9wZW5jdi1weXRob24tYW5kLWRlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmcvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )
* Raspberry Pi Face Recognition ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTgvMDYvMjUvcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZhY2UtcmVjb2duaXRpb24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

However, a common question I get asked over email and in the
comments sections of the face recognition posts is:

How do I spot real faces versus fake faces?

For instance, what would happen if a nefarious user tried
to purposely circumvent your face recognition system?

Such a user could try to hold up a photo of another person. Maybe
they even have a photo or video on their smartphone that they
could hold up to the camera used for performing face recognition:

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMTEvbGl2ZW5lc3MtZGV0ZWN0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

In those situations it’s entirely possible for the face held up
to the camera to be correctly recognized…but ultimately leading
to an unauthorized user bypassing your face recognition system!

How would you go about spotting these “fake” versus
“real/legitimate” faces? How could you apply anti-face spoofing
algorithms into your facial recognition applications?

The answer is to be apply liveness detection with OpenCV and Deep
Learning which is exactly what I’ll be covering today.

Inside the tutorial you will learn how to:
* Gather your own dataset of real versus fake faces
* Implement a Convolutional Neural Network (using Keras) for
liveness detection
* Train the network on our custom dataset
* Deploy the trained model and detect real/fake faces in
real-time using OpenCV

To learn how to incorporate liveness detection with OpenCV into
your own face recognition systems, just keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMTEvbGl2ZW5lc3MtZGV0ZWN0aW9uLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Looking for more more practical applications of computer
vision and deep learning?

If so, be sure to take a look at my book, Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTc0MjcwMzE0OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9eHh4eHh4eFx1MDAyNl9fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) (DL4CV).

Inside the book I provide detailed chapters (including code) on
how to:

* Identify and recognize facial expressions/emotions using CNNs.
* Train deep learning-based object detectors (Faster R-CNN,
Single Shot Detectors, and RetinaNet) on your own custom
datasets.

* Apply object detection to real-world projects, including logo
detection, front/rear vehicle detection, and weapon detection.

* Annotate your own dataset for instance segmentation with Mask
R-CNN.

* Train Mask R-CNN for cancer/skin lesion segmentation and
prescription pill localization.

If you're interested in learning more about DL4CV, including
grabbing a PDF of 5 FREE sample chapters and the table of
contents, just click the link below:

Click here and I'll email you a PDF of sample chapters and table
of contents. ( http://t.dripemail2. )

Once you click the link above I'll email you the PDF of the
sample chapters + table of contents in a few short
minutes.

New Course: Learn Phaser ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-phaser?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_18_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

Set Phasers to Game!

 

Like Star Trek, Codecademy is exploring new frontiers. We've taught
millions of people how to query data, design websites, and now we are
thrilled to introduce you to Phaser—a popular gateway into game
development.

 

Our new Learn Phaser ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-phaser?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_18_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )
course will show you how to create delightful web-based games
while also helping you build a valuable technical skill set.
The games you'll build in this course are inspired by arcade classics
like Space Invaders.

 

Spave Invaders with Codey from Codecaemy. ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-phaser?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_18_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=screenshot_img )
Space Invaders with Codey from Codecademy.

 

If you aren't familiar, Phaser is a fun-filled JavaScript framework that utilizes the
HTML5 canvas element to enable browser-based games.
Phaser skills provide you an excellent way to add creative projects to your
coding portfolio. For example, compared to static HTML and JavaScript websites, using Phaser demonstrates your ability to create a continuously interactive web experience.

 

Learn Phaser ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-phaser?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_18_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link ) kicks off by teaching you how to draw objects and recognize keyboard events in your game before covering more complex topics like simulating gravity and calculating a score. By the end, you'll have learned the fundamentals of how to use Phaser to build your own fun games.

 

Looking for inspiration before you get started? Our Curriculum Developers, Kenny and Tim, will be hosting a livestream today at 1:30pm EST ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sJlAzH-Kkx4 ). They will walk through the steps of using Phaser to create a game reminiscent to Frogger and will be taking questions from learners like you throughout. Check out their livestream before diving in to the course.

 

Start Now ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-phaser?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_18_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

Bonus Video: How to Pick a Path ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=exKho93RAug&feature=youtu.be )
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Do you face crippling indecision when faced with an overwhelming number of options (we're ? you, Seamless)? Don't worry it's completely normal—behavioral economists call this phenomenon the paradox of choice! If you're not sure what to learn, check out this new video: learn what our Paths cover and how to pick the right one based on what you want to accomplish.
Follow Along ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=exKho93RAug&feature=youtu.be )
P.S. Be the first to see new videos as soon as they're released: subscribe to our YouTube channel ( https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5CMtpogD_P3mOoeiDHD5eQ?sub_confirmation=1 ).

 

Happy coding,
Codecademy

Tushar, you have a new suggested connection to review
Hi,

I need a bit of help here.

As I announced earlier this week, I am writing a book on Computer
Vision with the Raspberry Pi. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTg1MjYzNDE2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMTgvaW0td3JpdGluZy1hLWJvb2stb24tY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLWFuZC10aGUtcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWFuZC1pLW5lZWQteW91ci1pbnB1dC8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

This book will focus on:

* Building practical, real-world computer vision applications on
the Raspberry Pi
* Optimizing your OpenCV code and algorithms on the resource
constrained Pi
* Computer Vision and Internet of Things (IoT) projects and
applications with the Raspberry Pi
* How to perform Deep Learning on the Raspberry Pi (including
utilizing the Movidius NCS and OpenVINO)
* Self-driving car applications with a Raspberry Pi

But before I can move forward, I need your help naming the book.

I have prepared a very short survey (only 2 questions) that will
take you less than 30 seconds to complete.

If you can spare a second, please use the link below to take the
survey and help me name the book:

Click here to help me name this upcoming Computer Vision +
Raspberry Pi book. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTg1MjYzNDE2OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmNvZ25pdG9mb3Jtcy5jb20vUHlJbWFnZVNlYXJjaDEvcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaHJhc3BiZXJyeXBpY29tcHV0ZXJ2aXNpb25ib29rdGl0bGVzdXJ2ZXk_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Remember, I am writing this book for YOU, so if you can take a
second to provide your input and help me name it, I would really
appreciate it.

Have an awesome day!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Bangladesh Insight | Mar 21, 2019

http://albd.org

Mar 21, 2019 | Issue 212

NEWSLETTER

https://goo.gl/iXLR3X

Bangladesh’s GDP growth to cross 8% for first time in FY19 https://goo.gl/iXLR3X

Bangladesh’s GDP growth in the current fiscal year is set to exceed 8% for the first time, according to Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics, or BBS. After analysing the data for the first eight months of the year (July-February), the BBS estimates a record economic growth of 8.13% at the end of the fiscal year 2018-2019. According to media reports, Bangladesh's per capita gross national income (GNI) jumped more than 9% to $1,909 https://goo.gl/nBbhhq last fiscal year from $1,751 a year ago, showed provisional official figures released this week. Bangladesh’s GDP growth was 7.86% in the past fiscal year while the per capita income was $1,751. Under the able leadership of Honourable Prime Minister (HPM) Sheikh Hasina, the economic growth crossed 7% in fiscal 2015-2016 after almost a decade in the region of 6%. 

Bangladesh celebrates 100th birthday of Father of the Nation Bangabandhu https://goo.gl/DerTwN

https://goo.gl/DerTwN

On March 17, the 99th birth anniversary of Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and National Children's Day was observed yesterday in a befitting manner with various socio-political and cultural organisations holding diverse programmes across the country. The Honouable President and the Premier paid their homage by placing wreaths at the mazar (mausoleum) of Bangabandhu in in Gopalganj’s Tungipara. People from all walks of life thronged Bangabandhu Memorial Museum at the capital's Dhanmondi, and made a vow to work together following Bangabandhu's ideals. 

https://goo.gl/xCx1ae 

HPM Sheikh Hasina condemn terror attacks https://goo.gl/3mRGhw

https://goo.gl/3mRGhw

Honourable President Abdul Hamid condemned the shooting at two mosques in New Zealand and reiterated Bangladesh's steadfast commitment against terrorism. In a message, he said, “We are deeply shocked to learn the shooting incidents at two mosques in Christchurch of New Zealand. We strongly condemn this heinous act of terrorism”. In a similar message to the New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, HPM Sheikh Hasina expressed her deep shock over the attack on New Zealand mosques that killed at least 49 people, including five Bangladeshis, and injured more than 20. In a similar development, the Canadian https://goo.gl/kysQAN premier phoned his Bangladesh counterpart and strongly denounced the terrorist attacks, urging the global community to stamp out terrorism.

Govt building overpasses at 4-way intersections: HPM Sheikh Hasina https://goo.gl/DuhFWy

https://goo.gl/DuhFWy

HPM Sheikh Hasina said on Saturday her government is building overpasses at the places of four-way intersections to ease communications by mitigating traffic congestions. “From now on, we will be building overpasses at the places of four-way intersections for making communications smooth and easier alongside stopping traffic gridlocks,” she said while inaugurating three development schemes. “There will be no four-way intersections at the places are meant for roads or rails. Initiatives have been taken to this end,” she said. 

Government plans maritime links with other states https://goo.gl/Nj4h81

https://goo.gl/Nj4h81

The government is planning to establish cross-border maritime connectivity with other countries after neighbouring Kolkata, India. The shipping service between Bangladesh and Kolkata will resume on March 29 after a suspension of long 70 years. According to media reports, a set of plans are being devised for establishing maritime connectivity with Assam and various states of India along with other neighbouring countries. The government will establish maritime connectivity, not only with the countries of this region, but also with other countries of different continents.

Bhutanese HPM to visit Dhaka next month https://goo.gl/gmeaAq

https://goo.gl/gmeaAq

Connectivity, increased trade and business, power and energy issues will get priority during the visit of Honourable Bhutanese Prime Minister Lotay Tshering who is expected to come to Dhaka in the second week of April. The Bhutanese premier is expected to visit here at the invitation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to increase cooperation on trade, inland waterways, health and agriculture sector between the two countries, according to media reports. During the visit, a number of bilateral instruments are expected to be signed to increase cooperation on inland waterways for cargo transportation, health and agriculture sectors.

Bangladesh working on trilateral power project with India https://goo.gl/k74HqE

https://goo.gl/k74HqE

Discussions are going on among Bangladesh, India and Bhutan to invest in a trilateral 1125MW hydropower project in Bhutan. Another trilateral hydropower project in Nepal by Bangladesh, India and Nepal is also under consideration. India and Bangladesh signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with GMR, an Indian company, in April 2017 for import of 500MW power from Nepal to Bangladesh. While speaking at an international conference on Tuesday, Bangladesh High Commissioner in New Delhi Syed Moazzem Ali confirmed the trilateral investment, reads media reports.

$145 million project to renovate gas pipelines in city https://goo.gl/vEChQ7

https://goo.gl/vEChQ7

Plans are laid out to take up a project to replace 2000 kilometres unfit gas distribution lines surrounding Dhaka at an estimated cost worth $145 million. The government is importing 500mmcfd of LNG. After supplying 350mmcfd in Chattogram, the supply of the rest 150mmcfd faces widespread systems loss in Dhaka due to old distribution pipelines. In consideration of the low-pressure problem, damaged gas pipeline and overburdened pipelines, the concerned authority has planned on improving gas distribution network in 60 areas in the first phase.

https://goo.gl/xCx1ae

China will facilitate more investment in Bangladesh: Honoruable Envoy https://goo.gl/KWqAVk

https://goo.gl/KWqAVk

Chinese Ambassador to Bangladesh Zhang Zuo said China would facilitate Chinese companies and SMEs to come to Bangladesh with more investments. “The Embassy of China in Bangladesh will work closely with DCCI (Dhaka Chamber of Commerce & Industry) to facilitate business together and to make innovations together. It will support DCCI as a bridge for communication with private industries,” the envoy said. The Chinese ambassador said this when he met DCCI President Osama Taseer at the DCCI this week.

New Course: Learn PHP ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-php?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_25_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

So what is PHP exactly and what does it stand for? PHP is a backend language that originally stood for Personal Home Page tools when it was first created by Rasmus Lerdorf in 1994. He developed PHP to track how many people were checking out his resume on his website (think Linkedin but in the 90s). Fast forward to 2019, PHP is now the fourth most popular programming language in the world with companies like Slack, Wikipedia, and WordPress using it to power their websites.

 

So why should you learn PHP?

 

1. You will be in good company — 80% of the internet runs on PHP.
2. You can pick up PHP faster — compared to other backend languages such as ASP.NET or CGI which require an understanding of other languages like C# or Perl to execute.
3. Create dynamic behavior on previously static HTML sites — with PHP your website will be able to interact with databases, send email, and customize the user experience for each visitor of your site.

 

Customize your website with PHP. ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-php?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_3_25_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=screenshot_img )
Customize your website with PHP.

In the first two modules we'll provide background information about the PHP language—including its history and how it's used today. Then we'll get hands on, starting with basic datatypes and variables.

Pop Quiz: What do Slack, Wikipedia, and WordPress have in common?
Hi there,

In today's brand tutorial you will learn how to build a Raspberry
Pi security camera using OpenCV and computer vision. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTkwNjMwMTE4OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMjUvYnVpbGRpbmctYS1yYXNwYmVycnktcGktc2VjdXJpdHktY2FtZXJhLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) The security camera will be Internet of Things (IoT) capable,
able to send TXT/MMS message notifications, images, and video
clips when the security camera is triggered.

Why build such a system?

To answer that, I need to tell you a short story:

Back in my undergrad years I had an obsession with hummus.

Hummus and pita/vegetables were my lunch of choice.

I loved it.

I lived on it.

And I was very protective of my hummus — college kids are
notorious for raiding each others fridges and stealing each
other’s food. No one was to touch my hummus.

But — I was a victim of such hummus theft on more than one
occasion…and I never forget it either!

I never figured out who stole my hummus, and even though my wife
and I are the only ones who live in our house, I often hide the
hummus in the back of the fridge (where no one will look) or
under fruits and vegetables (which most food thieves wouldn’t
want to eat anyway).

Of course, back then I didn’t have such a knowledge over computer
vision and OpenCV as I do now. Had I known what I do at present,
I would have built a Raspberry Pi security camera to capture the
hummus heist in action! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTkwNjMwMTE4OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMjUvYnVpbGRpbmctYS1yYXNwYmVycnktcGktc2VjdXJpdHktY2FtZXJhLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTkwNjMwMTE4OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMjUvYnVpbGRpbmctYS1yYXNwYmVycnktcGktc2VjdXJpdHktY2FtZXJhLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Today I’m channeling my inner undergrad-self and laying rest to
the chickpea bandit. And if they ever return again, beware, my
fridge is monitored!

To learn how to build a security camera with a Raspberry Pi and
OpenCV, just keep reading! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNTkwNjMwMTE4OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDMvMjUvYnVpbGRpbmctYS1yYXNwYmVycnktcGktc2VjdXJpdHktY2FtZXJhLXdpdGgtb3BlbmN2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Cheers,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

the loop? <a href="http://t.dripemail2.">Unsubscribe</a>.
