How to slay procrastination
It's rare that learning just one skill could rocket your pay into the six figures. But that’s the reality today.

Recent Indeed data shows that jobs requiring knowledge of React.js pay some of the highest salaries in the technology industry—as much as $102,589 per year on average. And if you've already designed a static website using HTML and CSS, you're perfectly placed to take advantage. Just give us a couple of weeks to get you up to speed.
 
Our new Web Development ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/paths/web-development?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=pro_test_mar_27_a&utm_medium=email&utm_term=a&utm_content=inline_link ) Pro Path will teach you the front-end programming skills that companies will pay a premium for. Along the way, you'll:
* Develop a strong foundation in JavaScript—before moving on to advanced concepts such as Modules and Requests.
* Learn React.js—the robust JavaScript library that powers Facebook, Instagram, and Netflix, among many other popular applications.
* Develop real-life portfolio projects—and front-end development skills you can start using in the workplace immediately.

Go from no front-end coding experience to building beautiful, functional web apps that will get you noticed—and hired. Start by tomorrow, March 28th, to take advantage of 20% savings on an annual Pro plan with the promo code REACT20.

Log In ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_login_button )

 

 

Monday Course Drop ( https://www.codecademy.com/catalog/subject/all?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=header_img )

 

 

New Course: Learn R ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-r?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

Pirate puns aside, we are stoked to introduce our first ever R course. R is not only one of the most popular programming languages for data analysis and statistics but is also an open-source interactive tool specifically designed to support data science. If you spend a lot of time slogging through Excel, it’s time to learn R.

 

To learn more about R and how people use it in their day to day work, meet Codecademy’s very own Data Scientist Manager, Catherine.

 

Codecademy's Senior Data Scientist - Catherine ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-r?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=screenshot_img )
Codecademy's Data Scientist Manager - Catherine

 

When and why did you learn R?
I moved over to R after college when I lost access to Stata (a statistics software). At the time, I was working as a data analyst and I needed to use software that was free to use. My primary motivation came after I saw examples of the data visualization and statistical modeling in R; it was beyond the capabilities of any other software I had used in the past.

 

What are the benefits of R over other languages?
Compared to other statistical software programs, R is great because it is free and open source. Open source languages tend to be well supported with online documentation, which made it much easier for me to look up code examples. Compared to other programming languages, R has built-in functionality for statistics and a wide ecosystem of packages. This means you can do virtually any type of statistical analysis you can imagine in R. You might’ve heard about Python for data science ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/data-processing-pandas?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta ). As a data scientist, it’s beneficial to learn a little bit of both R and Python, but choose whichever language works best for you to get started.

 

How do you use R on the day to day?
At Codecademy, I use R to clean and analyze our user data. We have millions of users and we use data to help us understand how to better serve our learners. I use R Studio and the packages I use most often are dplyr for data cleaning and ggplot for data visualization. R has allowed me to automate workflows, create interactive data visualizations, forecast business metrics, and detect breakages on our website.

 

Any tips for learning R?
1) Learn the tidyverse! This will make your code a lot cleaner and easy to read. Codecademy’s Learn R course will walk you through some tidyverse code to get you started.

2) Use data that’s interesting and/or meaningful to you. Using data you find interesting will make the learning process much more entertaining.

 

Our Learn R ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-r?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta ) course covers key R syntax such as variables and vectors and how to expand the capability of your workspace by importing a package. In the second lesson, we will tackle data cleaning and wrangling - two key prerequisites for performing sound data analysis.

 

Start Now ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-r?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

 

Looking for more?
Our Pro learners get access to projects that highlight the real world applications of R. In the first lesson of our brand new course, learners will estimate the population growth of Istanbul with UN data. Our curriculum developers, Natalia and Ian, will even be doing a livestream today at 1:30pm EST ( https://youtu.be/2hQeuALDU70 ), walking through the second lesson’s project -- how to clean data set from the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) on immigrant children separated from their families on the US-Mexico border. Upgrade today to start on one of these projects. ( https://www.codecademy.com/pro/membership?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=test_a )

Bonus Course: Learn LOLCode ( https://codecademy.com/learn/learn-lolcode?utm_source=customer_io_a&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

Codecademy Cat Coding ( https://codecademy.com/learn/learn-lolcode?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=screenshot_img )
Codecademy's Senior Product Manager's step cat coding

 

Happy April Fool's Day! To celebrate, we made a mini-course on an esoteric programming language called LOLCODE! Inspired by the old lolcats internet memes, this is a real programming language with catchphrases like "I CAN HAS" and "KTHXBYE" in place of traditional programming statements like print or echo. Basically, all those times your cat has been caught on the computer, they’ve actually been writing code. Learn with them and try out some LOLCode.

 

Start Now ( https://codecademy.com/learn/learn-lolcode?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_01_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

Tushar, you have a new suggested connection to review
Hi,

I just wanted to send you a quick email and let you know that
the Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision Kickstarter campaign is set
to launch in exactly one week on Wednesday, April 10th at 10AM
EST.

Image

Computer Vision, Deep Learning, and Internet of Things (IoT) are
three of the fastest-growing industries and subjects in computer
science — you will learn how to combine all three using the
Raspberry Pi inside my new book.

Whether this is the first time you've worked with the Raspberry
Pi or you're a hobbyist who's been working with the Pi for
years, Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision will enable you to "bring
sight" to the Pi.

Inside the book we will focus on:

* Getting started with computer vision on the Raspberry Pi
* Computer vision and IoT projects on the Pi
* Servos, PID, and controlling the Pi with computer vision
* Human activity, home surveillance, and facial applications
* Deep learning on the Raspberry Pi
* Fast, efficient deep learning with the Movidius NCS and
OpenVINO toolkit
* Self-driving car applications on the Raspberry Pi
* Tips, suggestions, and best practices when performing computer
vision and deep learning with the RPi

I also have chapters planned on the NVIDIA Jetson Nano and Google
Coral as well!

Additionally, I wanted to give you a heads up and let you know
that I'll be sending a few more emails than normal over the next
week:
* Thursday, April 4th: A sneak preview of the Kickstarter
campaign, including a demo video of what you'll find inside the
book.
* Friday, April 5th: The Table of Contents for Raspberry Pi for
Computer Vision. This book is practical and hands-on, giving you
the knowledge you need to bring CV and DL to embedded devices.
You don't want to miss this list of chapters!
* Monday, April 8th: The full list of Kickstarter
rewards (including early bird discounts and sales). You'll be
able to use this list to plan ahead for which reward tier you
want when the Kickstarter launches.
* Tuesday, April 9th: Please keep in mind this book is already
getting a lot of attention so there will be multiple people in
line for each reward level when the Kickstarter launches on
Wednesday, April 10th at 10AM EST. To help ensure you get the
reward tier you want, I'll be sharing my tips and suggestions you
can use to ensure you're first in line.

* Wednesday, April 10th: I'll email you the Kickstarter campaign
link you can use to claim your copy of RPi for CV, as well as the
additional discounts and sales!

I realize this is more emails than I would normally send on a
weekly or monthly basis. If you're honestly not interested in
supporting this book/myself, use the
following link to add yourself to the "do not contact" list ( http://t.dripemail2. ).

If you click the link above you'll still receive the normal
weekly blog post and email newsletter updates from me, but you'll
only receive a small number of Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision emails (one when the KS launches, another when it ends,
and maybe one or two in between).

But if you are as excited about the new RPi + CV book as I am, be
sure to keep an eye in your inbox for more info as Wednesday,
April 10th draws closer!

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief (very excited) PyImageSearcher

Glassdoor has the tools to help you land that perfect job
Welcome! Let's find your next job
Hi,

Wow, the Kickstarter launch date of Wednesday, April 10th is
approaching so fast!

I still have a ton of work left to do and I'm currently neck-deep
in Kickstarter campaign logistics, but I took a few minutes and
recorded this sneak preview of Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision just for you: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjAyNjYzNzA2MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC53aXN0aWEuY29tL21lZGlhcy9tZGp4am1vZmp2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjAyNjYzNzA2MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC53aXN0aWEuY29tL21lZGlhcy9tZGp4am1vZmp2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

The video is fairly short, clocking in at 5m56s, and
it's absolutely worth the watch, but if you don't have enough
time to watch it, you can read the gist below:

* 0m06s: I show an example of building a CV + IoT wildlife
camera. We'll be covering the exact implementation inside the
book.
* 0m29s: I discuss the Raspberry Pi, its compatibility with
cameras + computer vision libraries, and how we can use the Pi
for computer vision.

* 0m45: Can we write software that understand and take action
based on what the Pi "sees"? Absolutely, yes! And I'll show you
how through face recognition, footfall/traffic counter
applications, gesture recognition, deep learning on the Pi, and
much more!

* 1m01s: Regardless of whether you're an experienced computer
vision and deep learning practitioner or you're brand new to the
world of computer vision and image processing, this book will
help you build practical, real-world computer vision applications
on the Raspberry Pi.
* 1m16s: I provide a high level overview of the topics that will
be covered inside the RPi + CV book.
* 1m45s: Since this book covers such a large, diverse amount of
content, I've decided to break the book down into three volumes,
called "bundles". You'll be able to choose a bundle based on how
in-depth you want to study CV and DL on the Pi, which
projects/chapters interest you the most, along with your
particular budget.
* 2m50s: I'm a strong believer of learning by doing. You'll roll
up your sleeves, get your hands dirty in code, and build actual,
real-world projects.
* 3m03s: Demos of IoT wildlife monitoring, detecting tired
drivers behind the wheel, pan and tilt object tracking, and IoT
traffic/footfall counting.
* 3m41s: More demos, including hand gesture recognition, vehicle
detection and recognition, vehicle speed detection, multiple Pis
and deep learning, self-driving car applications, Movidius NCS
and OpenVINO, face recognition security camera, smart classroom
attendance system.
* The Kickstarter campaign will be going live on Wednesday, April
10th at 10AM EST— I hope to see you on the Kickstarter backer
list!

Like I said, if you have the time, the sneak preview video is
definitely worth the watch. ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjAyNjYzNzA2MiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vcHlpbWFnZXNlYXJjaC53aXN0aWEuY29tL21lZGlhcy9tZGp4am1vZmp2P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

I hope that you decide to support the Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision Kickstarter campaign on Wednesday, April 10th at 10AM
EST — if you're ready to bring CV and DL to embedded/IoT devices,
then this is the perfect book for you!

I'll email you tomorrow with the Table of Contents for Raspberry
Pi for Computer Vision— this is the big list of topics so you
don't want to miss tomorrow's email!

Until tomorrow,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief (really excited now) PyImageSearcher

Apply to Jobs Faster With One Simple Step
Hey there,

A couple of days ago ( http://t.dripemail2. ) I mentioned that on Wednesday, April 10th at 10AM EST I am
launching a Kickstarter for my new book, Raspberry Pi for
Computer Vision.

As you'll see later in this email, there is a huge amount of
content I'll be covering, so I've decided to break the book down
into three volumes called "bundles".

A bundle includes the eBook and source code for a given volume
(as well as a pre-configured Raspbian .img file with all the
computer vision + deep learning libraries you need
pre-installed).

Each bundle builds on top of the others and includes all content
from lower bundles. You should choose a bundle based on how
in-depth you want to study CV and DL on the Pi, which
projects/chapters interest you the most, along with your
particular budget:

* Hobbyist Bundle: A great fit if this is your first time working
with computer vision or the Raspberry Pi. Here you'll learn basic
computer vision algorithms that can easily be applied to the Pi.
You'll build hands-on applications including a wildlife
monitor/detector, home video surveillance, pan/tilt servo
tracking, and more!

* Hacker Bundle: Perfect for readers who want to learn more
advanced techniques, including deep learning, working with the
Movidius NCS, OpenVINO toolkit, and self-driving car
applications. You'll also learn my tips, suggestions, and best
practices when applying computer vision on the Raspberry Pi.
* Complete Bundle: The full Raspberry Pi and computer vision
experience. You'll have access to every chapter in the
book, video tutorials, a hardcopy of the text, and access to
my private community and forums for additional help and support.

The complete Table of Contents for each bundle is listed in the
next section.

*******************************
------- Hobbyist Bundle -------
*******************************

Image

The Hobbyist Bundle includes the following topics:

Working with the Raspberry Pi

* Why the Raspberry Pi?
* Configure your Raspberry Pi for computer vision + deep learning
(including all libraries, packages, etc.)
* Or, skip the install process and use my pre-configured Raspbian
.img file which comes with everything you need
pre-installed! Just flash the .img file and boot.
* Streamline your development process and learn how to optimally
write code on the Raspberry Pi (including suggested IDEs and
recommended settings/configurations)
* Access both your USB webcam and/or Raspberry Pi camera module
on the Pi
* Work with the NoIR camera module

* Learn how to utilize multiple cameras with the Raspberry Pi

Getting Started with Computer Vision on the Raspberry Pi

* Gain experience with OpenCV and your Raspberry Pi camera by
creating time lapse videos on the Pi
* Build an automatic bird feed monitor that detects when birds
are present
* Build an automatic prescription pill identification system (and
reduce the 1.2 million injuries and deaths each year that happen
due to taking the incorrect pill)
* Learn how to stream frames from a Raspberry Pi to your web
browser

Computer Vision and IoT projects with the Raspberry Pi

* Review hardware considerations and suggestions when using the
Raspberry Pi in IoT applications
* Learn how to work in low light conditions, including camera and
algorithm suggestions
* Build and deploy a remote wildlife monitor, capable of
detecting wildlife and saving clips of wildlife activity
* Learn how to automatically run your computer vision
applications on boot/reboot on the Pi
* Send text message (including messages with images and video) to
your phone from the Pi
* Create a vehicle traffic and pedestrian footfall counting
system capable of detecting and counting the number of vehicles
on a road/people entering and leaving an area

Servos and PID

* What’s a PID?
* Learn how to track faces and objects with pan/tilt servo
tracking

Human Activity and Home Surveillance

* Build a basic video surveillance system and detect when people
enter “unauthorized” zones
* Deploy your Raspberry Pi to vehicles and detect tired, drowsy
drivers (and sound an alarm to wake them up)
* Build an automatic people/footfall counter to count the number
of people entering and leaving a store, house, etc.

Tips, Suggestions, and Best Practices

* Learn about OpenCV optimizations, including OpenCL and how to
access all four cores of the Raspberry Pi, boosting your system
performance
* Discover my blueprint on how to design your own computer vision
+ Raspberry Pi applications for optimal performance

* Increase your FPS throughput rate using threading and
multiprocessing

*****************************
------- Hacker Bundle -------
*****************************

Image

The Hacker Bundle includes everything in the Hobbyist Bundle. It
also includes the following topics.

Advanced Computer Vision and IoT projects with the Pi

* Pipe frames from the Raspberry Pi camera to your laptop,
desktop, or cloud instance, process the frames, and then return
the results to the Pi

* Build a neighborhood vehicle speed monitor that detects cars,
estimates their speed, and logs driver activity
* Reduce package theft by automatically recognizing delivery
trucks and detecting package delivery

Advanced Human Activity and Facial Applications

* Extend your video surveillance system to include deep
learning-based object detection and annotated output video clips
* Track your family members and pets throughout the house using
multiple cameras and multiple Raspberry Pi’s

* Utilize the Raspberry Pi to perform gesture recognition

* Perform face recognition on the Raspberry Pi
* Create a smart classroom and automatic attendance
system capable of detecting which students are (and are not)
present

Deep Learning on the Raspberry Pi

* Learn how to perform deep learning on resource constrained
devices
* Utilize the Movidius NCS and OpenVINO for faster, more
efficient deep learning on the Raspberry Pi
* Perform object detection using the TinyYOLO object detector on
the Pi
* Utilize Single Shot Detectors (SSDs) on the Raspberry Pi
* Train and deploy a deep learning gesture recognition model on
your Pi
* Reduce package theft by training and deploying a deep learning
model to recognize delivery trucks

* Use deep learning and multiple Raspberry Pis to create a
network of “smart cameras”
* Review my guidelines and best practices on when to use the Pi
CPU, Movidius NCS, or stream frames to a more powerful system

Movidius NCS and OpenVINO

* Discover OpenVINO and how can it dramatically improve inference
time on a Raspberry Pi
* Learn how to configure and install OpenCV with OpenVINO support

* Configure the Movidius NCS development kit on your Raspberry Pi
* Classify images using deep learning and the Movidius NCS on
your Pi
* Perform object detection on the Movidius NCS to create a person
counter and tracker
* Create a face recognition system using the Movidius NCS on the
Raspberry Pi

Self-driving Car Applications and the Raspberry Pi

* Discover the GoPiGo3 and how it can facilitate studies in
self-driving cars with the Raspberry Pi
* Learn how to drive your GoPiGo3 with a Raspberry Pi
* Drive a course using the GoPiGo3 and Raspberry Pi
* Recognize traffic lights with the Raspberry Pi
* Drive to specific objects using the GoPiGo3 and a Raspberry Pi
* Create a line/lane follower with the Raspberry Pi

*******************************
------- Complete Bundle -------
*******************************

Image

The Complete Bundle includes everything in the Hobbyist
Bundle and Hacker Bundle.

In addition, it also includes:

* All additional bonus chapters, guides, and tutorials

* Video tutorials and walkthroughs for each chapter
* Access to my private Raspberry Pi and Computer Vision community
and forums

* A physical, hardcopy edition of the text delivered to your
doorstep

There you have it — the complete Table of Contents for Raspberry
Pi for Computer Vision. I hope after looking over this list
you're excited as I am!

I also have some secret bonus chapters that I'm keeping under
wraps until the Kickstarter launches. Stay tuned for this
details.

I'll be back on Monday with the complete list of Kickstarter
rewards, discounts, and sales. You'll be able to use this list to
plan which Kickstarter reward level you want to back.

Cheers,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief (can't hardly wait!) PyImageSearcher

P.S. Not interested in the RPi + CV book after reading the table
of contents? Don't want to hear about the book anymore? While I’m
certainly disappointed that you feel the book/big PyImageSearch
sale is not for you, I don’t want to be sending you RPi + CV book
emails if you’re genuinely not interested.

If you're honestly not interested in supporting this
book/myself, use the following link to
add yourself to the "do not contact" list. ( http://t.dripemail2. ) You'll still receive the normal weekly blog post and email
newsletter updates from me, but you'll only receive a small
number of Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision emails (one when the
KS launches, another when it ends, and maybe one or two in
between).

---------------------
To make sure you keep getting these emails, please add
adrian@pyimagesearch.com to your address book or whitelist us. Want out of
the loop? <a href="http://t.dripemail2.">Unsubscribe</a>.
Our postal address: PO Box 17598 #17900, Baltimore, MD 21297-1598

Are You Paid Fairly?
Bangladesh Insight | Mar 28, 2019

http://albd.org

April 07, 2019 | Issue 214

NEWSLETTER

https://www.thedailystar.net/world/news/bangladesh-top-5-growing-economy-wb-1724815

Bangladesh in top 5 growing economy: World Bank https://www.thedailystar.net/world/news/bangladesh-top-5-growing-economy-wb-1724815

Bangladesh is among the five fastest growing economies in the world, World Bank, or WB, has said. The outlook was reflected in a new World Bank report titled ‘The Bangladesh Development Update April 2019: Towards Regulatory Predictability’, published recently. This growth, has been attributed to stable macro and export-oriented industry-led growth, it said in the report. It said the growth was caused by manufacturing, construction and a bumper crop harvest, coupled with private consumption, remittance and rural income growth. The report added, regulatory predictability will drive the growth further up. 

Bangladesh’s GDP growth to scale 8%in FY19, says ADB https://bdnews24.com/economy/2019/04/03/bangladeshs-gdp-growth-to-scale-8in-fy19-says-adb

https://bdnews24.com/economy/2019/04/03/bangladeshs-gdp-growth-to-scale-8in-fy19-says-adb

Bangladesh’s GDP growth is set to hit 8 percent at the end of current fiscal based on the continuing positive trend in exports and public investments, the Asian Development Bank, or ADB, has said. The ADB makes the prediction in its annual publication titled ‘Asian Development Outlook 2019’, or ADO 2019, after analysing the state of the Bangladeshi economy. According to the report, the GDP of Bangladesh is expected to grow by 8 percent in 2019-2020 with robust private consumption, increased public investment, strong export performance, and expansion in industries. Under the able leadership of Bangladesh Premier, the country’s GDP growth hit 7.86% in the past fiscal year while the per capita income soared to $1,751.								

HPM lauded for Bangladesh economic growth http://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/381509/2019/03/31/PM-lauded-for-Bangladesh-economic-growth

http://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/381509/2019/03/31/PM-lauded-for-Bangladesh-economic-growth

Asian leaders lauded Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina’s efficient leadership in achieving unprecedented economic growth, establishing good governance and fostering global peace. They made the recognition while addressing an annual conference of BOAO Forum for Asia (BFA) held in Hainan province of China. Honourable Prime Minister of China Li Keqiang, Honourable former Secretary General of United Nations Ban Ki-Moon and former Bangladesh Communication and ICT Minister Syed Abul Hossain attended the conference. Ban Ki-Moon highly appreciated the role of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in putting an end to terrorism in Bangladesh and providing food and shelter for Rohingya refugees from Myanmar.

HPM opens, lays foundation stones of 24 economic zones https://www.thedailystar.net/country/economic-zones-in-bangladesh-pm-sheikh-hasina-opens-lays-foundation-stones-1724308

https://www.thedailystar.net/country/economic-zones-in-bangladesh-pm-sheikh-hasina-opens-lays-foundation-stones-1724308

HPM Sheikh Hasina inaugurated and laid foundation stones of 65 uplift schemes including 24 economic zones, opening up a new horizon in industrialization and employment for country’s overall development. The premier also laid foundation stones of 13 economic zones and works of five development projects under the initiative of BEZA (Bangladesh Economic Zones Authority). The premier asked the businessmen not to damage arable land while setting up industries. In this context, she said the government will fix the places for setting up mill and factories to save the crop land as the country is mainly driven by agriculture and opined that there is no alternative http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/first-page/11-economic-zones-open-for-setting-up-industries-1554314203 of going for industrialisation for overall development. 

Remittance up 10.28% https://www.thedailystar.net/business/news/remittance-1028pc-1723702

https://www.thedailystar.net/business/news/remittance-1028pc-1723702

Inward remittances edged up 10.28% year-on-year to $11.87 billion in nine months to March this year thanks to the steady depreciation of the taka against the US dollar. Majority of the banks have taken steps to boost foreign exchanges because of their higher import payments than export earnings. The central bank has recently taken a number of initiatives to prevent transaction through the 'hundi', an illegal cross-border channel to settle transaction among clients, giving a boost to the remittance inflow. In March, remittances increased 12.17 % year-on-year to $1.45 billion.

Bangladesh makes 26 pledges to UN Peacekeeping operations https://www.thedailystar.net/city/news/bangladesh-makes-26-pledges-un-peacekeeping-operations-1722766

https://www.thedailystar.net/city/news/bangladesh-makes-26-pledges-un-peacekeeping-operations-1722766

Bangladesh has made 26 pledges to the United Nations Peacekeeping operations at the 2019 United Nations Peacekeeping Ministerial meeting last week. “To meet the UN requirements, Bangladesh has pledged 26 Peacekeeping Capability Readiness System (PCRS) components, including nine from Army, six from Navy, three from Air Force and eight from police,” said State Minister for Foreign Affairs Md Shahriar Alam. In addition, Bangladesh has also pledged a unit for operational-level Unmanned Aerial Surveillance (UAS), in partnership with the United States, the state minister added. The state minister said Bangladesh has been supportive to Women, Peace and Security (WPS) Agenda of the UN since the adoption of Security Council Resolution 1325.

Bangladesh commits to global initiative on decent jobs for youth https://www.thedailystar.net/business/news/bangladesh-commits-global-initiative-decent-jobs-youth-1721797

https://www.thedailystar.net/business/news/bangladesh-commits-global-initiative-decent-jobs-youth-1721797

Bangladesh is the first country in Asia and the Pacific region to commit to the global initiative on decent jobs for youth, the International Labour Organisation (ILO) said in a statement. The Decent Jobs for Youth is a global, multi-stakeholder initiative that brings together governments, social partners, the private sector and youth and civil society organisations to scale up action and impact on youth employment worldwide. According to media reports, Access to Information (a2i) is the flagship programme of the Bangladesh government's digital agenda pledged to train 250,000 Bangladeshi youth on digital skills and to deliver 340,200 http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/trade-market/bd-to-train-250000-youths-on-digital-skills-1553787976 apprenticeships by 2023. 

Matarbari deep-sea port to outshine Asian peers http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/last-page/matarbari-deep-sea-port-to-outshine-asian-peers-1553793093

http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/last-page/matarbari-deep-sea-port-to-outshine-asian-peers-1553793093

The Matarbari deep-sea port will have the highest water draft against similar facilities in Asia. The first phase of the port is expected to be completed by 2023 when one jetty for handling containers and one for multipurpose use will be ready. A number of media reports, quoted officials as saying, this port will have 18.7-metre deep draft and will be able to accommodate container vessels of 8,200 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent unit) and bulk carriers of nearly 70,000 deadweight tonnage (DWT). The port will be connected to the national highway and also have access to Chattogram and Cox's Bazar. After the completion of the final stage by 2035, the port will have the capacity to handle 4.8 million TEUs of containers and 16 to 38 million tonnes of bulk cargos. 

WB to provide $100m to upgrade four city areas http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/trade-market/wb-to-provide-100m-to-upgrade-four-city-areas-1554058895

http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/trade-market/wb-to-provide-100m-to-upgrade-four-city-areas-1554058895

The World Bank has approved $100.5 million to improve public spaces and urban services in four neighbourhoods under the Dhaka South City Corporation. The Dhaka City Neighboorhood Upgrading Project will benefit about a million residents. It will especially cater to the needs of women, youths, elderly and disabled, who often refrain from using public amenities. Under this project, livability of the selected areas will be enhanced by improving open public spaces such as parks, playgrounds, waterfronts, streets, sidewalks, and public buildings such as community centres. 

Country to have 13266 MW power more in next few years http://www.bssnews.net/?p=189515

http://www.bssnews.net/?p=189515

In a major boost to power sector, the country is going to have 13,266 megawatts power more between 2020 and 2026 as setting up of some 53 power stations is underway. The under construction 53 power stations with a generation capacity of 13,266 MW will be commissioned between 2020 and 2026, while the present government set up 102 power plants during the last ten years raising the generation capacity to 21,169 MW. A master-plan has been put in place, particularly the poor and vulnerable communities, to generate 24,000-MW electricity by 2021, 40,000-MW by 2030 and 60,000-MW by 2041, to improve the livelihood of all sections of the people. 

201 crop varieties, 205 crop technologies invented http://www.bssnews.net/?p=190107#acpwd-190107

http://www.bssnews.net/?p=190107#acpwd-190107

Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute (BARI) has developed 201 high-yielding variety (HYV) and hybrid crops and 250 crop management technology during the last 10 years. The crops include wheat, maize, potato, pulse, oil-seed, vegetables, flower and spices. On the back of a raft of measures on the part of the government, Bangladesh has now occupied 2nd position in jute production, 3rd in vegetables, 4th in paddy, 7th in mango, 8th in potato and guava and 10th in food grains production in the world.

New Course: Learn C# ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-c-sharp?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_08_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

C# is an extremely powerful, versatile programming language that is named after the musical symbol sharp, indicating it is a level above C++. But don’t take our word for it—meet developers Nada, Harley, and Hayden who work in C# every day—they'll tell you why you should learn the language now.

 

 

 

 

Nada

 

So, why should I learn C#?

 

C# is not only a powerful programming language but is also great for beginner coders! Learning C# teaches object oriented programming features like polymorphism and inheritance while also exposing new coders to complex data structures. The language is also versatile, meaning it can be used to build applications in a variety of environments such as Windows desktop, the web, and the blockchain. If you need even more reason, learning C# opens the door to many career opportunities since thousands of companies use C# to power their services.

 

 

 

 

Harley

 

How do you use C# in your day to day?

 

I am the engineer behind Author Analytics for Microsoft Sway. This system is mostly made up of C# for handling and processing data. We have REST API endpoints that clients can call to submit data or to fetch analytics reports on the Sways that they have created. My day-to-day uses of C# consist of debugging these systems, adding new ways of processing data and analyzing performance.

 

 

 

 

Hayden

 

What's your top tip for learning a new language?

 

Come up with a project you can get passionate about building. Once you have something you really want to build, you'll be driven to learn all of what you need to know to make it a reality. This is what keeps me going whenever I get frustrated learning some new language or framework or technology. And it's way more motivating if you can see small parts of your complete vision come together as you learn more!

 

 

 

 

 

If you want to hear more from Nada, Harley, Hayden, and other amazing C# developers we interviewed for this week’s course release, check out our blog ( https://news.codecademy.com/why-learn-c-sharp-ask-developer/ ). Banglalink is hiring in Dhaka (Bangladesh). Apply Now.
Hi,

Inside today's brand new tutorial you will learn how to utilize
the OpenVINO toolkit with OpenCV for faster deep learning
inference on the Raspberry Pi: ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MTQ2OTg2OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMDgvb3BlbnZpbm8tb3BlbmN2LWFuZC1tb3ZpZGl1cy1uY3Mtb24tdGhlLXJhc3BiZXJyeS1waT9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Image ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MTQ2OTg2OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMDgvb3BlbnZpbm8tb3BlbmN2LWFuZC1tb3ZpZGl1cy1uY3Mtb24tdGhlLXJhc3BiZXJyeS1waT9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Raspberry Pis are great — I love the quality hardware and the
supportive community built around the device.

That said, for deep learning, the current Raspberry Pi hardware
is inherently resource-constrained and you’ll be lucky to get
more than a few FPS (using the RPi CPU alone) out of most
state-of-the-art models (especially object detection and
instance/semantic segmentation).

Since 2017, the Movidius team has been hard at work on their
Myriad processors and their consumer grade USB deep learning
sticks.

The first version of the API that came with the sticks worked
well and demonstrated the power of the Myriad, but left a lot to
be desired.

Then, the Movidius APIv2 was released and welcomed by the
Movidius + Raspberry Pi community. It was easier/more reliable
than the APIV1 but had its fair share of issues as well.

But now, it’s become easier than ever to work with the Movidius
NCS, especially with OpenCV.

Meet OpenVINO, an Intel library for hardware optimized computer
vision designed to replace the V1 and V2 APIs.

OpenVINO is extremely simple to use — just set the target
processor (a single function call) and let OpenVINO optimized
OpenCV handle the rest.

But the question remains:

"How can I install OpenVINO on the Raspberry Pi? How do I get up
and running?"

Today we’ll learn just that along with a practical object
detection demo (spoiler alert: it is dead simple to use the
Movidius coprocessor now).

To learn how to install OpenVINO on the Raspberry Pi (and perform
object detection with the Movidius Neural Compute Stick), just
click here follow the full tutorial! ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MTQ2OTg2OCIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMDgvb3BlbnZpbm8tb3BlbmN2LWFuZC1tb3ZpZGl1cy1uY3Mtb24tdGhlLXJhc3BiZXJyeS1waT9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Keep an eye on your inbox. In ~2 hours I'll be sending you
another email with more details on the Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision Kickstarter campaign, including the complete list of
Kickstarter rewards, discounts, and sales. You'll be able to use
this list to plan which Kickstarter reward level you want to back
when the Kickstarter launches on Wednesday at 10AM EDT.

See you in a couple hours!

OpenVINO, OpenCV, and Movidius NCS on the Raspberry Pi
Hi,

It's been quite the busy week! Since last Wednesday I have:

* Announced the Kickstarter campaign ( http://t.dripemail2. ) for Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision

* Given you a sneak preview ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMDQvc25lYWstcHJldmlldy1yYXNwYmVycnktcGktZm9yLWNvbXB1dGVyLXZpc2lvbi8_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) of the book
* Shared the Table of Contents ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMDUvdGFibGUtb2YtY29udGVudHMtcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24vP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 )

Today I am super excited to share with you the
finalized Kickstarter reward levels (in "Kickstarter terminology"
a "reward" is the RPi + CV book bundle and any additional
add-ons, like my other books/courses, you wish to purchase at the
discounted rate).

This reward list is exclusive to PyImageSearch readers like
yourself and will not be publicly available until the Kickstarter
campaign launches on Wednesday, April 10th at 10AM EDT.

So, why am I sharing this reward list to you now?

To give you the advantage, of course!

When the Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision Kickstarter campaign
launches on Wednesday, there will be 1,000s of PyImageSearch
readers (not to mention, other Kickstarter users) reading the
campaign page and trying to decide which reward to select.

The problem is that if you wait too long to decide on which
reward level you want, you might miss out on it!

* Throughout the entire Kickstarter campaign I'll be
offering 15-25% OFF all reward tiers...
* ...but for the first 10 minutes of the Kickstarter campaign
I'll be increasing the discount to a massive 30-35% OFF every
reward tier.
* There will be no exceptions on the 10 minute doorbuster
discount. Once the clock strikes 10:10AM EDT, I'm taking down the
30-35% discount

But 10 minutes can go by quick so you'll need to act FAST!

How quickly you ask?

I went back and ran the numbers from previous big product
sales/launches in PyImageSearch history to give you an idea:
* Four years ago I offered 10 hand-signed editions of Practical
Python and OpenCV on a first-come, first serve basis — all 10
were sold out in exactly 17 minutes.

* Three years ago I offered 10 hand-signed editions and 10 (free)
Raspberry Pi 3's — all 10 sold out in 5 minutes.

* Two years ago I offered 10 NVIDIA Jetson TX2s to the first 10
readers who purchased my deep learning book — all 10 of the TX2s
were claimed in 2 minutes, 16 seconds.

* And last year, there were so many readers on the PyImageSearch
blog eagerly waiting for the launch of the Black Friday sale that
the server went down for a few minutes (we won't have that issue
with the Kickstarter servers though!)

As you can see, these types of sales and discounts have a history
of being highly competitive and often sell out quickly.

Tomorrow I'll send you an email with some tips and tricks to help
ensure you're at the front of the line when the Kickstarter
launches, but for the time being, let's take a look at the
Kickstarter rewards.

Be sure to plan ahead and pick out the reward you want! Remember,
other PyImageSearch readers and Kickstarter users will be trying
to claim these spots too!

*******************
Kickstarter Rewards
*******************

The main reward for this Kickstarter is the Raspberry Pi for
Computer Vision eBook offered at a heavily discounted rate.

These rates are exclusive to the Kickstarter campaign and
will not be available once Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision officially publishes.

Since the book is going to cover so much content, I have broken
down the book into three volumes called bundles:

* Hobbyist Bundle
* Hacker Bundle
* Complete Bundle

You can decide which bundle is most appropriate for you based on:

* How in-depth you would like to study computer vision and deep
learning on the Raspberry Pi.
* Which projects/chapters in the book interest you the most.
* Your particular budget.
* Whether you would like any add-ons, including Practical Python
and OpenCV ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3ByYWN0aWNhbC1weXRob24tb3BlbmN2Lz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ), Deep
Learning for Computer Vision with Python ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL2RlZXAtbGVhcm5pbmctY29tcHV0ZXItdmlzaW9uLXB5dGhvbi1ib29rLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ), or the PyImageSearch Gurus course ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ). All three
of these add-ons will help you get up to speed with computer
vision and deep learning before you start applying them to the
Pi. I highly recommend at least one of the add-ons if you are new
to computer vision or deep learning.

Each Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision bundle includes:

* The eBook files in PDF, .mobi, and .epub format.
* All source code listings, datasets, and pre-trained models so
you can run the examples out-of-the-box.
* A downloadable pre-configured Raspbian .img file with Python,
OpenCV, and all the necessary machine learning + deep learning
libraries you need pre-installed. No need to configure your Pi,
just flash the .img file to your SD card and boot — you'll be up
and running in minutes!

The Complete Bundle includes additional items, including:

* All extra bonus chapters (which will be announced during the
Kickstarter campaign)
* Video tutorials and walkthroughs for each chapter in the book
* Access to private Raspberry Pi + computer vision community
forums, enabling you to better connect with me and other readers,
and get faster, more detailed answers to your questions

* A hardcopy edition of the book delivered to your doorstep

Again, please note that the Complete Bundle is the only bundle to
include the video tutorials, private community forums, and
physical, hardcopy edition of the text.

After choosing a bundle for Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision, you
should decide whether you would like any add-ons to help start or
level-up your computer vision + deep learning
education before you dive into the Pi book.

I highly recommend that you choose at least one of these add-ons
to make the most out of the Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision to
enhance your existing knowledge.

I've included the image below to describe what topics are covered
in each add-on:

Image

Add-on #2: PyImageSearch Gurus Course
-------------------------------------

Image

The PyImageSearch Gurus course ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) is similar
to a college-level survey course on computer vision, but far more
detailed and much more hands-on and practical.

Inside the PyImageSearch Gurus course you'll find:
* An actionable, real-world course on computer vision and OpenCV
* The most comprehensive computer vision education online today,
including 13 modules broken out into 168 lessons with over 2,161
pages of content

* A community of like-minded developers, researchers, and
students just like yourself, who are eager to study computer
vision.

If you're a regular reader of the PyImageSearch blog, you know
that I don't discount the PyImageSearch Gurus course (normally a
one-time payment of $995).

You'll be getting a HUGE deal by going with any reward that
includes this course (the cost of Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision is essentially FREE once you build in the price of the
Gurus course). You can learn more about the PyImageSearch Gurus
course here ( http://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA3MzU5MzI5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3B5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2gtZ3VydXMvP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ).

Bottom Line: You should choose the PyImageSearch Gurus course
add-on if you want to study computer vision in-depth, enabling
you to better develop computer vision applications for your
Raspberry Pi.

Image

Whether this is the first time you've worked with machine
learning and neural networks or you're already a seasoned deep
learning practitioner, Deep Learning for Computer Vision with
Python is engineered from the ground up to help you reach expert
status.

As James, a PyImageSearch reader says:

"By far, one of the most well-written, informative books that
I've read on the subject. Adrian takes months, perhaps even
years, of research via trial and error, and condenses it into a
single, information-packed book!" — James

Bottom Line: You should go with this add-on if you have any
interest in studying deep learning. This book has helped 1,000s
of developers, researchers, and students master deep learning for
computer vision. The knowledge in this book can be directly
applied to your own computer vision + deep learning projects on
the Pi. Best of all, Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision is
essentially FREE once you build in the price of the deep learning
book.

Hi,

I just wanted to send you a quick reminder that tomorrow
(Wednesday, April 10th) at 10AM EDT the Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision Kickstarter will launch.

If you haven't had a chance to look at the Kickstarter sale and
discount list ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA4NzA1MDQ5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tL3RoZS1maW5hbGl6ZWQtcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24td2l0aC1weXRob24ta2lja3N0YXJ0ZXItcmV3YXJkcy1saXN0P19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) yet, you'll definitely want to plan out some time later today
to take a look.

Not only does the Kickstarter campaign include discounts on the
upcoming RPi + CV book, but it also includes 15-25% discounts and
sales on my other books/courses, including:

* Practical Python and OpenCV
* Deep Learning for Computer Vision with Python
* PyImageSearch Gurus course

But I'm not stopping there...

* To make this a true doorbuster sale I'm going to increase the
discount from 15-25% to 30-35% OFF for a limited time.

* If you purchase in the first 10 minutes of the sale (April 10th
from 10:00AM-10:10AM EDT) I'm increasing the discount to 30-35%
OFF!
* There will be no exceptions on the doorbuster discount. Once
the clock strikes 10:10AM EDT, I'm taking down the 30-35%
discount.

I rarely offer these types of sales and discounts — they have a
history of being a HUGE deal on the PyImageSearch blog and
community. And more to the point, they are highly competitive and
often sell out quickly:

* Four years ago I offered 10 hand-signed editions of Practical
Python and OpenCV on a first-come, first serve basis — all 10
were sold out in exactly 17 minutes.

* Three years ago I offered 10 hand-signed editions and 10 (free)
Raspberry Pi 3's — all 10 sold out in 5 minutes.

* Two years ago I offered 10 NVIDIA Jetson TX2s to the first 10
readers who purchased my deep learning book — all 10 of the TX2s
were claimed in 2 minutes, 16 seconds.

* And last year, there were so many readers on the PyImageSearch
blog eagerly waiting for the launch of the Black Friday sale that
the server went down for a few minutes (we won't have that issue
with the Kickstarter servers though!)

For the RPi + CV Kickstarter I'm going to level the playing field
so no matter where in the world you live and no matter how good
your internet connection is (or isn't), you have a full 10
minutes to take advantage of the 35% OFF discount.

But 10 minutes can go by quick so you'll need to act FAST!

To make sure you're able to take advantage of the 35% OFF
doorbuster "early bird" discount I suggest you:

* If you don't already have a Kickstarter account, make sure you
create an account ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA4NzA1MDQ5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9zaWdudXA_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) before Wednesday. Having to go through the registration process
of typing in your name, email address, password etc. will eat up
valuable time. Keep in mind you'll only have 10 minutes to select
your reward and purchase at the super discounted rate. Creating
account now will save you valuable time (and help ensure you get
the reward tier and discount you want).
* Set an alarm on your phone and desktop for Wednesday, April
10th at 10:00AM EDT (in fact, I would recommend setting your
alarm a few minutes early to ensure you don't miss out on the
sale). You can use the following link ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA4NzA1MDQ5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnRpbWVhbmRkYXRlLmNvbS93b3JsZGNsb2NrL2NvbnZlcnRlci5odG1sP2lzbz0yMDE5MDQxMFQxNDAwMDBcdTAwMjZwMT0xNzlcdTAwMjZwMj0xMzZcdTAwMjZwMz0xNzZcdTAwMjZfX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ) to convert Wednesday, April 10th at 10AM EDT to your own
timezone— just use the "Add Another City" field to add your
country/timezone.
* Start refreshing your inbox for the announcement email as soon
as your alarm goes off.

* Keep refreshing my Kickstarter profile page ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA4NzA1MDQ5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9wcm9maWxlL2FkcmlhbnJvc2Vicm9jay9jcmVhdGVkP19fcz1paHlubjZxYm1meTYxYXF0emdwciJ9 ) (which lists all projects I've ever created on Kickstarter)
until you see the Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision link appear
(this is helpful just in case there is a delay in your email
provider delivering the announcement email to your inbox). Then,
click on the RPi for CV link and select the reward tier you want
to purchase.
* Pay attention to my Twitter feed ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjA4NzA1MDQ5OSIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vdHdpdHRlci5jb20vUHlJbWFnZVNlYXJjaD9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ ), where I'll also be posting a
link to the Kickstarter.

See you tomorrow at 10:00AM EDT.

the doorbuster early bird sale so don't miss it...

Hiring now: Augmedix, NewsCred, Banglalink, Veon.
Augmedix is hiring in Dhaka (Bangladesh). Apply Now.
As a writer, it's rare that I am at a loss for words. But right
now I am.

Yesterday I launched a Kickstarter campaign to fund the creation
of my new book, Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision. ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjExNzU3NjExMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9wcm9qZWN0cy9hZHJpYW5yb3NlYnJvY2svcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24tZWJvb2s_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

The campaign itself was funded in less than 5 seconds and is
currently over 4,200% funded.

The immense amount of gratitude, thankfulness, and appreciation I
feel right now is truthfully overwhelming in the best possible
way, making it hard for me to explain how lucky I feel to be
creating this book for you.

It's honestly a privilege and an honor, one I don't take lightly.
From the bottom of my heart — thank you.

******************************************************
So, what's next for the book and Kickstarter campaign?
******************************************************

When a Kickstarter campaign hits its initial funding target, the
creator often defines funding goals that are higher than the
original target. The creator promises that if the higher funding
goals are reached then they will deliver the "bonuses" to the
original product. Kickstarter calls these targets "stretch
goals".

For the Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision Kickstarter our stretch
goals are going to be additional bonus chapters for the book.

The bonus chapters were determined based on the numerous emails
and comments I have received prior and during the Kickstarter
campaign.

Take a look at the stretch goals/additional bonus chapters below:

* Face recognition with the Movidius NCS. State-of-the-art face
detection + recognition methods struggle to obtain more than a
few FPS on the RPi. In this set of bonus chapters you will learn
how to utilize the Movidius NCS for face recognition, enabling
true real-time performance on your Raspberry Pi! These chapters
will be part of the Hacker Bundle.

* Train custom Caffe + TensorFlow models for the NCS. The
majority of tutorials you'll find today on the Movidius will only
show you how to use pre-trained models on the NCS. I will teach
you how to train your own Caffe/TensorFlow models on your custom
datasets and then deploy the model to the RPi + NCS. The custom
NCS model chapters will be included in the Complete Bundle.

* TensorFlow Lite and Human Pose Estimation. TensorFlow Lite is a
lightweight, super optimized version of TF for mobile and
embedded devices. In these bonus chapters you'll learn how to (1)
train your own models using TF Lite, (2) convert existing models
to TF Lite format, (3) deploy fast, highly optimized TF Lite
models the Pi, and finally, (4) perform human pose estimation
using TF Lite. All TF Lite chapters will be part of the Complete
Bundle.

* Build CV and DL apps with the Google Coral Edge TPU USB
Accelerator. Google has released "Coral", a super fast, "no
internet required" dev board and USB accelerator (similar to the
Movidus NCS) that enables deep learning practitioners to deploy
their models "on the edge" and "closer to the data". Building on
the previous stretch goal of using TF Lite, this set of bonus
chapters will show you how to configure your Google Coral,
perform image classification and object detection, and even
deploy your own custom models to the Coral Edge TPU! I will be
covering Google Coral in the Complete Bundle.

* NVIDIA Jetson Nano hands-on tutorials and guides. Just a few
weeks ago, NVIDIA released the Jetson Nano, what many consider to
be the "$99 Raspberry Pi for AI". The Nano is small but super
powerful, containing a 128-core Maxwell GPU and quad core 1.43
GHz processor. The Nano enables you to run multiple deep neural
networks on a single board, including real-time image
classification, object detection, segmentation, and more! These
chapters will teach you how to configure your Nano, perform image
classification/object detection, and run your own custom models
on the Nano! All Jetson Nano chapters will be part of
the Complete Bundle.

Where possible, all code examples in the book will be compatible
with the Raspberry Pi, Google Coral, and NVIDIA Jetson Nano as
well!

Do these chapters sound interesting to you?

If so, definitely consider getting in on the action and
supporting this Kickstarter campaign. ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjExNzU3NjExMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9wcm9qZWN0cy9hZHJpYW5yb3NlYnJvY2svcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24tZWJvb2s_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

By pre-ordering your copy of Raspberry Pi for Computer
Vision now, you'll be receiving a significant discount compared
to when the book is publicly released (plus, I'm offering some
pretty great discounts on my existing books and courses as well!)

Over 750 readers have already pre-ordered — are you next? ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjExNzU3NjExMiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9wcm9qZWN0cy9hZHJpYW5yb3NlYnJvY2svcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24tZWJvb2s_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Cheers,

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

Monday Course Drop ( https://www.codecademy.com/catalog/subject/all?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_15_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=header_img )

 

 

New Course: Learn CircuitPython ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-circuitpython?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_4_15_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

Since 2011, Codecademy has helped teach millions of people technology skills they need to upgrade their careers. Today, we are expanding our reach with our first-ever hardware programming course, Learn CircuitPython, in partnership with Adafruit Industries. Our new course introduces you to the world of hardware and electronics with the help of Adafruit’s beginner-friendly circuit board, Circuit Playground Express—get your own shipped to you for free. Read on for details.

 

Customize your website with PHP. ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-circuitpython?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_4_15_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=screenshot_img )
Circuit Playground Express.

 

Hardware programming has a reputation for being difficult to get started and intimidating. But through this innovative partnership with Adafruit, we’ve managed to give you all the tools you need to build your own hardware projects.

 

What is hardware programming exactly?
The term hardware programming is an umbrella term that relates to controlling electronic devices spanning smartphones, satellites, to blue-tooth headsets. Nearly everything in the digital world we physically touch has a hardware component to it. All these different pieces of hardware require programming which is where CircuitPython comes into play.

 

CircuitPython is a Python-based language designed specifically for programming hardware, giving you the ability to create programs that interact with hardware sensors and other external components. That’s what makes learning and building your own hardware so exciting: you can make custom applications useful to your everyday life.

 

What can you build with a Circuit Playground Express?
The real question is, “What can’t you do?” This device comes equipped with LED lights, temperature/light/motion sensors, audio speaker, memory, and ability to connect to other hardware (like circuit boards or your computer). You’ll put all of these components to use in our new Learn CircuitPython course.

 

Through our projects, we will teach you how to program a bike light, measure moisture levels in your house plant, and make music with fruits (it’s gonna be bananas). Not convinced? Check out our livestream today at 1:30pm EST ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szsYLKicTzo&feature=youtu.be )—our curriculum developer Sonny will walk through the bike light project.

 

Start Now ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-circuitpython?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_04_15_19_a&utm_medium=email&utm_content=inline_link )

Bonus Video: Working with Code Written by Someone Else ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdQtww8ZfEw&feature=youtu.be )
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The further you get in your coding journey, the more complex projects you'll do, and the more likely you are to work with code written by someone else. Transitioning from being 100% DIY writing your own things from scratch to working as part of a team or as a successor to a project started by others can be really hard. We have ten tips that could save you a headache when the time comes.
Follow Along ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdQtww8ZfEw&feature=youtu.be )

Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:

1. Learn how to solve common developer job interview algorithm challenges in this free course from a professional developer interview coach (5 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/master-your-coding-interview

2. Neural networks are at the core of what we call "Artificial Intelligence." Learn about convolutional and recurrent neural networks, and deep learning in this free course (4 hour watch): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-deep-neural-networks-work

3. How one developer used Python to analyze Game of Thrones (19 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/503a96028ce6

4. What I wish I knew when I started to work with React.js (5 minute read): https://medium.freecodecamp.org/3ba36107fd13

5. 3 years ago, Shawn walked away from a US $350,000/year job in finance to learn to code with freeCodeCamp. Today he's a developer at Netlify, and he runs the official ReactJS subreddit. I interviewed him about his coding journey (2 hour listen): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/shawn-wang-podcast-interview

http://albd.org

April 21, 2019 | Issue 216

NEWSLETTER

http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/last-page/bangladesh-bhutan-agree-on-dfqf-access-of-few-goods-1555175192

Bhutan Bangladesh relations reach new heights http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/last-page/bangladesh-bhutan-agree-on-dfqf-access-of-few-goods-1555175192

During a recent visit to Bangladesh, Honourable Prime Minister of Bhutan Dr Lotay Tshering focused on exploring more connectivity and business opportunities between Dhaka and Thimphu. According to a joint statement on the state visit, the two premiers welcomed the signing of the standard of procedure (SOP) for the operationalisation of the MoU http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/first-page/dhaka-thimphu-to-sign-transit-agreement-soon-1555350134 on the 'Use of Inland Waterways for Transportation of Bilateral Trade and Transit Cargoes http://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/385168/2019/04/14/Bangladesh-Bhutan-agree-on-quotafree-market-access-' between Bangladesh and Bhutan. Moreover, both countries viewed that the proposed trilateral cooperation with India in hydroelectric power can further strengthen https://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/385432/Teamwork-on-hydropower-tomitigate-climate-challenges regional cooperation, encourage the use of renewable energy and mitigate climate change challenges. 

Bangladesh received $12b remittance in 9 months https://www.thedailystar.net/city/news/bangladesh-received-12b-remittance-9-months-1729273

https://www.thedailystar.net/city/news/bangladesh-received-12b-remittance-9-months-1729273

Bangladeshi expatriates sent nearly US $12 billion remittance in the first nine months of the current fiscal 2018-19 -- highest in the last three years. During the July-March period in the current fiscal, they had sent $11.87 billion, 10.30 percent higher than the amount received in the corresponding period of the preceding fiscal. According to Bangladesh Bank, the country received $10.76 billion remittance during July-March period of 2017-18 financial year while $9.19 billion in 2016-17, $11.06 billion in 2015-16 and $11.26 billion in 2014-15. 								

Footwear exports fetch $651m in 9 months https://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/384953/2019/04/13/Footwear-exports-fetch-651m-in-9-months

https://www.daily-sun.com/printversion/details/384953/2019/04/13/Footwear-exports-fetch-651m-in-9-months

Footwear sector is strengthening its footing in the international market despite the negative growth of Bangladeshi leather products in export markets. Footwear exports totalled $651 million in the last nine months of the current FY 2018-19, which is around 10 per cent higher than the same period last fiscal. The country’s footwear industry rapidly grew in the past decade. Exports soared from $68 million in 2004 to $870 million in FY 2017-18. This year’s target for footwear exports has been fixed at $860 million.

Bangladesh observes Mujibnagar Day to mark formation of first government https://www.thedailystar.net/backpage/news/mujibnagar-day-observed-1731403

https://www.thedailystar.net/backpage/news/mujibnagar-day-observed-1731403

Tributes to Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman have poured in as Bangladesh observes the historic Mujibnagar Day, commemorating the formation of the country's provisional government in Meherpur in 1971. On the same day in 1971, the provisional Mujibnagar Government was constituted in Meherpur’s Baidyanathtala, which was later renamed as Mujibnagar. The village witnessed the ceremonial formation of the provisional government and millions of freedom loving people listened to the announcement over radio. The Mujibnagar Government was constituted with Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman as the president, Syed Nazul Islam as acting president, and Tajuddin Ahmed as the prime minister. 

Japan set to give largest-ever loan to BD for five ongoing projects http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/last-page/japan-set-to-give-largest-ever-loan-to-bd-for-five-ongoing-projects-1555523135

http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/last-page/japan-set-to-give-largest-ever-loan-to-bd-for-five-ongoing-projects-1555523135

Japan is set to provide the highest-ever amount of loan to Bangladesh under a new loan package to facilitate implementation of five large ongoing projects in the port, communications, and energy and power sectors. Officials said a negotiation team of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) has confirmed the funding for the five projects under its 40th Official Development Assistance (ODA). Of the projects, Matarbari port development project will get the first tranche of the loan amount, while Matarbari power project will get fifth tranche of the total loan commitment. The Second tranche of loan will be provided for both MRT Line-1 and FDI promotion projects, which will facilitate setting up of the second corridor of metro-rail in the city and a special economic zone (SEZ) of Japan respectively.

BD's aviation market doubles in seven years http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/trade-market/bds-aviation-market-doubles-in-seven-years-1555349385

http://today.thefinancialexpress.com.bd/public/trade-market/bds-aviation-market-doubles-in-seven-years-1555349385

The aviation market of Bangladesh doubled over the last seven years to 2017 and is expected to grow at even faster rate in the near future. This has prompted Airbus to look to the market with offers for supplying their most modern and up-to-date aircraft for meeting the country's needs. According to media reports, the aviation industry of Bangladesh would be doubled in 15 years - at par with the global growth rate of aviation industry. The global air traffic has proved to be resilient to external shocks and doubles in every 15 years. 

Bangladesh-China 2nd home-minister level meeting held http://www.bssnews.net/?p=197989

http://www.bssnews.net/?p=197989

The second home minister-level meeting between China and Bangladesh was held in Beijing last week in a bid to establish close cooperation and share intelligence on issues like terrorism and cybercrimes. Home Minister Asaduzzaman Khan led the 19-member Bangladesh team while China’s State Councilor as well as Public Security Minister Zhao Kezhi led his 14-member in the meeting, according to media reports. During the meeting, the minister of China stressed on strengthening the cooperation between the two police forces of the two countries. Asaduzzaman sought the cooperation of China for the safe return of Rohingyas to their motherland Myanmar safely with dignity while the Public Security Minister Zhao expressed optimism over it. 

HPM Sheikh Hasina grieves Notre Dame cathedral fire https://www.thedailystar.net/city/news/pm-grieves-notre-dame-cathedral-fire-1730770

https://www.thedailystar.net/city/news/pm-grieves-notre-dame-cathedral-fire-1730770

Honourable Prime Minister (HPM) Sheikh Hasina expressed deep shock at the damage to the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris on Monday. “We are terribly shocked and deeply saddened at the colossal damage to the Cathedral Notre Dame due to a catastrophic fire,” she said in a message to President of France Emmanuel Macron. The damage to this iconic cathedral is heart-wrenching not only to people of France but for the entire humanity. “With a deep sense of loss and grief, I, on behalf of the people and government of Bangladesh and on my own behalf, convey our profound sadness to you and to the people of France,” reads the message.

New Course: Learn Web Scraping with Beautiful Soup ( https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-web-scraping?utm_source=customer_io&utm_campaign=monday_course_drop_4_22_19&utm_medium=email&utm_content=top_cta )!

 

What does web scraping have to do with soup? Let us break it down.

 

First off, web scraping is when you extract data from websites. Let’s say you want to analyze reactions from yesterday's Game of Thrones episode. To find the relevant data, you can scrape Twitter. Web Scraping is an extremely valuable skill when you need to do analysis on data that is not easily retrievable.

 

So how does soup fit into the picture?

 

Beautiful Soup is a Python library named after a song in the popular movie Alice in Wonderland that can scrape and parse HTML/XML files. You can use Beautiful Soup to easily take information from a website and convert it into a DataFrame.

 

Our new Pro-exclusive course will walk you through how to parse and build a dataset. You'll learn how to scrape a turtle shell-ter website and complete a project that identifies the world's best chocolate bar.

? + ? = 
Hi,

A few weeks ago, Google released Coral, a super fast, “no
internet required” development board and USB accelerator that
enables deep learning practitioners to deploy their models “on
the edge” and “closer to the data” (which is what we'll be
covering today ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjI1NTY2NDg4NiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMjIvZ2V0dGluZy1zdGFydGVkLXdpdGgtZ29vZ2xlLWNvcmFscy10cHUtdXNiLWFjY2VsZXJhdG9yLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )):

Image ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjI1NTY2NDg4NiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMjIvZ2V0dGluZy1zdGFydGVkLXdpdGgtZ29vZ2xlLWNvcmFscy10cHUtdXNiLWFjY2VsZXJhdG9yLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Using Coral, deep learning developers are no longer required to
have an internet connection, meaning that the Coral TPU is fast
enough to perform inference directly on the device rather than
sending the image/frame to the cloud for inference and
prediction.

The Google Coral comes in two flavors:

* A single-board computer with an onboard Edge TPU. The dev board
can be thought of an “advanced Raspberry Pi for AI” or a
competitor to NVIDIA’s Jetson Nano.
* A USB accelerator that plugs into a device (such as a Raspberry
Pi). The USB stick includes an Edge TPU built into it. Think of
Google’s Coral USB Accelerator as a competitor to Intel’s
Movidius NCS.

Today we’ll be focusing on the Coral USB Accelerator as it’s
easier to get started with (and it fits nicely with our theme of
Raspberry Pi-related posts the past few weeks).

To learn how to configure the Google Coral USB accelerator, as
well as perform classification + object detection on the Coral,
you'll need to read the full tutorial here! ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjI1NTY2NDg4NiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnB5aW1hZ2VzZWFyY2guY29tLzIwMTkvMDQvMjIvZ2V0dGluZy1zdGFydGVkLXdpdGgtZ29vZ2xlLWNvcmFscy10cHUtdXNiLWFjY2VsZXJhdG9yLz9fX3M9aWh5bm42cWJtZnk2MWFxdHpncHIifQ )

Adrian Rosebrock

Chief PyImageSearcher

P.S. Google Coral, Movidius NCS, and NVIDIA Jetson Nano devices
are bringing computer vision and deep learning to resource
constrained systems such as embedded devices and the Raspberry
Pi.

In my opinion, embedded CV and DL is the next big wave in the AI
community. It’s so big that it may even be a tsunami — will you
be riding that wave?

I know I will be.

Will you join me?

To help you get your start in embedded Computer Vision and Deep
Learning, I have decided to write a brand new book — Raspberry Pi
for Computer Vision. ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjI1NTY2NDg4NiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9wcm9qZWN0cy9hZHJpYW5yb3NlYnJvY2svcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24tZWJvb2s_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 )

Inside this book you will learn how to:
* Build practical, real-world computer vision applications on the
Pi
* Create computer vision and Internet of Things (IoT) projects
and applications with the RPi
* Optimize your OpenCV code and algorithms on the resource
constrained Pi
* Perform Deep Learning on the Raspberry Pi (including utilizing
the Movidius NCS and OpenVINO toolkit)
* Configure your Google Coral, perform image classification and
object detection, and even train + deploy your own custom
models to the Coral Edge TPU!

* Utilize the NVIDIA Jetson Nano to run multiple deep neural
networks on a single board, including image classification,
object detection, segmentation, and more!

I’m running a Kickstarter campaign ( https://t.dripemail2.com/c/eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiNDc2ODQyOSIsImRlbGl2ZXJ5X2lkIjoiNjI1NTY2NDg4NiIsInVybCI6Imh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmNvbS9wcm9qZWN0cy9hZHJpYW5yb3NlYnJvY2svcmFzcGJlcnJ5LXBpLWZvci1jb21wdXRlci12aXNpb24tZWJvb2s_X19zPWloeW5uNnFibWZ5NjFhcXR6Z3ByIn0 ) to fund the creation of the new book, and to celebrate, I’m
offering 25% OFF my existing books and courses if you pre-order a
copy of RPi for CV.

In fact, the Raspberry Pi for Computer Vision book is
practically free if you pre-order it with Deep Learning for
Computer Vision with Python or the PyImageSearch Gurus course.

The clock is ticking and these discounts won’t last —
the Kickstarter pre-sale shuts down on May 10th at 10AM EDT,
after which I’m taking the deals down.

Reserve your pre-order of RPi for CV now and while you're at it,
grab another course or book at a discounted rate. Question: Why couldn’t Dr. Strange warp Thanos into falling forever the way he did to Loki?

Answer from Adam Bestler
